After spending 10 years giving away art and months holding free art days at his home, Adrian Wilson decided last summer to do the impossible: open a store that didn't sell anything.From that simple idea, The Inutilious Retailer was born. It was created to remind people that buying things doesn't make anyone happy, that a hobby is something important in life and that everyone enjoys making art.The front part of the store is black and white, lit by a giant barcode. In the middle of the store is a slot machine from 1929, the start of the aptly named Great Depression, on a school desk.There are colorful clothes hanging on umbrellas that are free if anyone wants them but first they have to pull the slot machine handle. The reels are blank, signifying the futility of our working lives, though if the customer uses his imagination to describe what might be on the reels, a wall mirror swings open and the customer is invited into the secret workshop behind the wooden wall.There are only two conditions to get the garment, after all nothing is ever free. Firstly they have to agree to use a new garment, paint and printing blocks to create art on a new piece of clothing to replace it. Secondly, they must agree to be photographed so that they will find out which random person made what they picked and which random person will pick what they replace it with.The customer then spends as long as they want in the privacy of the workshop. They are shown how to use the 100 year old hand made stamps but never judged on what they make. There is no right and no wrong. Phones are switched off so that nobody is disturbed and the customer has to use their imagination to describe their experience to their friends.The store also has a secret courtyard garden where every wall has been covered in street art by Adrian Wilson's fellow street artist friends.There are around 300 people who have wandered into the store and found what has been compared to Narnia, Oz or Willy Wonka's. Originally planned only to be open from September 1st to January 1st, single parent Wilson has continued to 100% fund the project from his own pocket ever since. The landlord even lowered the rent by 20% to help keep the store open.The Inutilious Retailer won a prestigious Retail Design Institute Store of the Year award a few months ago, with a special category created for the first time in 45 years of awards. In order not to spoil the surprise element, Wilson only allowed one newspaper to cover the whole store and workshop and that was because The Guardian was founded in 1821 in Manchester by a textile merchant who would have used the same printing blocks.The store has become a big part of the local Lower East Side community, contrasting with the gentrification of the area by the arrival of high end galleries and ever increasing rents. As well as supporting street artists with free and legal places to create, the store has held events and gallery takeovers to provide a forum for the graffiti community.The store's value is in it's ability to inspire everyone who comes inside. In a city designed to make money, a free store makes no sense but it makes complete sense to everyone who experiences it.ŒæWhen your grandmother knitted you a hat or sweater every winter, you didn't ask how much the wool cost or suggest she make a business out of selling more, you just accepted it. The payment for both of you was unconditional love.We all need reminding sometimes that we should sometimes do things just for the sake of it.ŒæEven open a store that sells nothing.Unfortunately, I have run out of funds to keep it going, so I am asking for your help to keep the only store in the world that has a permanent "100% OFF" sale from closing down.

waste lights waste world-ŒæWat kunt u verwachten?ŒæEen enorme wereldbol gemaakt van hergebruikte blikjes. Op deze wereldbol wordt met LED verlichting het afvallicht dat de aarde afstoot gevisualiseerd, zoals te zien in het heelal. Dit licht wordt gevoed door 'lege' batterijen; daar zit nog genoeg energie om LED licht een aantal dagen te laten branden. Wij nodigen bezoekers van het Amsterdam Light Festival uit om lege batterijen mee te nemen en deze zelf in het kunstwerk te steken zodat í©í©n van de 10.000 LED-lampjes gaat branden.ŒæWaarom een crowdfunding campagne?Om dit project te kunnen realiseren hebben wij nog minimaal 5000,- euro nodig. U kunt ons helpen door ons te sponsoren via deze Kickstarter campagne. Kijk bij de 'rewards' hoe u uw naam terug kunt vinden in het kunstwerk. Hou onze Facebook, Twitter en website in de gaten voor updates over het project.Volg het project op www.urbanwaste.nllike it?www.facebook.com/urbanwastecollectivevolg ons! Œæwww.twitter.com/UrWaCoŒæ

In 2014, a grassroots cry for non-violence, among soldiers, police and civilians, would resonate worldwide.ŒæFrom Russiaäó»s emerging imperialism, to a third US military confrontation on Iraqi soil, to the citizens of Hong Kong pleading for democracy, to the militarized police in Ferguson, the time is particularly ripe for an anti-militarist message.Guo Jian + MarcusEriksenŒæwill create a multi-dimensional piece which includes a war memorial statue and documentary film footage about the memorialäó»s creation. 35-40 actors of various cultural backgrounds will be recruited to shoot a movie, documenting the creation of a war memorial. The actors will wear military uniforms representing several military cultures, anachronistic and often on historically opposing sides. Akin to traditional war memorials such asŒæIwo Jima, this group of military men and women would be planting a flag together äóñ but here it is aŒæwhite flag of surrender.ŒæA participatory photo series calledŒæ#SURRENDER SelfiesŒæwill also be part of the exhibition. The artists are encouraging supporters worldwide, from opposing factions, to submit photos with their hands up. Whether or not you can donate, please post a #SURRENDER Selfie.ŒæLearn More.Help support this project and receive unique and meaningful rewards ranging from meeting the artists to owning a piece of their artwork! Check out some examples of the rewards below.Exhibition T-Shirt ($50 Level)ARTWORK: The Reds - #SURRENDER Exhibition PrintŒæ(+$300)ŒæARTWORK: Chi-I-Joe (+$500)ARTWORK: #SURRENDER Exhibition Print Series (+$1000)ARTWORK: "MEAT" Photo Series (+$5000)Guo JianŒæis a Chinese artist who has exhibited worldwide, and has been featured in the NYTimes and WallStreet Journal. He is a third generation military veteran, having served inChinaäó»s Peopleäó»s Liberation Army during the Sino-Vietnamese war.Guoäó»s work is heavily influenced by theChinese Cultural Revolution of 1966äóñ76, the late 1970s, early 1980s war with Vietnam, and theTiananmen Square massacre of 1989 äóñ in which he participated as aprotestor. After theevents of 1989, Guo Jian became a pioneer of the Chinese avant-garde art scene, anda founding member of the famousŒæYuanmingyuanArtist Village.Guo Jian was recently exiled from China, after he completeda morbid diorama of Tiananmen Square, which he covered in ground meat and leftto rot. (Financial Times 123,ŒæCNN).After worldwide coverage of his arrest and detainment, Guo was deported andseparated from his family, ending up in Sydney. The collaborationwith Emerging Collective will be his first project since being exiled.Marcus Eriksenis a US Marine Corp veteran whose work centers on the realities of war,disillusionment with militarism, and environmental activism. He has won awardsfor his service in Kuwait City during the Gulf War, and afterwards became interestedin showing the harsh realities of wartime, and how it changed him and hispeers. He is an environmental activist with notable projects that have garneredmedia attention. Now based in LA, Marcus earned his PhD in Science Educationand has the skills to work with metal, wood, paint, andeven animal flesh. Through art-as-activism, he has brought attention to theplight of Hurricane Katrina victims, plastic in the worldäó»s oceans, thematerial refuse and rubble that results from armed conflict, the shame ofsurviving conflict, and the sadness of fallen soldiers.Œæ ŒæEmerging Collective is a non-profit art initiative, creating dialogue between the First Worldand the Emerging Markets through the prism of art. The program involvesimmersive art exhibitions, mentorship of emerging artists by globallyrecognized artists, and a digital content platform cataloguing these newendeavors. With an emphasis on activist and avant-garde art, EmergingCollective aims to catapult the most promising creatives to the forefront ofthe global art scene, and serve as a cultural change-agent for the nextgeneration.HOW IT WORKSThe program consistsof a dual artist-in-residency program and a collaborative exhibition äóñ one globallyrecognized artist and one top emerging talent. One of these artists will comefrom the first world, and the other will come from the emerging markets. Thementorship relationship will be solidified in their collaboration.First, they will create a piece inthe disused space chosen. The creative process will be live streamed, and thework will be on auction from the moment the work begins, ending when the workis complete. They will also collaborate on an immersive concept andbuild it together. ŒæThe exhibition will be centered around these two artworks.During the exhibition, Emerging Collective will curate intimatediscussions with the artists, as well as other culturally relevant programmingin the exhibition space.Œæ The mentorshiprelationship, and the immersive work that is produced from it, will be theresult of north-south dialogue. Thiswill be a transcendent artwork that neither artist could have imagined alone,and will be Emerging Collectiveäó»s biggest contribution to humanity äóñ toliterally push culture forward.Œæ

jack-prendergast.comI am determined to re-stage and expand the original installation I created over the past two years, building it to full scale, combining previous elements and many new ones.Œæ I would like to get as many people as possible involved and coming along to the opening night or one of the exhibition days.Œæ The exhibition will be held in London hopefully in June next year.Œæ ŒæŒæ The stained glass artworks are completed, and are in storage in my studio.Œæ The goal is to take them out of storage and display them in a suitable exhibition space, and perhaps also tour them around in a truck so that the installation can be seen more widely (have a look below at my model!).Œæ Imagine seeing the work in a supermarket car park late at night, by the coast, or high up on a mountain.ŒæŒæ I have also begun work designing the next installation and can't wait to start work on it.Œæ I am really exited by this new project, but can't say too much at this stage; but it also involves glass artworks, photography, painting and metalwork.Œæ The other goal of this Kickstarter project is to get this new work under way.In this work I was inspired by Aztec and Native American art, comics, folklore and motel signs.Who am I?My name is Jack Prendergast, I am 23 and work in London as an artist.Œæ I recently graduated from City and Guilds of London Art School, having studied there for four years.Œæ I completed a painting and fine arts degree, which also involved a great deal of etching and printmaking.Œæ I began working with glass about two years ago.Œæ Photography and metalwork are also important elements in my work.Œæ I am currently working with photography and combining this with audio.Œæ Have a listen to my lovely friend Sandy talk about her life living in the Arizona desert with her five awesome dogsIn these two works I looked at food, gun culture and Aztec symbolsSeveral years ago a few friends and I drove across North America in a $700 Cadillac (it broke down 8 times).Œæ I loved the trip and was fascinated by the variety in the landscape, people, architecture, and wildlife, amongst other things.Œæ From place to place there were some striking contrasts, in particular the divide between the wealthy and the poor.I met many amazing people, who revealed so many different aspects of this vast nation.Œæ Having documented my journey with photos, audio recordings and drawings I decided to build an art installation.Œæ I wanted to encapsulate the experiences I'd had and the places I'd explored. Œæ Œæ Œæ Having returned to London, I was not sure of the best material to convey my ideas.Œæ I decided to sign up for evening classes in glass work and was soon making stained glass windows using medieval techniques.Œæ My stained glass teacher Carey was brilliant and very inspiring.Œæ I suggested to her that I build a Chapel in which I could record my impressions of America.Œæ She gave me enormous support and encouragement.I did not want the glass pieces to appear like traditional church stained glass, so I looked at old motel signs, Aztec art and patterns, Native American art, video game graphics, arcade machines, gas pumps, comic books, wildlife, art deco buildings and wild landscapes, amongst many other things.Œæ After many weeks at the drawing board, I came up with four key designs (see below).Motels are everywhere in the United States.Œæ They are fascinating places; the architecture, the signs, their strange histories, and the sense of not knowing who has been in your room before you.Œæ I stayed in a particular motel in Memphis which someone had reviewed with - "I wouldn't recommend this place to my worst enemy".Œæ  In my installation the viewer goes through the Gastly Motel room and then into the glass Chapel.Œæ ŒæWhy Kickstarter?I want to reach out to as wide a range of people as possible from many different countries and I think this is best method.Œæ Hopefully, through using Kickstarter, many different people will get to see the project and share the experience.Œæ ŒæŒæ Your support will help expand and re-stage the original project and also get my next project off the ground.When I had the chance to install the Gastly Motel and Chapel the first time, the available space was not large enough to allow for a full installation, which would have included a double motel room with bathroom.Œæ I was only able to use the space briefly.Œæ Your support will enable me to develop my ideas further and on a larger scale.Œæ Here is what the funds would go towards:For the new project the funds would go towards:I believe it is crucial that supporters receive interesting rewards for getting involved.Œæ I have structured these to be as affordable and varied as possible, so that there is something for everyone.Œæ Have a look below to see examples of my work and the rewards being offered.Everyone who can come to the opening in London will also be able to try a slice of my apple pie.Limited edition etchingsBelow are examples of limited edition etchings available as rewards.Œæ I have been etching for four years now and have learned a huge amount about all aspects of the process in the etching department at City and Guilds.Œæ I recently had some of my prints (shown below) on display at the Royal Academy print fair in London.Œæ The series of prints I am working on at the moment are about folklore, animals, gun culture and food.Œæ Below are examples of my previous etchings... new work is under way! Here is how they are madeEtching is a very old form of printing, involving rolling wax across a metal plate.Œæ The artist draws an image into the wax, and then uses acid to erode a groove into the line.Œæ This groove allows ink to be rolled into it, which can then be printed using an etching press, as shown below.Œæ Rembrandt and Goya were both innovators in their styles of etching, I highly recommend having a look at their etchings if you haven't already seen them. Œæ Œæ Here are some close ups which show a bit more detailŒæWhy do guns feature in my work During my travels throughout the United States I became familiar with the gun culture.Œæ While I was there the Colorado Cinema Shooting took place, revealing the devastating and tragic impact that guns can have in the wrong hands. Here is a selection of photographs that I took on my travels throughout the US.Œæ The quality of these images has had to be reduced for copyright protection, but all the photographic prints offered as rewards will be supplied in high resolution and will be printed at optimum quality on the highest quality paper.Œæ They will all be signed on the back with a thank you message.Œæ Photographs are available in different sizes, please look in the reward section to find out more. Œæ ŒæThere are also more images on my website -Œæ jack-prendergast.comBelow are examples of my monoprint paintings.Œæ These are made by painting images on to metal and then running them through the etching press.Œæ This creates a certain texture in the print. Œæ These are one-offs, not editions like the etchings, and they will also be signed.If you were wondering how the glass artworks in the Chapel were made this explanation may help.The Chapel is made up of 22 glass pieces mounted in wooden light boxes and surrounded by 42 light bulbs housed in wooden structures.Œæ Once I had designed the pieces, I handmade each one, using the same techniques as medieval stained glass makers.Œæ The glass was cut and shaped to size, then joined together using lead and solder.Œæ Once joined together I used a black stained putty to enhance the structure and provide waterproofing.For the imagery I used the technique of glass painting, a method that has been used for hundreds of years.Œæ A lead-based pigment is ground down and then water and gum Arabic are used to create a paste/liquid.Œæ This liquid is then painted on to the glass and left to dry.Œæ Once this stage is finished you begin drawing.Œæ I have had various inspirations for the imagery, including folktales, video game graphics, comic books and Aztec symbols.Œæ When each drawing is finished the glass is fired in a kiln at 600 degrees, setting the material into the glass so that it becomes permanent.Œæ The light boxes were all handmade by myself in a carpentry workshop and have strip lighting for illumination.Œæ My friend David was hugely helpful when making the boxes.If you got down this far, thanks so much!

Be a part of history...The Historic Dominion Hotel on the corner of Yates and Blanshard is being transformed into 97 micro-units aimed to service a unique, contemporary downtown lifestyle. ŒæThese smaller, affordable living spaces will exist above a dynamic retail environment within the building.The sign that currently hangs from the building is old, heavy, and doesn't work. ŒæWe'd like to have it re-done, and updated to reflect the new use of the building; we'd like to give the sign a facelift. Additionally, the way the sign needs to be properly and structurally anchored to the building, which it at this point, is not.

Who are we?:Ghost Magnet Roach Motel is a Punkformance outfit from the borderlands of Tijuana, Mexico. This International Sound Collective consists of 2 Mexican visual artists, 1 Japanese performance artist and 2 American punk-musicians. We have been generating these pro-active art projects for the past 10 years, and this spring we have an opportunity to make a big installation "THE COCKROACH EFFECT"ŒæŒæin 2 important music festivals - NRMAL Festival in Mexico City, and South by Southwest (SXSW) in Austin, Texas.ŒæWhat is the project?: INSTALLATION / PUNKFORMANCEThe ROACH MOTEL (stage-installation), a 20 x 40 foot sculpture constructed from scaffolding, vinyl and other paraphernalia for will become our stage forŒæTHE COCKROACH EFFECT tourŒæ, that offers the public the chance to penetrate the boundaries between stage and audience by letting them crawl and interact through the passages of the ROACH MOTEL while GMRM punkforms throughout NRMAL and SXSW.THE ROACH MOTEL (3D model):ŒæMaterial specifications (ROACH MOTEL):Modular scaffolding will be used as the skeleton of the structure, covered by transparent, translucent and solid color vinyl; we will use wood plank platform floors, and LED lighting throughout the sculpture. The ROACH MOTEL permits the audience to travel though the "installation-stage-tunnel" that will be converted into a sound and light passage way that constantly emits the audio-recordings and live punkformances that GMRM will produce at each festival.ŒæThere will be video projectors strategically located inside and outside the structure and a large megaphone will be placed on The ROACH MOTELŒÇs tower that will be used to "alarm" the audience that the Punkformance is in process.What is PUNKFORMANCE?:ŒæWe have been developing PUNKFORMANCE for the past several years, mostly showing in museum and gallery settings for a selected few. Now we look to punkform in bigger venues and to the wider audiences, knowing that the de-contextualization of the "expected concert experience" creates paths to different forms of perception and content interaction. What is improvisation to others is sacred to us, the act of creating sound and circumstance onsite can revamp what is usually a safe and viewer friendly experience, we offer something totally different.some previous examples:Durring the self-titled punkformance at ICBC in 2010, we appropriated the whole gallery space with the projects name painted in huge white on black letters. We punkformed for three straight Fridays, deconstructing the space (painting over parts of the letters and destroying parts of the wall), placing open mics around the gallery for audience interventions and literally flooding the floors with tap water and infesting the space with live crickets we bought in a pet store.Our "Loosing Face in Beijing Tour" happened inside a centuriesŒæold former ToaistŒætemple in the middle of old Beijing, China. In a deep collaboration with Chinese Opera trained vocalist Fenni, Japanese performance artist Meguni Shimizu and French Photo and Video Artist Olivier Modr, we plugged into a tradition of historical self reliance and introspection methods that make sound and noise through collective energies; proving that foreign dose not mean distant nor diferent, only unknown until present. This wasnŒÇt the first time we punkformed without all the "members" physically present, we use p2p video and audio chat applications to shorten distances when we are not in the same room...ŒæFor ALL MY FRIENDS Music Festival in Rosarito Mí©xico, we realized the power of the Punkformance in the "music festival scene". We built on site sculpture for the festival stage that became the "orb of oddness and unique beauty" for a more conventional one band in one band out music festival structure.ŒæThis has been a dream project for all of the members, Shinpei Takeda, Daniel Ruanova, Tony Cozano, Julio Orozco, and Brian Sweda, all of whom have been seeking this new way of expressing ourselves that is beyond what is considered art and music. We want to provide something that is not POP, and yet something that invigorates the cockroach effect inside of each of us.ŒæWho is Ghost Magnet Roach Motel?: "aŒæNEO-GLOBAL/POST-MEDIUM/SOUND-GENERATING/ARTIST-COLLECTIVE"From TIJUANA, MEXICO:ŒæJULIO OROZCOŒæPHOTOGRAPHER/ VISUAL ARTIST, his pieces that border the notion of history, narrative, nostalgia and cultural identity have been exhibited in various places in Mexico, USA and Europe; Met Room Foundation (Barcelona Spain) Nowy Theater(Warsaw, Polonia) Kunst Raum H&H (Koln, GermanyŒæ(official website:Œæhttp://julio-orozco.tumblr.com/)ŒæDANIEL RUANOVAŒæVISUAL ARTIST, creates a variety of objects, images and situations that encourage the public/viewer to re-think their own position on äóìeveryday politics of aesthetics,äó usually focusing on the pleasures that meaningless violence and aggression create in overindulged societies. He is constantly showing his work in the US-Mexican border region (that includes Los Angeles), China, Germany, among other placesäó_Œæ(official website:Œæwww.danielruanova.com)From OSAKA, JAPAN :ŒæSHINPEI TAKEDAFILM MAKER / INSTALLATION ARTIST, his documentaries äóìThe Closest Mexico to Japanäó, äóìHiroshima Nagasaki Downloadäó, explore the memory of post-conflict diaspora, while his äóìAlpha Decayäó installations explore human annihilation and radioactivity. Exhibited at various places in Japan, Europe, USA, Mexico and BrazilŒæ(official website:Œæwww.shinpeitakeda.info)From SAN DIEGO, USA:ŒæANTONIO COZANOŒæMUSICIAN,trained in Classical, Bossa Nova, Rock, and Punk. Has been part of äóìCondomnedäó, äóìLove Sin and Diamondsäó, äóìAntonio Cozano Quintetäó. Played at Old Globe Theater, Coors Amphitheater, Paul Rodriguez and Vicky Carr.ŒæBRIAN SUEDAPERCUSSIONIST,has been part of äóìNeon King Kongäó, äóìStarbucks Needle Exchangeäó, äóìBrian Congrejo and the Handosme Fiveäó.COLLABORATORS: GELASIO MORENO, JOHANN LEITNER, JOSEMAR GONZALEZ, MELY BARRAGAN, NATALI ROMAN, SAULO CISNEROS, MIGUEL ARVIZU, JOEY MUíïOZ and many more.Support us now!:One of the reasons we have been able to keep our artistic integrity and freedom of thought is because we have been self-producing ourselves mostly from our pockets or from sales of our artworks.Rewards price range:20 USD	CD 30 USD	T-SHIRT50 USD	CD / T-SHIRT75 USD	POSTER / CD100 USD 	POSTER / CD / T-SHIRT200 USD	J.OROZCO ARTWORK400 USD	D.RUANOVA ARTWORK500 USD	S.TAKEDA ARTWORK1,100 USD 	D.RUANOVA ARTWORKS1,600 USD 	D.RUANOVA ARTWORKS3,000 USD 	J.OROZCO-S.TAKEDA-D.RUANOVA ARTWORKSYour choices of artist editions available as rewards:Some of these works are limited in number so we reserve the right to substitute any of these within the reward package. See images below of the limited edition artworksŒæDaniel Ruanova - To Kill a Statue I, II, III, Limited EditionŒæsilkscreens / Old Weather & T.K.A.I, Limited edition etchingsShinpei Takeda - The Last Panopticon, Beta Decay series edition ink on paperŒæJulio Orozco - La Taquillera, Limited Edition c-prints / Devoluciones 1 y 2, Evoluciones, paintings______________________________________________Ghost Magnet Roach Motel Album T-Shirt Reward - (INITIALŒæBACKING OF $50.00 usd) :https://soundcloud.com/shinpei-takedaGhost Magnet Roach Motel poster from "Loosing face in Beijing tour"Œæ(18 x 12 inch gicleí© print on archival paper)NEWS:Œæhttp://2015.festivalnrmal.net/ghost-magnet-roach-motel-prepara-una-trampa-multisensorial-para-el-festival-nrmal/

Important update:1Iäó»ve been asked if this gallery is for my art or for othersart as well. Please let me emphasize that this is so very much not about myart. I will focus most of my personal art sales to art fairs and online.Œæ I primarily want to open this gallery for theartistäó»s in this immediate area. And there are many amazing artists aroundhere. I believe they should have a place to show their unique talents. I want(with your kind and generous help) to open thatŒæplace for them to let their artworks shine!Important Update:2This isnäó»t just a business opportunity for meäó_ this is formy community. We are the gateway to the beautiful and historical Mount LoopHighway. Iäó»d love to give those who would normally just pass through anotherreason to stop and check out our wonderful little mountain town. Iäó»m enamoredwith this town and its environment and people. I want the gallery and myself tobe able to participate in the fairs, benefits and parades that help make this afun and community driven place to live and visit.Important Update:3I've been asked if this will be a non-profit or will it becommission based.Œæ The plan is to startas a commission based gallery and start figuring out our options as we (theartistäó»s and I) decide what is best for sales and the community at large. Themajority of the funds collected through this campaign are for one yearäó»s rent,utilities, insurances (including theft and liability), overhead and spot lightinstallation, building and buying wall mounts, ceiling mounts, locking displaycases and shelving. A portion also goes to shipping, painting supplies,canvases, scanning, printing and the other items and services needed to fulfillmy rewards obligations.I have fallen in love with this quiet, little mountain townthat is the gateway to the stunningly beautiful Mount Loop Highway (Google it,but donäó»t blame me if you then decide to sell all you own and move here). Wehave the necessities and moreäó_ Supermarket, restaurants (Chris Pratt hung outat the pizza joint across the street during his high school days), hair salons,a dance studio, hardware store, parks, nice schools and a wonderful sense ofcommunity. What we donäó»t have is a place for local artists to display and selltheir art.ŒæI have been painting in a little studio right smack in thecenter of downtown. Adjacent to my studio is an open space with lots of naturallight and just big enough (approx. 35äó»x25äó») to display quite a few pieces ofartwork. The store front is mostly windows and is perfect for showcasing all the different types of unique artworks created by our fantastically talented Northwest artists. Including jewelry, blown glass, original paintings, sculpture and anything creative and beautiful that will fit in the space. It is on the main thoroughfare with lots of traffic from locals,tourists and those passing through town.ŒæI will have my Grand Opening no later than May 1st,but the reality is we should be open and running by April 1st. Therewards will be shipped out ASAP. As soon as the prints are printed, the shirtsare made by hand, the paintings promised are painted etc., all will be safelypacked and out the door as quick as I can. It will be as much a priority as openingthe gallery.The $33,000 Iäó»m trying to raise will pay for a full yearäó»srent, insurance and utilities. It will cover the costs for art mountinghardware, locking display cases, shelving, lighting, and any flooring andpainting that will be needed. I was a building maintenance supervisor beforerediscovering my artistic talents and will be doing the majority of the workmyself. My wife is an office manager and is helping with the budget anddetails. A portion of the funds will be used to cover the cost of the prints,coloring books, t-shirts, shipping, etc., for your contributor rewards. A smallamount of the funds will be apportioned for canvases, paint, and othernecessities that will help color the world and make it a little more beautifultoday than it was yesterday. With your help I know we can make it even morebeautiful tomorrow.ŒæPlease don't hesitate to leave me any questions, comments or suggestions.Œæ

Aspect 1- äóìLive Artäó» Event Painting- This is the expression of an event or atmosphere where the artist interacts with everyone and everything going on and paints äóìLiveäó the feelings, emotions,  colors and images onto a canvas for all to see. This style is usually not a main performance but done with other headline acts or done covertly to merely paint the specific event: wedding reception, party, birthday, special event, concert, etcäó_ŒæŒæThis is the main painting done for a full 3-Day Event in Jan. 2012. This was the Tri-Cities Sportsmen Show and there are 12 things hidden inside this painting. ŒæClose-up showing some hidden things in the Sportsmen Show painting.... Here are 4 things to look for... 19th, Archery, Merle, & Bev....are all hidden in the close-up above ....have fun!ŒæŒæThis is the smaller personal painting created for the promoters of the Sportsmen Show using their company logo.ŒæAspect 2 The addition of names; logos; dates; ages; anniversaries; places; and/or images etc.that are painted and specifically hidden inside the painting. They are placed  with varying degrees of difficulty for people to then have to find. Some will require the need to get within inches to be able to find- kind of like whereäó»s Waldo but whereäó»s your momma?? Or whereäó»s your doggy? Where's your company name or logo?ŒæThis was done during a 2 hour "Live Art" event at Avalon Retirement in Pasco, WA. I did an additional 8 hours placing the hidden objects and doing final touch ups.ŒæAspect 3- äóìLive Artäó Interactive Event Painting- This is where the artist interacts with everyone  and everything going on  and incorporates the suggestions/ideas of those at the event into the painting. This style is also done as primarily a main performance, staged and directed by myself and those present. Every event  creates its own dynamic depending  on those  who choose to engage in helping me create and design an original painting äóìLiveäó. During this style I am writing down the suggestions and names of those who are mainly engaged in helping to create the painting along with me. Then once the 2 to 3 hour event is over I will spend another approx. 7 to 12 hours placing the hidden objects, text, or images and doing all final additions and touch ups to the painting.I quote äóìLive Artäó because there is a three  fold äóìLiveäó aspect to my style of paintings that no other event painters incorporate.The first äóìliveäó aspect is the literal painting äóLiveäó at the actual event as it is taking place for all to watch. This is what all event painters create.The second äóìLiveäó aspect is an element Iäó»ve designed to add to my style. It is a never ending and ongoing äóìLiveäó  interaction with hidden images placed into my event paintings. I tactically hide images, names, logos, dates,  and other information for people to be challenged to find.  Some are seen easily, while  others will require individuals to literally get within inches to find .The third aspect that I am currently doing is a NEW and  unique style of äóìLive Artäó event painting that I have not found being done by anyone but myself. I am currently  preparing to launch these new styles.There is also one more additional element that I plan to add to my events- all original music written and recorded by myself.  I have been a keyboard player/musician for 24+ years also. This music will be played in the background as I perform each event. C A U G H T I N T H E A C T  MURAT ADASH    NAAMA ARAD    OREN PINHASSI    ERIKA CERUZZI           TOBIAS DONAT    ZUZANNA CZEBATUL     ALEXIS L. GRISíŠ      ELIF ERKAN         STEPHEN KWOK Caught in the Act is a group show investigating relations and frictions between corporeality and spatiality through works located between the kinetic and the static. Based on a dialectical approach to the disciplines of sculpture and performance, this exhibition explores the liveliness of objects and the plasticity of gestures. From dancing bodies to a halt and objects shifted from one place to another äóñ Caught in the Act attempts to take a position from within utilitarian, abstract, symbolic and political moves that manifest into a physical structure and simultaneously emanate from physical space into movement. Gestures of stopping, copying, revolving, interrupting, repeating, accelerating and decelerating are acted out, and subsequently caught in and exposed within the exhibition space. An empty store-frontäó»s physical boundaries provide a frame in which disparate and diverse artistic positions are juxtaposed, yet interwoven into a complex constellation of a whole.

The project idea is a question. What happens when diners in a remote part of the world, far from any city and active, rich art world are exposed to contemporary art that is MORE than an exclusive decoration on the restaurant walls?ŒæWhat happens to the art work when installed in an environment where people are relaxed, social, feeling good and (one can only hope) open to new perspectives?ŒæThe project will focus on showing engaging, idea-based and visual Œæenchanting contemporary art in the restaurant milieu. The art work will not be for sale in the restaurant.ŒæThe diner's reactions - interviews, films and so on - to the art work in the restaurant will be documented on the project's web site.Œæ

(The following should be read as a flight attendant)Hello fellow Borderlings,We need your help transporting the Kaleidoscope and the Space Lift Home to this years Borderland.The Kaleidoscope was originally build for Borderland 2013 and is hopefully returning this year as a communal project restoring the mirrors and once again make it a wonderful place for gazing into a million eyes, stars and blinky lights!In The Space Lift is you will be surrounded by you to a degree that hopefully should kick your Ego into space or make your eyes pop with the true awesomeness of the being presented before you at all angles!We hope that you will help make this happen as many days work has gone into the prototyping, construction, reconstruction and rethinking of these projects!Thank you!Hugs,The So Spaced Out Team

After 4 years running our special retail project in downtown Denver, we are ready to expand to a second location. I Heart Denver Store only sells products from Colorado artists, designers, and creative-focused businesses, and those artists get 70% of the sales made every month.*I Heart Denver Store is a special retail project in the heart of downtown Denver. For 4 years, we have supported the creative community in Colorado by offering a generous consignment model that gives 70% of sales back to artists, designers, and other creatives every month. We only sell items that are designed in Colorado by people who live in Colorado.We have supported over 300 local artists, designers, and creative-focused businesses in our years of operation as well as given them the opportunity to feature their work in a high-profile retail location that caters to a global clientele. We have also expanded into online sales and built an impressive social media reach that promotes the unique creativity that happens in our state. To date, we have sold $2.2 million in local goods, $1.4 million of which has gone back into the pockets of artists and designers.The downtown store has been such a success that we were approachedŒæby the owners of a mall redevelopment in Littleton, Colorado, a suburb of Denver, to build a second store location. We welcomed this opportunity to expand our business model and support even more artists and designers in our great state. The new location is at the Southwest Plaza Mall is set to open in October 2015. We have a signed lease and just need to raise money to complete construction and merchandising, as well as prepare for a larger staff and new overhead costs that come with owning two stores.ŒæThe $10,000 raised on Kickstarter will go towards obtaining building materials for the interior of the store, paying local craftspeople for finishing touches, and funding the first few months of staffing so we start off with a great sales team. Participating artists and designers are helping us raise additional funds on top of what we get from the support of this community.If we surpass our goal, we plan to use the extra money to create and sell more awesome local products like "I Heart Littleton" mugs and original artwork based on the Littleton area. Locals love to find art and designs based on where they live, and they love to support local creatives in their community.ŒæWe have pulled together some awesome thank you items that are exclusive designs for I Heart Denver Store. We really appreciate your support and will ship most rewards worldwide. Match the images below to the reward descriptions to see what you will get!ŒæUnlimited RewardsLimited RewardsWe are offering several limited edition rewards, and you can check back for some surprise rewards that will pop up throughout the campaign. Follow us on Facebook to see new limited rewards as they come up! Œæhttp://facebook.com/iheartdenverstoreI Heart Denver Store started as a special pop-up store project with 24 local artists in a vacant retail space during a Denver city program called Create Denver Week. That week-long store led to a lot of press, excitement on social media, and great sales for the artists.ŒæBecause of the great response to the pop-up store and the amount of vacant space in the city during the recession, we were able to work with the owners of Denver Pavilions, a shopping center on the 16th Street Mall, to get short-term leases for more pop-up stores. After 3 more pop-up store experiences, we were ready to create the permanent store that we operate now.ŒæThe permanent location has been in operation since April 2011, and has sold millions of dollars in local merchandise. It has been an exciting experience to help promote Denver and Colorado's creative scene, which is a major part of the success the state has seen in growth. We meet people from all over the world every day, helping them find something special to bring back to friends and family.ŒæVisit our website to find more info about our program and how it works: www.iheartdenverstore.com/aboutSamuel Schimek- Store owner and the innovator behind the I Heart Denver Store program. Samuel manages design and build of the new store space, lease execution, and day-to-day operations. Lisa Ly Pohlman- Special Project manager and longtime part of the team. She has been involved since the store opened in 2011 and now helps out with special projects like this campaign for the second store. Adam Vicarel - Denver artist and designer who focuses on hand lettering. Adam is working on vector designs that will be used in new store products, as well as design and installation for large-scale murals in the second store location. Scott Bennett - Furniture designer in Denver and long-time participant in the store project. Scott will be helping us design new fixtures in the second store that will promote local furniture designs and sales. Sam Mobley - Sam has been working in Colorado on fine wood furniture and design pieces for years. He has been involved in the store since the very beginning and will be helping to craft the interior displays in the new store.

ŒæWAYWARD BEASTIES ART CAR - Sometime in life's journey, you'll run into someone with whom you'll want to wander around the world. Sometime you might even run into these two! Simon the Turtle and Finkle the Mouse are the wild wandering pair that makes up the Wayward Beasties Art Car!ŒæCollaborators Sam Ogden (@samogdenart) and Macy McKenny (@simonsaysmacy) are back again after Simon the Turtle's debut year at Burning Man 2017.ŒæŒæA shiny geodesic turtle shell riding on a custom-built steel chassis atop four 5000W electric brushless hub motors, Simon the Turtle is a giant remote-controlled car, turning heads while the operator pilots the beast onboard, inside, on top, or even walking/biking alongside!ŒæŒæAs of November 2017, we've finished the initial fabrication for Simon the Turtle, creating the chassis and platform from nothing more than steel and wheels for BM 2017. We hauled Simon out to Black Rock City and successfully registered with the Department of Mutant vehiclesŒæ for both our daytime and night time licenses (Thanks DMV Hotties!). We journeyed across the playa, had lots of fun, snuggled, and made some new friends.ŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæWhile we faced many challenges, the Turtle Team came well-prepared. Burning Man 2017 was a successful adventure, allowing us to troubleshoot real scenarios and test our backup plans, yielding lots of important improvements for the coming year. With your help we'll purchase faster, higher-powered 300AmpŒæRoboteq motor controllers and LiPo batteries to replace our heavy AGM batteries. We'll create the crow's nest observation platform, refine the design of the head/face, and fabricate our favorite mouse pal Finkle to guide our turtley travels!ŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæ-History-Conceived at BRC 2016, Simon the Turtle is an experimental vehicle for providing both a warm comfortable intimate space inside of Simon's shell and an elevated vantage point from up top to safely (and slowly) transport riders, with his companion Finkle the mouse guiding the way to your next adventure!A MOOP-hungry monster, Simon will happily gobble up bottles, cans, feathers, cigarette butts, and any other stray bits you have to feed him! (MOOP = Matter-Out-Of-Place) Not only will he transport wayward wanderers, Simon provides a friendly way to Leave-No-Trace! FEED THE TURTLE!Simon was created based on Macy's sculpture "Wayward Beasties." SAMACY (Sam and Macy) intend to bring the art car to various festivals and art events throughout the year (including Burning Man) to provide participants with unforgettable and unique experiences to remember for a lifetime... and help clean up, one piece of MOOP at a time...REWARDS (BRAND NEW DESIGNS FOR THIS YEAR COMING SOON!!!)ŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæ

An integer overflow is a numeric value represented outside the capable range of a given number of bits. Overflow conditions return incorrect results when the outcome is not anticipated. The unpredictability of overflow outcomes can therefore compromise the reliability of a program.What if some conspiracy theories are true? What if the human desire to uncover the truth is actually an expression of societyäó»s drive to continually question and scrutinize itself? What if our obsession with curbing an integer overflow, in the lead-up to Y2K, helped us to avoid the very calamity we predicted? INTEGER OVERFLOW is the culmination of our research into the similarities between the disasters predicted to occur on January 1st, 2000 and those which did occur subsequent to November 8th, 2016. It is a thought experiment, with the intent to create and then immediately deconstruct a post-human aestheticäóîenvisioning what would emerge in the event of a technological singularity, a nuclear holocaust, or colonization by malignant extra-terrestrial (or subterranean) overlords. It is both a celebration and an indictment of our culture of fantastical reasoning, responsible for the greatest achievements of human creativity and also our pathological resistance to facts, rationality, and logic. The works in the exhibition explore the tales, truths, and taboos surrounding some of the most gripping conspiracies of our generation, questioning ideas about post-American life, protection, scarcity, and consensus reality.Our research will be collected and displayed in a gallery exhibition tentatively scheduled to open on December 15, 2017 featuring works from a variety of media (sculpture, painting, drawing, video, performance, and a life-size doomsday bunker).

'Suspended' is a continuation of 'Flight', which hung in St Jamesäó»s Piccadilly over Christmas 2015 seeking to highlight the humanitarian crisis of forced displacement across the world.Two years later, thousands more refugees have continued to flee war, persecution and famine for the safety of European shores, deepening what has become the worst humanitarian crisis since WW2. Whilst Europe struggles to come to terms with this, human trafficking networks are becoming brutally efficient at exploiting and making profit from the vulnerability of migrants. As a war artist, Suspended is my response to the deepening refugee crisis.This installation, which will comprise hundreds of garments of clothing discarded by refugees on their arrival to Europe, is a direct sequel to Flight. Like Flight, this installation will address the global policies affecting the future of every refugee. In so many cases, these refugees are stuck; they cannot return to their countries, but they cannot move forward into a future they urgently need and deserve. This is especially poignant when it comes to young people, who face an uncertain future fraught with discontent and run the subsequent risk of human trafficking, slavery, and radicalisation.Suspended will hang in St Jamesäó»s Piccadilly for 2 months over the Christmas period and then transfer to New York City, where it will be exhibited in Trinity Church Wall Street, during Lent & Easter.Œæ

Œæ Œæ Œæ Œæ Œæ Œæ Œæ ŒæTHE "FIX" IS IN at ŒæOLD CITY HALL - TALLADEGA, ALThe City of Talladega, AL is an old southern town dating back to 1834.  Talladega county and the city derives its name and land from a part of the Creek Indian nation.ŒæFor you sports fans, Talladega is where the initial Œæconception of Auburn University and Birmingham-Southern College began. The world famous Talladega Super Speedway is a short drive from the city,  Check out the Talladega Walk of Fame Davey Allison Memorial Park located directly behind the Old City Hall building.ŒæNearby Talladega airport is believed by some to have been the site of the first powered heavier-than-air flight made by Lewis Archer Boswell before the Wright Brothers. ŒæIn 2002, the Talladega airport was renamed Boswell Field.The city is also home to Talladega College, the oldest liberal arts Historically Black CollegeŒæin the state, and home of the Armistad Murals that commemorate significant events in African American history.ŒæThe oldest continuously operated court house in Alabama is the central focus of the nearby Talladega Court House Square Historic District which isŒæ listed on the National Register of Historic Places.ŒæŒæThis District is centrally located and covers a two block radius in any direction.The Ritz Theater is another focal point in the historic district.  The theater, with its äóìvitroliteäó glass panels is one of the oldest theaters in the U.S. in continuous use.The Old City Hall building along with the nearby Silk Stocking District and Talladega College Historic District are all located in the city of Talladega and are within a half mile of each other.Œæ . These combined historic areas all support the Talladega Court House Square Historic District making the entire area a must see historic destination.The Old City Hall building is located within 1-2 blocks of these historic places.ŒæŒæTheŒæbuilding was initially planned by the Talladega City Council around 1874. The engineer and designer was City Engineer E. H. Walpole.ŒæIn 1890, the city contracted with B.H. Clardy & Sons to build a structure that äóìwould be suitable for the conduct of the publicäó»s businessäó. Œæ Official records show the building project was financed by "security bonds from New York City". ŒæŒæOld City Hall was the headquarters and focal point of Talladega city government for many years. It was later sold and the city moved its operation to a more modern building.ŒæOld City Hall is a beautiful structure consisting of two levels with a grand front entrance staircase to the second floor. Completed and dedicated in 1892 as inscribed on the cornerstone, the architecture is Dutch Flemish. ŒæThe front facade has several bas relief scrolls, gargoyles, and other carvings. There is a stone carving on the upper front facade rumored to be the work Œæof Italian sculptor Giuseppe Moretti who designed the Vulcan statute in Birmingham, AL. ŒæMoretti is known to have carved many statues for use as grave markers in area cemeteries.Additionally, local stories claim there is a picture or carving on the front of the building depicting slaves working in the cotton fields.Œæ At some point protest from local citizens resulted in the picture being covered.Œæ Looking up you can see a metal like cover on the building.Œæ What's under the cover is somewhat of a mystery.The building has four different but joined roofs.  The peak of which are the two towers with distinct architectural scrolls and carvings.  Unfortunately in the 1970s, many buildings around the square, including Old City Hall, front facades were covered with glass, plastic or aluminum in an attempt at modernization.  Over the years, the Old City Hall building was used for different retail businesses on the ground level.  The second floor, while not used in modern times, consists of several small rooms and a larger room reminiscent of a dance hall or ballroom. ŒæThese are the rooms that housed the city government.ŒæŒæIt is a marvelous space, but like the rest of the building, is in need of repair.ŒæSo now the task at hand is to restore this building, to shore up the structure, make it functional and restore it'soriginal appearance as much as possible. Starting withŒæPhase 1. Œæstabilize the brick facade and windows back and frontPhase 2. Œæroof stabilization/restorationPhase 3. ŒæInterior Beam/Wall Structural Repair/RestorationPhase 4. ŒæInterior structural/safety repair/stabilizationPhase 5. ŒæUtilitiesŒæŒæA portion of theretail space on the first floor will be set aside for community meetings exhibits, and gatherings by various public groups.ŒæWith your help and support, we will shore up the outer faí_ades of the building äóñ to include the windows, bricks, paint, and roofing. ŒæThe building will be rehabilitated to not only reflect it's original Dutch-Flemish architecture of the 1800s, Œæbut also to support revitalize of the Talladega Historic Court House Square District.ŒæCome, be a part of the journey to put the " fix in" atŒæOld City Hall. Œæ Œæ ŒæŒæ Œæ Œæ Œæ Œæ Œæ Œæ Œæ Œæ Œæ Œæ Œæ Œæ Œæ> > > ŒæŒæBE A PART OF THE FIX Œæ< < <Thank you for your consideration and assistance

I've been collecting Pepsi cans since 1989.In 2003 I realized my collection was the largest in the world and I was assigned the Guinness World Record(TM).Despite I've changed house a few times in my life, I never had enough room to display all cans. My dream has always been to built a museum, displaying all cans, sorted by country and ordered chronologically, in order to share my passion and hobby with people visiting the place.Project is aimed to restructure an existing building, so that part of it will be dedicated to display the entire collection. Special shelves will be built for the purpose.

La instalacií_n Derribando MurosŒæes un proyecto deŒækolí‚ctiv.feat, nuestro colectivo artí_stico, que por un lado plantea una reflexií_n profunda a traví©s del arte sobre nuestra libertad, y por otro lado contiene las obras creadas en el Taller de Expresií_n Artí_stica impartido en el Reclusorio Varonil Norte de la Ciudad de Mí©xico por nuestro colectivo, impulsando un proceso de sanacií_n,Œæreadaptacií_n y reinsercií_n social a traví©s de la creacií_n artí_stica. Derribando Muros es el í_ltimo segmentoŒædel Proyecto Libertad.ŒæThe Artistic Installation Derribando Muros /Knocking Down Walls is a project of kolí‚ctiv.feat, our artistic collective, which on the one hand raises a deep reflection through art about our freedom, and on the other hand contains the works created in the Workshop of Artistic Expression taught in the Norther Penitentiary of Mexico City by our collective, promoting a process of healing, readjustment and social reintegration through artistic creation. Demolishing Walls is the last segment of the Freedom Project.La instalacií_n se presentaríç de manera gratuita entre el 28 de febrero y el 03 de abril de 2018, en el recinto de la Biblioteca de Mexico äóìJosí© Vasconcelosäó (www.bibliotecademexico.gob.mx).  Buscamos que la instalacií_n llegue a miles de personas.  The installation will be presented free of charge between February 28th and April 3rd 2018, in the campus of the Library of Mexico "Josí© Vasconcelos" (www.bibliotecademexico.gob.mx). We want the installation to reach thousands of people.ŒæLa instalacií_n se realiza despuí©s de míçs de 200 horas de Taller de Expresií_n Artí_stica impartido en el Reclusorio Norte presentando 4 mí_dulos con escultura, 28 obras plíçsticas, arte objeto y 2 conciertos sinfí_nicos. La instalacií_n generaríç ademíçs el impacto necesario para expandir programas basados en arte para la reinsercií_n social en reclusorios. El espectador recorreríç en la Instalacií_n la transicií_n desde los muros tangibles del sistema carcelario, ajenos a í©l, hacia los muros invisibles que nos rodean, y que en muchas ocasiones generan una sensacií_n ficticia de libertad.  The installation is made after more than 200 hours of Art Expression Workshop taught in the North Prison presenting 4 modules with sculpture, 28 plastic works, object art and 2 symphonic concerts. The installation will also generate the necessary impact to expand arts-based programs for social reintegration in prisons. The spectator will go through the installation in the transition from the tangible walls of the prison system, alien to him/her, to the invisible walls that surround us, and that often generate a fictitious sense of freedom.ŒæLa instalacií_n Derribando Muros forma parte del Proyecto Libertad, en el que buscamos provocar a la intuicií_n y preguntarnos acerca de nuestra libertad, y a la vez se busca probar el efecto positivo del arte en la reinsercií_n social de internos en los reclusorios.ŒæThe installation "Derribando Muros" (Knocking Down Walls) is part of the Freedom Project, in which we seek to provoke intuition and ask ourselves about our freedom, and at the same time, try to prove the positive effect of art in the social reintegration of inmates.ŒæŒæŒæ(Entrevistas a algunos integrantes del Taller de Expresií_n Artí_stica. subtí_tulos pendientes. / Interviews to some participants at the Artistic Expression Workshop. Subtitles in English Pending )(Entrevistas a algunos integrantes del Taller de Expresií_n Artí_stica. subtí_tulos pendientes. / Interviews to some participants at the Artistic Expression Workshop. Subtitles in English Pending )El Proyecto Libertad incluye el Taller de Expresií_n Artí_stica dentro del Reclusorio Norte, series de retratos fotogríçficos y de retratos hechos con escanner de los internos-artistas, realizados por Lulí_ S. Puig artista visual miembro del colectivo, la creacií_n de 16 obras de intervencií_n individual (Serie Libertad äóñ intervenciones colaborativas) creadas por los internos sobre las series fotogríçficas y 12 obras de intervencií_n colectiva de gran formato (Serie Libertad äóñ intervenciones colectivas) creadas por los internos y artistas fuera de prisií_n; la publicacií_n de un libro, 2 exposiciones. Derribando Muros cierra el proyecto.Lo vivido hasta ahora nos han enseí±ado la gran capacidad del arte de cuestionar, pero tambií©n de regenerar y reconstruir ví_nculos entre personas y de abrir oportunidades y esperanza de reinsercií_n. Esto fue realmente emocionante.The Freedom Project includes the Workshop of Artistic Expression in the North Prison, series of photographic portraits and portraits made with scanner of the inmate-artists, made by Lulí_ S. Puig visual artist member of the collective, the creation of 16 works of individual intervention (Freedom Series - collaborative interventions) created by the inmates on the photographic series and 12 large-scale collective intervention works (Freedom Series - collective interventions) created by the inmates and artists outside the Penitentiary; the publication of a book, 2 exhibitions. Derribando Muros closes the project.What we have experienced so far has taught us the great capacity of the art to question, but also to regenerate and rebuild bonds between people and to open up opportunities and hope for reinsertion. This was really exciting.ŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæLa instalacií_n se desarrolla en un espacio de 165m2 rodeado de alambrada que incluye cuatro mí_dulos y un espacio de exhibicií_n para las 28 obras creadas en el taller. Cada mí_dulo presenta un contexto diferente del encierro, los dos primeros se vinculan con el entorno carcelario, los sonidos propios de la cíçrcel, la estí©tica carcelaria, ajenos al espectador (ver video). El tercer mí_dulo nos traslada a un entorno vinculado a nosotros, escenificando nuestras limitaciones fuera del espacio carcelario a traví©s de esculturas que se adhieren a las paredes. En el í_ltimo modulo, desaparecen las paredes y se presenta al ser humano empaquetado como objeto estandarizado, mientras, un algoritmo que se alimenta del äóìíçnimo social colectivoäó encontrado en las redes sociales, lo traduce en imíçgenes y llena varias pantallas planas.The installation takes place in a space of 165m2 surrounded by wire that includes four modules and an exhibition space for the 28 works created in the workshop. Each module presents a different context of the confinement, the first two are linked to the prison environment, the sounds of the jail, prison aesthetics, alien to the spectator (see video). The third module takes us to an environment linked to us, staging our limitations outside the prison space through sculptures that adhere to the walls. In the last module, the walls disappear and the packaged human being is presented as a standardized object, while an algorithm that feeds on the "collective social mood" found in social networks, translates it into images, fills several flat screens.ŒæComo parte de la instalacií_n, los dí_as 17 y 18 de marzo la Orquesta Carlos Chíçvez ejecutaríç en dos conciertos en formato inmersivo (el director se encuentra en el centro de la sala y los mí_sicos se sití_an entre el pí_blico), la Cantata äóìSueí±osäó de Arturo Míçrquez junto con textos de Martin Luther King, Gandhi y el Jefe Seattle, haciendo conciencia de cí_mo las limitaciones individuales acaban transformíçndose en muros colectivos.As part of the installation, on March 17 and 18 the Carlos Chíçvez Orchestra will perform in two concerts in an immersive format (the director is in the center of the room and the musicians are among the audience), the Cantata "Sueí±os" of Arturo Míçrquez along with texts by Martin Luther King, Gandhi and Chief Seattle, making aware of how individual limitations end up transforming themselves into collective walls.La instalacií_n requiere de recursos por 197,500 pesos, mismos que seríçn utilizados para la construccií_n de los mí_dulos, creacií_n de esculturas, alambradas, sistema elí©ctrico, pantallas planas, entre otras cosas (ver descripcií_n detallada míçs adelante). Important: Unless the project reaches it's full goal by the 22nd of January, your money will be totally refunded - If you donate and want something engraved, you don't need to decide on your message until Feb 2018 (you will be emailed asking for your request)A few months ago I decided to create a walk through musical trail using huge metal instruments that would be played by the wind, rain and passers by. The first thing I did was find a place that was willing to host it, so I bothered a lot of people, and eventually Lotherton hall agreed to have it set up in their estate. Then I found a sculptor whoäó»s created similar projects before, together we worked out the budget of Œ£3300 for materials, workshop space, labour and transport; we immediately considered applying for arts funding.Then I thought, because this is a project for everyone, I want everyone, or as many people as possible to be involved in making it. So I set up this kickstarter page.ŒæPeople have already ready gotten on board, because they can see that in a climate of cuts to art funding, this project will be another burst of colour in what can otherwise be a very dull world.Although thereäó»s been a lot of interest, we still have a long way to go and a short time to get there, so Iäó»m asking that you please give whatever you can towards this. No money will leave your account until the 22nd of January, and only if we reach the full target.Giving Œ£10 or more will let you engrave your name and a message on the instruments themselvesIt'll be your unchanging mark on something that sounds different on every visit. Please, donäó»t hesitate, the deadline is the 22nd of January, give whatever you can now, because how often do you get chance to be part of something like this?ŒæJed xMore Info-Lotherton website-http://www.leeds.gov.uk/museumsandgalleries/Pages/Lotherton-Hall.aspxEstimated completion: April-May 2018Check Facebook and Twitter for more info and updates -Œæhttps://www.facebook.com/The-Singing-Forest-162336607707555/https://twitter.com/theforestsong

We are Lina and Ania and we are the creators of PURGATORY. We are both Architectural Designers based in Leicester, UK  and we have been working on this project for over a year now.Œæ ŒæPURGATORY is an architectural installation unmasking contemporary socio-political alternative reality. It has been created after thorough research in historical background, observation and participation in various civic affairs. ŒæPURGATORY is a rather inconspicuous structure from the outside and it surprises with an intricate journey on the inside. We are both very satisfied with the design and we feel strongly that everyone should experience it which is why we need your help!ŒæPURGATORY will be constructed in StudionAme in Leicester and first shared on 10th of February until 5th of March 2018 at Attenborough Arts Centre, University of Leicester, UK as part of DeStress Fest. ŒæWe received funding from Attenborough Art Centre which helped us with studio renting but we need quite a lot of money for materials as it is a 50 square metre structure!ŒæMATERIALS WE NEED:Furniture foam, MDF boards, structural timber posts, hard board sheets, spotlights, printing, black frames, mirror roll, spray mirror glue, black paint.ŒæIf we are successful PURGATORY will then tour to venues and outdoor public spaces, drawing upon and informed by audience feedback to fuel the second part of this installation which will be developed and delivered in later 2018.ŒæŒæŒæPURGATORY is our reaction to recent events in which media and politics are conflated. From the outside the installation looks like a large black room with a very small door. It leads into a dimly lit constricting corridor, forcing the participant to crawl and negotiate maze-like obstacles symbolically representing the constrictions imposed by authority and shared as riddles via the media.ŒæThe participant views posters with strong empowering messages in äóÖpropaganda-styleäó» on the walls of the maze. The posters are revealed in different lighting atmospheres and room sizes. Small openings offer views into unreachable spaces. The journey through the maze builds up tension, representing the feeling of gradually getting more and more lost in this reality. Finally, in the central space, the participant encounters an alternative reality. The space is well lit and the walls are covered with reflective material, in the middle stands a reflective box creating distorted reflections of the participant and their surroundings. Here, the participant can challenge pre-formed perceptions of body and senses and is forced to analyse this new perception, possibly as a mental confessional, a purging evoking clarity of perception. Upon exiting and returning to a world which is day lit and full of straight lines we expect the participant to evaluate everyday reality with a rediscovered scrutiny and freshly recalibrated senses.ŒæIs this place familiar?  ŒæIs this your reality?  ŒæPurgatory has reset you.ŒæŒæŒæŒæArchitectural design and concept: Lina Geseviciute and Anna Chorzepa Curator: G Sian (InkMilk) Special thanks to:ŒæG Sian (InkMilk) for curating our project and supporting us throughout,ŒæKishan (Zeropence) for being our camera man and spiritual guide,ŒæKajal Nisha Patel for allowing us to use her photography with Lina and Mette after Women's Protest in London.DJ Format and Sly5thave for giving us rights to use their wonderful music and endorsing our ideas!ŒæŒæ

We strive to teach.Œæ We strive to inspire.Œæ Combining art and science allows our museum to make lasting memories for children.Colossal Fossils is a natural history museum nestled in the middle of a shopping mall which, in turn, is nestled in Central Wisconsin.Œæ Every three months, we have been creating new, exciting science exhibits that combine hands-on art activities with the science displays.Œæ This gives children a chance to spend more time with each display, allowing them to glean more information from the items in our collection.The latest exhibit that we will be featuring is called "Sea Monsters," and showcases a collection of aquatic reptiles that ruled the world's oceans during the Mesozoic Era.Œæ These include animals such as ichthyosaurs, and mosasaurs.Œæ We will be giving kids an opportunity to touch these fossils and fossil replicas that come from animals that are millions and millions of years old.Kids will make origami mosasaurs.Œæ They will make giant crayon rubbings from a 60" swimming reptile.Œæ The funds generated from this Kickstarter campaign will cover the cost of these art supplies, as well as help us acquire the fossil replicas necessary to make this exhibit complete.

Hello friends and future pergola discussionors! The people pergola is a project focused on helping people come together under one roof! A pergola is an amazing way to create an intimate gathering space in an otherwise open world. Pergolas are a great place to put chairs and shield your eyes from blinding sun. My hope is to erect a Pergola like the one in the photo and then have our supporters come together for an intimate outdoor gathering to celebrate this work of art in the community of Green Bay, WI.  The pergola will be a way to invite neighbors in, friends, and other guests all who will share the pergola with us. Our pergola will measure 14äó» x 15äó» feet between posts and will be built out of Cedar. I will first dig some holes in the ground, and then add some concrete to create something called a footing.  The footings will have picture drawn in the concrete to represent the new beginnings, my wife and I will add our personal touches to the concrete with a paper clip and draw a decorate picture or two. Once footings are set, we will put up posts and continue building the people pergola from there. While the project is being built, we will continue to think about how it will draw people together in outdoor fellowship. Œæ Our goal is to create a gathering place for friends, family, kickerstarter people, kids, dogs, and anyone who appreciates the intimate setting of a pergola, and the design elements of stick construction.Œæ

In the cover of darkness I plan to fill my grandparent's lawn with plastic flamingos. I have found a place that sells smaller ones with rotating wings for $3 each. All funds raised will be spent on flamingos.

The Residency:This winter I'll be following the heat and heading to Buenos Aires, Argentina as an artist in resident with the 'ACE Foundation. Its a non profit organization that promotes the generation of ideas and innovative practices, and international culture exchange.The 'Ace Residency Program is one of the major projects supported by the foundation. The program aims to promote contemporary artistic practices that use printmaking, photography, design, and new media to explore mutual hybridization, and multiple capacity though research, and production to promote the exchange, and discussion of collaborative work.ŒæDuring the residency I'll be using the 'Ace facilities to learn more about various printmaking methods, and incorporate my findings with my current artistic processes. I will create large scale immersive installations (public) that incorporate print, body movement, and fiber art.The money raised through Kickstarter will go toward:BASIC RESIDENCY FEE: US$2320INSTALLATION: US$ 600TECHNICAL/CURATORIAL ASSISTANCE: US$ 500SHARED LODGING: US$ 500Concept:I am aware of the space between the sky and the ground but I am more interested in the point of intersection- where these two things meet and how they actually connect. What is our role in this relationship?We sprout up from the ground, and walk this surface as if the earth beneath our feet is flat. There is infinite direction. A million courses jetting from the body attached to a series of labyrinthian grids. We weave our way through, solitary, and grounded, sharing our weight with the world- asking it to support us while we use it hoist ourselves up.There is always something at our feet. And at our feet we are each at the top of the world. Our world.As individuals we are grounded and independently responsible for our weight, and the placement of our bodies. What happens to this point of groundedness Œæwhen we collide with something or someone else- when the point beneath our feet shifts slightly to acknowledge another energy-when we confront each other with our weight. Is this intimacy?There is no bridge between us but we are aware of the space we take and that which we give.The nature of this relationship is intuitive, perceptive, sensitive, and understanding, because to shift the centrifugal point is both violent and tender. We ritualize this point through movement, space, weight, and the sharing of these things.***Video filmed and edited by Gleb MikhalevCurrent Work:

This art installation grew out of my frustration with how issues around the environment are being handled.ŒæIf the interests of the environment are on one side, and the interests of money on the other, there seems to be an block that neither side can get past. Both sides counter each other with like for like: both have good arguments for and against; both have dedicated scientists that support their views; both seem to get no where in advancing change.ŒæHowever, I don't believe the money side needs to win. A draw is good enough. It keeps things the way they are. And money continues to advance, and the environment continues to suffer.Object 5, "Let Earth Win", picks up on this struggle. It uses the game board and play of naughts and crosses to describe what is happening and a solution. Naughts and crosses is a futile game. Between two skilled opponents the result should always be a draw. If we substitute environment for the naughts and money for the crosses, the result is the same. Two skilled opponents, playing the game, always result in a draw. The question is, "Is that okay?"ŒæThe installation raises questions about arguments and power and "winning". Money (growth, wealth, greed) only needs a draw to keep winning. But the Earth will continue to lose while there is a draw. And nothing will change.ŒæThe only solution is for money to let earth win.ŒæHowever, I think it would be wrong to think of money as only corporations and big business. It starts with individuals, and the daily choices we make, and if we are able to let earth win.ŒæThis is the installation. A small handmade object, made out 100% recycled cardboard, using letterpress techniques to create a beautiful and simple game to engage with the issues around the environment. It is not a poster to rally the masses. It is a small object, 20cm by 20 cm, to engage two people at a time, and challenge us to think about our own responses to the environment and money and what we can do to make a change for the better.
