The ADAM wants to welcomeŒæJA, a performative installation inspired byäóÂJosef Albers,the concept of abstractness and unicorns by OHT. The show will be presented at ADAM,Œæjust 150 m from the Atomium, the symbol of Brussels.Born only one year ago, the ADAM is a museum dedicated to art and design of theXX and XXI century.ŒæNow, you can become a contributor for OHT's latest sitespecific installation äóñ performance for the first time in Belgium. Your helpwill allow them to do the rehearsals and a period of set-up before thepresentation on the 14thŒæ and15th of May.JA is a site-specific version of Squares do not (normally) appear in nature, a show by OHT that buildson how Josef Albers himself drew away when he left the Bauhaus for America. Hewas not only traveling across the Atlantic to a new life in the US, but also toa deeper kind of observation -one that brought him to the essence of how theworld and objects are built and thus perceived.By presenting the exhibition The Bauhaus #itsalldesign, the ADAMŒæis the ideal context to show OHTäó»s performanceinspired by Josef Albers, who played a leading role in transmitting the moderndesign principles of the Bauhaus to the United States and whose fundamentalresearches are displayed in the exhibition.ŒæJA confronts the audience with an aural and visualspace: 13 experiments of sound and vision without the use of performers. Theworkäó»s basis is the awareness of colours via certain protagonists: light, mist,glass, font and image. This is akin to how apparently abstract themes are theactors of Josef Albersäó»s research of reality.Observation is connected to the physical action ofseeing. Albersäó»s words and criteria, as much as his materials äóñ his palette andhis objects äóñ visually connect the audience to a renewed kind of narration. Aslowed down narration, which brings the audience to terms with unfamiliarreferences and their own predisposition to open eyes. An attitude that Albershas already envisaged with his work. Perception, as Albers conceived it in histeaching, from the years of Bauhaus to Black Mountain College and Yale, is nowon stage. JA is -first of all- an invitation to hear, see andspend time. This work also regards nature and what normally doesnäó»t appear init. In particular, the performance dramatizes abstract effects by stagingnatural phenomena such as rainbows and the northern lights. This specificchoice deconstructs the misleading convention that abstract art is tooimpersonal or cold. No wonder that Elaine de Kooning noted äóìhowever impersonalhis paintings might at first appear, not one of them could have been painted byany one but Josef Albers himselfäó.The Bauhaus#itsalldesign,is an exhibition by Vitra Design Museum and it will be hosted by ADAMŒæŒæthis year from March, 15 to June, 11. The exhibition presentsa comprehensive overview of design at the Bauhaus encompassing a multiplicityof rare, in some cases never seen before, exhibits from the fields of design,architecture, art, film and photography. At the same time, it confronts theBauhaus design with current debates and tendencies in design and with the worksof contemporary designers, artists and architects. In this way, The Bauhaus #itsalldesign reveals the surprising present-day relevance of alegendary cultural institution.WHAT IS OHT?The artistic research of OHT takes on from the wishthat Google does not answer to all the questions. Therefore, OHT investigatesreality and its representation without limits in terms of shape, genre andemotion. OHT has collaborated with national and international institutions suchas Artistsäó» Salon NYC äóñ ONDA (FR), Triennale di Milano (IT), Prague Quadriennal(CZ), Whitechapel Gallery London (UK), MAXXI museum (IT) and many more. FinallyCentrale Fies (IT) and MART museum (IT) have frequently been partner of variousprojects, either for productions or for premieres."OHT springs out of the will of making theabstract concrete" /ŒæIcon Designäóì[...] one of the most interesting [theatre companies]of the independent sceneäó /ŒælaRepubblica"atalented company" /ŒæSKYArte"it brings back theatre to its deepest roots, aplace for existential resistance." /ŒæilFatto QuotidianoäóìOHT [äó_] is a company encompassing artists fromdiverse backgrounds to invent original contaminations of different languages.äó /ŒæHystrio magazine

cafí© con arte y cultura.Hola mi nombre es Jonatan Almeida Juarez, este es un proyecto que he estado pensando desde hace tiempo, se trata de un cafí© en el que se vuelve una experiencia llena de cultura, pues habríç libros de todo tipo, para cada gusto, incluso libros que te ayuden en la escuela.la idea comienza a partir de......yo vivo en San Mateo Tlaixpan, tecamachalco, Pue. Mí©xico.es un pueblo en donde la juventud empieza a tomar un camino equivocado, en este cafí© haremos lo posible por cambiar la forma de pensar, y de crear conciencia acercaŒæde varios íçmbitos, cultura, polí_tica, etc.Cabe mencionarŒæque es un establecimiento en al aire libre (en la azotea de una casa, justo en el centro de la poblacií_n), en donde tomarse un cafí©, con el cielo como principal atraccií_n, seríç algo extraordinario.

"I'm actually scared to see how this installation would come to life..I'm scared of how the metaphor wouldactually work and reminds me of those days that I sit next to her hospital bed, watching..hoping..praying toGod..that she would open her eyes and wake up from her coma äóñ which deep down inside I knew would neverhappen"äóìTransfusionäó is an interactive conceptual installation that serves as an ode to the artistäó»s mom, who diedof a rare blood disorder called AIHA in 2011.The installation encompasses a white gallery space as the foundation upon which hundreds of black flexiblerubber channels containing linear LED lights traverse the space, sprawling from wall to wall and across theceiling.The channels intersect, overlap, and meander - transforming the environment into an intricate circulatory system ofpattern and light.Visitors are encouraged to touch sensors on the wall located underneath each channel, activating a red LED lightthat slowly fills the channel, flowing from one end to the other, simulating the transfusion of blood througha vein. The more visitors touch the sensor, the more äóìaliveäó the whole vein becomes.Through this interactive element, the artist is inviting the audience to complete the artwork, breaking downthe divide between the public and the deeply personal to arrive at an experience that illuminates theconnections between us. The artist begins the artwork, but the audience in some way completed it.ŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæ

Why should you support this project?------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Dear Friends & Supporters,welcome to the HEART MOVEMENT ...feel!I mean YOU, exactly YOU. The words you are reading - isŒæ Y-O-U . So here we are together now - may I ask you: What do you feel? I would like to give you this experience to STEP INSIDE YOUR VERY OWN HEART. Feel - you are there. At Art Basel we have this giant inflatable heart that fills itself with air and pulses in a breathing rhythm accompanied by light, sound and scent -> for you to enter.It is an emotional experience to FEEL and SEE and HEAR. Straight into your heart.What did you experience while walking inside your very own heart? Is there a feeling ? In our HEART MOVEMENT we ask you to please share what your heart wants to say by using the hashtag #breathingheart2017 via Twitter, Instagram and our public Facebook group. ŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæOur art installation at Art Basel is absolutely free of charge. I would welcome you to enjoy our art project, relax, mingle with likeminded people and have a wonderful time. After the Art Basel, our inflatable äóìHeart Objectäó will be part of the äó_Houses of Emotionsäóì Festival in Berlin in August 2017 and could move on to future events, exhibitions around the world to keep the heart movement going strong and alive. It's time for a new art experience. äóÂäóÂThe following budget is needed:20.000 ä‰å Inflatable heart object (diameter about 10 meter, inflatable seats for 40 people, air blower machines) äóÂ22.347 ä‰å Technical equipment (projector, LED stripes and installation, sound system, light design, programming) äóÂ7.687 ä‰å Light programming, Electricians äóÂ1.500 ä‰å Insurance äóÂ5.500 ä‰å Travel Costs of Team, Flyers, Banners at exhibition8.000 ä‰å Documentation (360 ŒÁ filmshoot and photography) äóÂ10.000 ä‰å Accountant, Shuttle bus, Press agency3.520 ä‰å Exhibition set up, Shipping costs4.500 ä‰å Contingency, Technical drawings, EditoräóîäóîäóîTotal amount: 83.054 ä‰åThe location Basel Filter4 is about 20 minutes driving distance from the Art Fair Basel. We are still looking for a shuttle service sponsor, as well as some dedicated people to motivate the Art Basel audience to come by to see our exhibition. It will be the last stop of Tram 16 to Bruderholz. It would be amazing to have friends and supporters helping out, so we can keep the costs low in setting up and guarding our exhibition. To make our exhibition successful, we need a couple of electricians, digital nerds for setting up and programming our LED show, fog machines, a fog screen, LED stripes 2,50 - 3 meter in lengths for the columns, 6 - 8 projectors, helium ballons or latex ballons with lighting inside and a soundscape artist. Whoever is a filmmaker, photographer, journalist etc. is very much welcome to document our new exciting art installation andspread our message into the brave new world. :)Thank you so much for your time & support! Heart greetings,Johanna ^_^ŒæŒæŒæ

Folks, I am COMPELLED to make this happen in memory of John B. McLemore. I am making a promise to you and to all who share a desire to pay tribute to one of humanity's brilliant minds, that I will do everything I can to make this happen!If you're reading this message, chances are you too were captivated by the incredible story of a man challenged by his own brilliance and misunderstood by so many. You and I have probably shared similar emotions as we listened in awe during Brian Reed's masterful narration of John's life during the 7-part Podcast: S-Town. If so, I hope you will embark on this journey with me.I made the conscious decision not to look up any web images of John's masterful maze in effort to allow my imagination to paint a picture of what I believed the hedge maze would look like on my own. Immediately following the 7th episode, I began exploring images of the maze and was blown away by the intricacy and craft John dedicated to making his vision become a reality.ŒæHonestly, this effort is strictly a concept at this point but my ultimate goal is to make a complete replica of the John B. McLemore maze for all to admire and experience. My vision is to incorporate as many aspects of the maze into this replication, even if it requires flying Tyler Goodson up to Indianapolis and paying for his time to make this recreation as authentic as possible. I would also welcome any feedback/assistance Mr. Reed could provide to ensure this effort is an honest tribute.ŒæAny funds donated to this effort will be shared publicly utilizing an "open-book" methodology to ensure that none of this project is self-serving. Any additional proceeds netted from the effort will be donated to non-profit organizations dedicated to shedding light on the Mad Hatter disease as well as any additional foundations that would parallel John's vision for a more sustainable world. I would intend to work with those who knew John best to identify such foundations.Again, this is strictly a vision at this point but I'm hopeful we can capture the interest of our fellow supporters to make this dream become a reality!Thank you for your shared interest!

Roccapalumba (Sicily, Italy) is called "The Stars' Country" thanks to its two Astronomical Observatories and a Planetarium, the idea is to increase interest in astronomy with a creation of an astronomical village that will improve the existing structures in one hand, and will crate a turistic attractive in another hand. The astronomical village will contain astronomical clocks, sundials, telescopes that will be instructive and artistic at the same time, and also it will contain a park with astronomical toys for children to increase their love for stars and universe. Into the astronomical village there will be also a science exihibit where maths and physics become a play for children and adults, to approach to the knowledge of Platone, Archimede, Pitagora and their discoveries.

Here goes!This project is for my final degree show in June, which will then end my time at university! The reason I'm using Kickstarter is to raise funds for my final piece as I'm hoping to go out with a bang, but I won't be able to achieve my goal without some help!I plan to make 1-3 giant teddy bears to act as interactive art, along side a CRT Monitor playing a film that I've made, on loop. The plush teddy bears will be larger than the average person (over 6ft tall) and anyone will be able to hug, kick, jump and relax on them over the entire run of the exhibition.To create these giant teddy bears I will need a lot of cardboard/paper, fabric, stuffing, thread, weights and patience; 5 out of 6 of those will require money! Which is hopefully, where you guys come in...My practice this past year has been based around the question "Is it morally right to use animals for our own gain?". This could mean anything, from guide dogs to help the disabled, to elephant riding for our entertainment. I have volunteered with police and domesticated dogs in England to see the differences in how they are treated. I was also lucky enough to get a bursary and extend my research further by going to Thailand. I volunteered with the mistreated dogs over there, which really changed the path I was on with my project. I was also lucky enough to spend a week with elephants, which informed my practice even further, helping me to gain research that I wouldn't have been able to attain had I only stayed in England.After many months of research, the main thing that kept cropping up - time and time again - was how animals are used for human profit. To demonstrate this, for my final piece I am creating teddy bears to reflect how children use toys for their own entertainment and pleasure, before dismissing them when they are no longer of use. Whilst observing our societal relationships with animals, it was brought to light just how entitled we think we are as a species to use animals all around the world for our own gain.My hope for this piece is to create an elephant, sheep and dog teddy bear - all filled with feathers, wool and generic stuffing. This is to represent another way we use animals, even if we can't see it. Once I finish making these teddies I will 'hurt' them in all the places I saw the animals hurt on my volunteering courses. The degree show will run from 12th - 23rd June 2017 in the SIA Gallery, Sheffield, UK.ŒæLast but not least, if for whatever reason I have leftover money from these donations, I won't be profiting! Instead, I will split the money between 3 animal charities that I have linked below:http://www.seashepherd.orghttps://www.animalaid.org.ukhttp://www.animalhopeandwellness.org

Hallo everybody!We will create a new artistic performance underwater with a sincrony between coloured light and music and a live streaming involving the Elviscott wreck which lies between 10 and 20 meters deep in front of Pomonte - Elba Island , Italy. For this artistic performance we need to collect ä‰å 20.000.Many divers come to respect the sea and drowned in this heritage site , wich is slowly crumbling because of tides and waves. We would like Honorí© , share it with other ( non-divers too) and make it eternal ... so ...The Elviscott wreck, turistical point of interest since many years, itäó»s  part of the Elba Islandäó»s story and itäó»s located on the west coast near Pomonte village. Elviscot was a small merchant ship built in 1960, 62,25 meters long for 499 tons. Created by Scheepswerven Gebr Van Diepen Waterhuizen, holland. Lavinia Antonio Scotto, Napoli - IT, became his owner and started using it for wood commerce.On 10th January 1972, near the Ogliera rock in front of Pomonte, läó»Elviscot drown: on his route to Marseille due to a storm it hit the rocks, luckily without consequence for the crew.ŒæŒæToday the whole stern, the bridge and part of the flank are resting on a sandy bed just at 12 meter depht. All the metallic structures looking east to the horizon are covered with sealife and fishes.ŒæOn 4th September 2015 äóìLuci da Profondoäó team, in cooperation with Esest (European society for Enviromental Science and Technologies), produced and streamed in occasion of äóìIl Calelloäó fairy, un video - photo reportage to let  the Elviscott re-emerge from the ocean, bringing it on the beautiful Elban shores. The shooting started on the previous evening, 3rd September. Elviscott came back to life thanks to an internal light set up studied by iWave Design, bringing light in the depths.Due to the  great success and the impressive press feedback äóìLuci dal Profondoäó decided to raise the bet  improving every aspect of the show. Œæ

BREAKFAST TABLE - Created by a Hong Kong individual theatre artist, is a news-food-media collage project. In a form of multi-media installation.The collage artwork contained videos, text, some live movement and a small bit of tasting experience.Material and source from mass media and journal published in daily life include YouTube, Facebook, newspaper, TV news and (or) äóìsomeone told meäó.BREAKFAST TABLE Is going to debut in Taipei Free Art Fair 2016 !After all hiding preparation work, we are so glad to announce the table is going to have its first released in Taipei Free Art Fair - a platform without restrictions, promoting artistic freedom. With an Art Fair of artists and groups from all over the world, it is our honour to be part of it and share our work with everyone.From small home collection to a multi-media collage projectBREAKFAST TABLE was a small collection in my laptop start from 2014, to collect the news in digital form, like videos of democratic movements, FB news feed discussion of elections, TV news sound bites of refugees... all kind of mass media stimulating you in every morning.After arranged and edited, it comes up to an experimental collage installation. To share the view of living, political, humanity or just the opinion of the NEWS.How the fund be used?BREAKFAST TABLE is a non-profit art project. We are spending own money and own time to make it happen. The fund we seek this time will be using in the project first released in Taipei Free Art Fair : Travel costs from Hong Kong to Taipei, accommodation costs, costs for all print out materials, costs for the props and decorations.The inner issue we would like to discuss in the collage-- Daily -- We read news and crisis happen in everywhere thanks for the mass media feeding us every day . The crisis happened far away from us locationally, but as a human being, can it touching you? Sometimes I saw theyäó»re having the same food like mine in the news. Is it sort of linkage ? Sort of connection?-- Iäó»m not you, I can never be the same like you. True?-- Iäó»m not the refugee, am I really canäó»t understand how they feel? I was in a protest, is it mean that I understand all the protest? Can we help? Can we give an opinion? What do we need to work on and improve the world? Can we really help and change the world? Can we change something ? Are we really helping? Or we should do nothing?No one can tell easily, we try to look for an answer through the creative process.BREAKFAST TABLE is not a one-time installation exhibition, we would like to bring the table everywhere for share.We got two set of collages editing meanwhile, will be ready to show at the Art Fair in 2016 Nov. More collage pieces will continue to appear in next year. We really hope you will support us by sending us love !Financially support is very important for us to bring the work travel overseas! Please do us a kindness and spread the word.Please visit our website and FB page for more details.Thank you so much !xxxxxxxp.s. All funds are in HKD :)

I would invite you to imagine civilisation as you know on the brink of collapse, we are having fungal takeover. Great! Think of buildings, transport and people suddenly being eaten by fungi...Right, okay, creepy but just think of what it would look like, pretty damn cool I would say!So my endeavour for my final year is to construct a small scale fungal architectural paradise, my vision for this art piece is that it will be encompassing. my intention for the viewer is that they will be completely immersed in the work.The money I raise will go towards fresh produce that will serve as a catalyst for fungi growth, acrylic;which will be the architectural structure for the fungi to grow on. Sounds clips to install in to the space to further immerse the public.I thank you so much for getting this far, I love what I do and I want to share my quirky love for fungi with others. A healthy dose of appreciation for life that exists without us can do wonders...The display of the work will be on show in the University of Kent Degree Show during April/May. Date to be confirmed.

Intercultural, Art For World Peace will exhibit at Etra Fine Art Gallery in the heart of Wynwood Arts District in Miami during Art Basel, Dec. 1-4, 2016. The Fine Art Photography collection Intercultural raises awareness to the many nationalities living in modern day society by enlightening ideologies while initiating a common respect to all humanity and ultimately a peaceful coexistence. I have secured Etra Fine Art Gallery in the heart of Wynwood Arts District. During this period galleries charge Artist an upfront fee to showcase their art as funding is needed for art production, shipping and promotion. Miami Art Basel is the most important Contemporary Art Fair that happens in America as 29 countries send their most powerful, curators, collectors, gallery owner and artists.I need your support to help unite humanity through art!Thank you,Sheinina Raj

ArtEast Map will be a free printed art map and web page indicating the key galleries, artist studios and other creative places that are located in the East End of London; with the vision of building opportunities for many more people to reach and enjoy the art in this rapidly changing part of the city.After introducing the project to galleries in areas of Hackney and Tower Hamlets, the project have support from galleries such as Flowers, IMT Gallery, Degree Art, Bow Arts, Print Club London, Nelly Duff, Hang up Gallery, Arebyte, Peer Gallery, Calvert 22 and many others.There will be no distinction made between galleries as the idea is to provide locals and visitors with an almost exhaustive listing in the selected area.The ArtEast Map will be printed to a high-quality standard and designed by the East London based illustrator and printmaker Claudia Borfiga. It will be completed by an ergonomic web page constantly updated with galleries' new exhibitions and events.It will also highlight a selection of cafes, bars and restaurants close by where artists hang out and where gallery visitors might like to take a break.The printed map will obtain information relevant to the selected participants as well a calendar of events for the upcoming year 2017.ŒæŒæHow was the idea born?We have noticed that many East London art spaces are too often under-represented on art listings, art mobile apps and tourist guides, even though they are areas of London with some of the most substantial cultural and creative activity. Hackney Wick and Fish Island together has recently been recognised the biggest concentration of artists and art activities in Europe.Unit G Galleryäó»s primary mission is to help sustain our local artists and we desire to increase the number of visitors participating in art activities in East London and to offer them useful up-to-date information. We will engage with creative locals to facilitate connections with them.Too often, London tourists are orientated to major gallery names when looking for creative and cultural experiences, when some of them are more eager to discover hidden gems and to connect with the soul of the area they are exploring. We want them to know that there are alternative activities they can do which wonäó»t necessary be the better-known City of London Art Tours.Who is ArtEast map for?ArtEast Map will feature such a wide range of artworks that it is made for anyone and any taste. A short description of each space will be provided to make sure the chosen places will best fit the moment and the mood.We would aim to distribute the map to prospective East London art lovers, be they local residents or tourists, and ask that the galleries and art spaces represented on it will maintain printed copy stocks.We intend for the map to be made available in cafes, bars and restaurants in the area as well as neighbouring businesses and tourist centres.ŒæWhat are the concerned areas?Tower Hamlets : Victoria Park, Fish Island, Bow, Mile End, Stepney Green, Columbia Road, Bethnal Green, Brick Lane and Spitafields.Hackney : Hackney Downs, Lower Clapton, Hackney Wick, Hackney Central, London Fields, Homerton, Dalston, Haggerston and HoxtonŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæAfter introducing the project to galleries in areas of Hackney and Tower Hamlets, the project have support from galleries such as Flowers, IMT Gallery, Degree Art, Bow Arts, Print Club London, Nelly Duff, Hang up Gallery, Arebyte, Peer Gallery, Calvert 22 and many others.Local networking to reach a global audience. With all galleries and participants each communicating their news, every gallery will be able to benefit from each otheräó»s network to be sure they touch a greaterrange of art aficionados. ArtEast Map will also have a presence on social media. Participants will be mentioned in these posts to create synergies and target the right audiences.The ArtEast Map must aim to increase awareness of, and hence traffic to, both virtual and physical creative spaces.The rise of community-based initiatives and local businesses shows how popular demand can push against the dominance of global brands, especially in an area like East London with its own strong identity. Yet when all local players act together there is a better chance if reaching a global audience.How will the money be spentWe are asking for Œ£10,000 that will be distributed as follow:Œ£2000 for the illustration and design of the mapŒ£1500 to print 5000 copies of the mapŒ£1500 to reward the people who have helped us realising the campaign (Video maker, staff)Œ£2000 to develop an interactive mobile friendly web pageŒ£3000 for promotion and to fund the launch event

"Hey guys, looks like the museum failed." What? No, absolutely not! The museum is still alive and well. It's an idea that won't go away, that occupies our consant thoughts. At worst I would say that this Kickstarter campaign failed. Why? Two reasons.First, our goal was pretty high. We knew that going in. But if we only aimed for and got $8500 in rewards, we would not have been able to do very much with it. You would have been sorely disappointed with what that annual pass got you.Second, our campaign didn't spread as far as it should have. We traced metrics through Facebook, Twitter and other online social media. You guys did a decent job of helping us spread the word. But we really missed the mark on the local media. We tried, it just didn't stick. And many of the larger LEGO fan blogs didn't pick us up. Maybe they figured we were too local to interest their worldwide fan bases. Or maybe they didn't like our head shots."So the museum is still happening then?" Oh, definitely. Maybe not as huge as we had envisioned, but we'll enjoy our holidays then rework our vision, find additional funding sources beyond what we currently have, and present a new opportunity for you to help. Maybe it will be on Kickstarter, maybe not.This was a great learning opportunity though. We gained so much knowledge through the metrics about what you wanted, where you came from and how willing many people were to help make it happen.So enjoy your holidays and keep an eye out for what's coming next. You can check in here or join the conversation via our communication list atŒæhttp://www.brixmuseum.com/.ŒæWe'd love to have you continue to join us on our journey!-----I love collecting. And building. And sharing with others. And... warehouses? I've always been attracted to large open indoor spaces where creativity and inspiration can abound without threat of rain, vandals, or pigeons. After running my own Bricklink (secondary market LEGOŒ¬ parts) store for several years I decided I wanted to go bigger. I'd been picking up odd parts as extras in orders, from thrift stores, and from free bins. While they were fun to look at I thought it would be nice to share them with others. Anyone can go look at the Bricklink catalog and see every part ever made. But to see it all under one roof? Now that would be awesome!If you wanted to see a LEGO Museum, where would you go? Billund, Denmark, home of LEGO? Or you could visit the Czech Republic. Still too far away? Maybe Ohio is more suitable. But west of the Mississippi? Nothing.Hence, BRIX. Build, Rebuild, Inspire and Experience.Of course a museum should be about more than just walking through a stuffy space to see things. It should be engaging, hands on, an experience! Have you ever heard of Znap? Do you know how it works with the rest of the LEGO system? Do you want to play with some? Why not!Or maybe you'd like to come to a build your own holiday ornament workshop where you can get advice on building tips and build an ornament to take home. Or you're looking for a fresh summer camp idea for your kids.What's the history of the brick? What does 3001 mean? Find out with interactive displays, detailed layouts and more information than you knew existed!Do you like art? View, purchase, or even sell your art at BRIX! And don't limit your media to just LEGO. Paintings, wood carvings and wax sculptures inspired by the plastic brick are all welcome.ŒæPrivate funding is secured but we also want to make this project available to the public to support. With what is available we can open and be ready to operate, but at a very limited scale. We aren't interested in loans. We'd rather take that money that would be spent on interest and invest it back into our guests and visitors. And supporters!ŒæWe have negotiated a great lease rate on aŒæspace. As members of PortLUG there is no shortage of people that are willing to help us set this up and make it happen. We have friends of all skills and backgrounds that are helping us make this dream a reality including a teacher, a LEGO historian, and a business woman.The majority of operating expenses will be covered by visitors to the museum experience. A retail store will also bring income as well as camp, classes, and events throughout the year. With this income we can continue to improve the experience and expand. We also plan to invest back into the local community by hiring employees and participating in philanthropic causes.The question is not if but when. We will absolutely be securing the keys to our space in early 2017 and setting up the most amazing experience we can dream of. But we would love for you to be a part of this too. Whether you are looking for a unique gift for the LEGO fan in your life or to be immortalized in LEGO, we want to offer you an opportunity to join in with what we are doing.Besides the other rewards we're offering (many of which are exclusive just for us) we will also offer a once in a lifetime opportunity. When this campaign meets its goals, every single person who contributed will have their name added to a LEGO-built plaque that will sit right by the front door of the museum for everyone to see. Once this campaign ends though, that plaque will be closed for good. We will put all of our Kickstarter supporters names on there and never add another one to it, ever again. This is just one way we want to honor you for what you're doing here today.Everyone who contributes $5 or more will also receive an invite to our pre-grand opening, just for donors.What are we going to do with your money? First, secure our lease. Then we need to build it up with display space. We also need to acquire more collections and pieces. Not every display we want to set up can be ready on opening day; those will grow over time. See this spreadsheet for a detailed working analysis of how we will spend funds over the next 2 years.ŒæWe will also develop our education arm with a dedicated staff and curriculum built from the ground up. And the same brainstorming will also develop the events arm offering birthday parties, corporate events and the like.Finally our gift shop will include well curated items that will enhance your experience at home. The Mini Museum rewards being offered here are just the start of what will be meaningful items to take home.We appreciate your support but we also really appreciate you spreading the word!Huge thanks to Boone at Toy Replay for his mad production skills on our video and to Jason for letting us crash his LEGO room for the shoot.

ELIZABETHäó»S VISION...ŒæNew York City's First Flower Farm.This would be the first Specialty Cut Flower Farm within the five boroughs serving both the wholesale and retail markets. The owner and lead designer of the floral design studio SOLIDGOLDOK, Elizabeth Wetherbee, has been working in the floral industry for over 10 years. She has worked as a farmer for seven on Marthaäó»s Vineyard and a floral designer for ten in both Martha's Vineyard & New York City. She has produced, designed, and installed wedding and celebration events and now brings her expertise to the the City that never sleeps. The only place to shop for wholesale flowers is on busy 28th street, which mostly sells flowers that have been shipped from all over the world, that are grown using pesticides and have an horrible ecological footprint, not to mention a vastly shorter vase life than locally produced blooms. This is why NYC needs a sustainable and ecologically responsible flower farm.Elizabeth currently lives in Rockaway, Queens and has secured a 262,000 sq ft lot to farm and site the greenhouse in on Beach Channel Drive and Beach 85th street.ŒæŒæThis farm will be the first of many, serving as an example to New York and global markets that high yield production level urban farms can be both profitable and ecologically sustainable in urban environments when novel designs and niche crops are the focus. Help Elizabeth turn the "City So Nice, They Named It Twice" into a leader for innovative urban agricultural design and floriculture.ŒæFUNDING GOAL:ŒæThe proposed funding goal was intentionally set very low, Ms. Wetherbee has secured clients, space, farmhands and profitable species. She has a decade of experience starting similar projects with less. It is after all New York City! This base funding goal will cover basic expenses including  a small greenhouse,  tools, placing the seed order and delivering product to clients and buyers markets. Anything raised above the set goal of $6,000, translates into more square feet in production. With this goal reached, Elizabeth can get 80,000 sqft in production, equating to over 25,000 dollars of annual income, enough to reinvest   towards the goal of  a 60,000 sqft rooftop production greenhouse.ŒæŒæGREENHOUSE & TOOLS:Basic hand-tools and a tiller are already in use. One of the largest expenses will be the greenhouse. Luckily, Elizabeth has extensive experience building many types of greenhouses, including the proposed design; a 100 ft semi-permanent and the most affordable option for NYCäó»s extended winter season. Check the farm's evolution on our website for drawings, plans, and picture updates as this project grows.SITES:Œæ"Pop-Up Flower Farm":ŒæThe first round of investment will enable a "Pop-Up Flower Farm" on a vacant lot in Rockaway (seen above), on Beach Channel Drive and Beach 86th Street. The site is absolutely beautiful, with a view of the city across Jamaica Bay. Proximity to clients, great sun, good soil and a stunning backdrop make this location ideal.ŒæWHY KICKSTARTER?"This would be the first completely self-sustaining, ecologically responsible 'zero-footprint' floral market of its kind. The reason I am interested in starting with a Kickstarter Campaign, is so that in ten years when these strides have been made, we can look back and say that it would not have come to be if it were not for the general public supporting such an endeavor. I hope that this will serve as an example to all artists and designers, that you can dream big and actualize your visions as long as you are able to voice it clearly to the world. Draw out your crazy ideas, they just might work. I understand that big things start small because I am a farmer. A tiny seed, given the right nutrients and care can grow into the most beautiful flower you've ever seen.ŒæSo, watch us grow from the ground up and soon you'll be smelling the freshest flowers New York City has ever seen!"-Elizabeth WetherbeeŒæ

Dragons and art span all cultures and all time. The U.S. is failing in the craft field. We have taken Arts and Crafts out of our schools and away from mainstream learning. We are not doing a good job of passing on traditions and we are losing the stories of our past. The U.S. has limited craft magazine choices. You can find: Knitting, quilting, and scrap booking magazines in any grocery store. It is hard to find any other projects. At Dragon Art, we believe that the artistic traditions of our ancestors need to continue. So, we are creating a new Magazine. Dragon Art Magazine will show a variety of projects in every issue. It will feature crafts and art that the U.S doesnäó»t currently have a magazine for along with projects we all know and love. It will feature artisans working in the Art business today, and every project will have a link to a video so you can see how those artisans create their works of art. And, because of direct publishing, it is now possible for each volume to continue to be available to the public. So, skills can grow as the magazine continues. If you learn a skill in volume one, you may need it again in volume three, when you take it to the next level. With full instructions, and video links you will have the chance to learn crafting skills in multiple ways. We are trying to raise the money for production costs, paying for distribution, and hiring more artist. We are on track to release Volume one, in February.

Terminal Flux is a site-specific drawing that will be created at the Schlesinger Concert Hall and Arts Center on the Northern Virginia Community College, Alexandria Campus in Virginia. My site-specific drawings are created on location, for that specific location, and last for a predetermined amount of time before they are painted over/destroyed. In conjunction with the transitory imagery, these aspects of the project offer a metaphor for evolution - moving the viewer through creation, existence, and eventual destruction.Your support for this campaign will cover the costs of executing the drawing as well as documenting the project through professional video and photography. (A time-lapse video of a previous project expanding on my concepts and process can be seen here)Terminal Flux will be created by drawing with graphite directly on the wall in the atrium adjacent to, and above the entrance to the Schlesinger Center. The drawing will be over 2o feet tall and 30 feet wide and features challenging architectural elements to work upon. This will be my largest site-specific drawing to date. I will create the drawing between January 9 and 20, 2017.  A time-lapse video will be created to document the entire process start to finish in addition to high-quality photographs of the finished drawing.  The drawing will be on display for approximately one year where it will be seen by thousands of visitors who attend concerts and art exhibitions at the Schlesinger Center, in addition to the Northern Virginia Community College students.Iäó»ve completed over a dozen site-specific drawings in the Washington, DC/Baltimore area; documentation from most of the projects can be found on my website. Iäó»m honored to be the first artist asked to create a site-specific artwork at the Schlesinger Center. Iäó»m confident that my previous successful experiences have prepared me to complete this project. There are many steps and considerations for working in each site, but the process is similar for each drawing. I begin the process with a site visit, where I look for interesting architectural details, which I will engage as part of the drawing.ŒæŒæŒæI complete a number of perspective drawings and sketches, and then proceed to make a number of studies in the studio to develop a vocabulary of marks for the drawing.ŒæŒæŒæOn the first day of drawing in the space, I will lay out the drawing and mask off areas of the wall. The drawing and masking process continues for several days until complete.ŒæŒæThe area around the drawing is then tented with plastic to create a äóìspray boothäó for the drawing, and the drawing is sealed with a clear sealant to protect it.  The tent and masking materials are then removed to reveal the finished drawing.I need your support to fund the expenses for this project. It's important to note that 62% of the budget will be used to pay arts professionals in my community for their contributions to the project which include photographic and video documentation as well as skilled labor for the install. ŒæThis is by far the largest component of the budget. Your contribution doesn't just support me, it supports five (or more) artists.The budget of $4250 covers the following:Northern Virginia Community College/Schlesinger Arts Center is not providing any funds as they currently do not have a budget for exhibitions or special projects. NVCC will be providing me with necessary equipment to access the space (cherrypicker, ladders etc.), which eliminates costly equipment rentals.

The journey will culminate with hot coco and smores!

ŒæŒæWebsite: Œæhttp://spaziotraum.wixsite.com/spaziotraum---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Œæ(T)Raum= from german words Traum-dream and Raum-spaceABOUTŒæThe founder of spazio (T)Raum is Roberta Busechian (researcher, artist and lecturer). She works with sound research questions that are relevant Œæfor the meaning of sound art inside culture, politics, philosophy and language.Sound art, Klangkunst or Lydkunst is an art direction developed in the last 40 years by musicians and visual artists, performace artists and curators. (T)Raum was founded first to discover critically Œæthe meaning of sound art projects in the Œæplace where there are presented, their meaning for experiencing the social and natural scape through the artistic and theoretical work with sound.WHAT IS (T)RaumT (Raum) is a non-profit exhibition project space based in Milan from september 2016 that aims to diffuse and create new containers - and content - for research on sound art in Italy by home and international artists, with hi-fi and also with low-fi recording and sound-production equipment.Œæ(T) Raum wants to make possible the dialogue between sound studies and experimental electronic music, the architectural and rural spaces, urban and suburban cultures, sound curatorial projects and writing about sound metters.(T) Raum artists will develop narration projects (even documentary) as fieldrecordings, radio plays (Hí_rspiel) and experimental elaborations of traditional music;mobilization projects (soundwalks) using scores and sound maps for urban and nature trails; projects such as spatial soundŒæinstallations, live sound performances and audiovisual projections. All of the projects can be helded also by distance, working on theoretical aspects of the sound art research, in every part of the world.(T) Raum will organize also seminars and conferences (by university professors, researchers, field recordists, musicians, sound artists, writers) about the sound art research between artistic and scientific metters. With specific open calls on sound art topics there will be helded workshops Œæand residencies.Past events:- We already organizeŒæworkshops about sound interaction with ŒæArduino and Max/Msp with Marco Pucci.- October/November 2016: We presented the first sound installation, Frag_mented underwater, about underwater recordings and granular sound synthesis- (T)Raum was presented art ArtVerona Art Fair onŒæ16th October 2016, 12 amWHAT DO WE WANT TO DO WITH YOUR HELPŒæThe first goal is to achieve 8,000 Euros toŒæmake it possible to run the space and support the artists during their work at (T)Raum forŒæthe first year (2017). (T)Raum has already many international contacts,that means artists that were invited to present their research and to develop their own sound works, do conferences or talks, Œæradio broadcasts, produce project/research related writings. Some of those artists Œæfor 2017 are Bill Fontana, Nicolíçs Rupcich, Andrea Cera, Seth Cluett, Daniela Cascella. To make possible their stay in Milan, the organisation and materials for the installations, the print of specific project catalogues and ŒæCD releases we will need your support to achieve 8,000 Euros.The second goal is 15,000 Euros, with this (T)Raum will be able to organize the events for 2018, plan more workshops and run the residence programm, where artists could be able to work and research for defined periods.ŒæŒæ(T)Raum field recordings research:Œæ(T)Raum needs every small support, from sharing the project to every Euro donated:Œætalk about it, connect!---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------(T)Raum founder and director: Roberta BusechianCollaborators:ŒæAndrea Cera,ŒæValentina Lacinio, Marco Pucci, Curti Covi,ŒæValeria Di Sabato,ŒæCorrado Polini, Federica Cecco, Matteo Lelli, ŒæAnnalisa Ligorio, Angelo IodicePartners:ŒæPolini EditoreŒæBunker Museum (Tobblach)Œæ

NLS welcomes the 2016 Summer Residents: David Gumbs, Kelley-Ann Lindo and Susanne Winterling, three brilliant artists from Martinique, Jamaica and Germany with diverse art practices.Over the nine-week residency, Gumbs, Lindo and Winterling will bring their unique backgrounds in 3-D mapping, video, paintingŒæand marine bioluminescence together to create a responsive mental and social landscape that investigates the vulnerability of water-associated ecologies andŒætheir link to our individual and cultural experiences and memories.Aesthetically the artists approach the project with diverse materials,Œæcombining amorphous sculptural cues,Œæa lab aesthetic, and a focus on heightening sensibilities and consciousness within audience participation. The artists draw inspiration from Jamaica's marine ecology-- Œæparticularly bioluminescent algae and the conch shell, as well as the context of that ecology within human experience of water-- natural disasters, history, practices and politics.NLS provides organisational, career and infrastructural support with the provision of work space (visual and recording studio space), critical feedback and event programming. Your donations help cover the cost of their materials, accommodations and travel expenses for the project.More About the Artists:Susanne WinterlingWorking across film and photography, Winterling is known for installations that critically intervene in their surroundings, directing attention to the sensual and perceptual qualities of spaces, objects and the representation of realities. Winterling's most recent exhibitions include 'Nature after nature' at the historical Fridericianum, Kassel, 'Drift' at the Gallerie Parrotta Contemporary Art, in Stuttgart, and 'The Lulennial: A Slight Gesturay', in Mexico City. In her exhibitions, her interests include biodiversity, nature/culture, and subjectivity to technology. Opting for a poetical rather than a power oriented practice, Winterling focuses on the entanglement of ecology and politics. She is also one of the founders of the art collective Akademie Isotrop, and is a professor of contemporary art.David GumbsGumbs is a multimedia artist who approaches his practice through drawing, painting, photography, new media, and interactive video. He has taken part in several new media festivals including the Trinidad and Tobego Film Festival, the Transforming Spaces in Bahamas, the Biennale Internationale Däó»Art Contemporain (BIAC) in Martinique, and the Beep Bop Boop New Media Festival in Florida. In his works, he explores the offscreen of perception, memory, the cycle of life, the visible and invisible, and rhizome graphical macroscopic universes. Gumbsäó» polymorphic art reveals the interbreeding and hybridization process in the collective and individual unconsciousness in Caribbean imagination. His artistic approach is based on a famous quotation from XVII th century French philosopher and chemist Antoine Lavoisier: äóìMass is neither gained nor lost, merely transformed.äóKelley-Ann LindoLindo works in photography, videography and painting. She earned her Bachelors of Fine Arts in Painting at The Edna Manley College of the Visual and Performing Arts in 2015. Lindo serves as art counselor at the Bellevue Hospital and the Jamaica Council for People with Disabilities. She utilizes elements of fragility and abstraction to fuel a tradition of remembrance art, as she seeks to break the passivity of the spectator. Her work predominantly explores the memories and visual legacies that remain after flooding, and through the manipulation of fragile materials she demonstrates the susceptibility of memory and the necessity of recollection.

The NYC&T show is a labor of love, an homage to the sights, sounds, and feelings of New York. It stands for New York City & Tom (me). I have been working on the show for years, doing paintings, installations, and brainstorming ideas of different ways to depict the city in a bigger way than just a gallery show with pictures on the wall. I want the show to mimic the largeness and the compactness of the city.ŒæTo fully realize my vision, I need to enlist the generosity of people like you. We need capital to complete the construction of several installations. There will be a subway installation that will mimic the feeling of standing in the station while the trains go by, using audio and video. Pull up a stool to the bar, or cozy up in a corner booth where you can sit and watch the traffic outside the window. Pick up a newspaper or magazine from the newsstand and grab a table at the Italian restaurant outside the entrance to the subway. And of course, there will be paintings adorning the walls and sculptures filling the space. All of it has been inspired by my love for that city, and created by me, with a lot of help from my friends.To thank you for your help, we have come up with some gifts that we hope will entice you to pledge your support. Any contribution amount will help, and we have a wide range of gifts to choose from. Below are photos of what you can have:This mural was commissioned by the Original Hot Dog Place, in the San Francisco Bay Area, but is not typical of what the NYC&T experience will be. It's kind of a fun piece about New York, and it was one of the things that got me excited to visit for the first time.For $20, you can choose from a coffee mug with the show logo, a mousepad with a painting I did of the infamous Hotel Chelsea, or a pack of eight of the above postcards with a personalized note from me on one of them:ŒæTaxicab bowties, handmade by my daughter Miranda. She appears in the video above, and has been instrumental in making this show happen.We are offering prints of some of the pieces of art that will be on display:ŒæHere is the neon sign that could be yours for a pledge of $400:My love for New York City took root the first time I visited that great metropolis, when I was in my early twenties. I grew up in the San Francisco Bay Area during a time when it was still somewhat rural and quiet. Imagine my surprise, as I walked down the crowded sidewalks of Manhattan, and heard a deep rumble while the ground began to shake. As a Californian, my first thought was, "Earthquake!". I soon realized that it was the subway beneath my feet that caused the shaking.I have since been to New York City six more times, and the excitement and thrills have never diminished. It's changed so much over the years, but always somehow retains the essence of what it is: an international hub for commerce, finance, fashion, art, and entertainment. As a night-owl, I feed off the energy of the city to keep me going even during the day; I don't need any other stimuli. New York, to me, is the greatest modern city existing today, and I hope this exhibit can capture some of that feeling.Œæ

ŒæThe project has a fundamental purpose of being able to spread the magic world of magic is a fundamental reason that will generate theses and conjectures that requires thinking and researching reason to discover the secret of it and is intended to keep you occupied without deviating in your moment of idleness resources with alcohol drugs and sedentary lifestyle so it is magic because it forces you to make changes in your life and is the fundamental purpose of this project will also try to spread the magic in a workshop as it is a circus for large quantities and then those same people who have occupied most of his time in Learning magic can present this Circus for people to see the progress of the magic world is the specific purpose of this circus world channel to help and promote magic worldwide

We would like for American artist, Dale Chihuly to build an installation near where Pulse Nightclub is. After the tragedy that occurred June 12, 2016 we wish to bring back love, life and hope to the grounds ofŒæS Orange Ave, Orlando, FL. In memory of the victims and in effort to support all of those who were effected- their loved ones, the people of Orlando, FL, and the entire LGBT community.Chihuly's installations have been all over the world and are universally liked by everyone due to their vibrant colors, craftsmanship and aesthetic. Dale's passion seeps through his work.Art has the power to bring comfort and in doing so we aim to aid the healing process of the victims friends and family and the LGBT community globally. Rather than live in fear, we should support one another and honor love.Orlando is the first stop. It is in the United States, where Dale Chihuly and his team are based. Our hope is that if this becomes successful, we can continue this mission to install his artwork in places where there has been recent shootings or bombings by Daesh. Example- in Istanbul at the airport or Dhaka at the Holey Artisan Bakery cafe. This would fuel people to return to these places to look at Chihuly's work and in doing so, would bring life back to these places. The horrible events of Daesh have touched us deeply as the victims could have been anyone of us. Let us never forget.Art is one of the greatest means of consolidation and healing.ŒæDale's work has so much light and vibrancy, we believe this can help greatly with the healing process.ŒæŒæŒæFor more on Chihuly's work, visit his website:http://www.chihuly.com/

The pursuit of creative adventure, explored through the range of light.  A journey harmonizing the human spirt with the natural world. With the trail as my guide, I share the path of creative venture through visual communication.  I use the medium of photography as a way to communicate this passionate story.  My focus is on expansive landscapes that marry the natural world with the human spirit.  Compositions express the narrative of truth, found in the beauty of the natural world around us.  I use the tangible complexity of light and shadows that dance off the mountains and lakes to have this visual conversation. Sharing this sanctuary filled with raw emotion with others is the mission.I have been selected to showcase my Range of Light collection of photographs that were taken while thru hiking the John Muir trail on the United States National Parks 100 year anniversary.  The premier showcase will be at the House of Blues in San Diego, CA on October 5 2016, featured by RAW Artist.  I will be selecting 6 photos of the Range of Light collection to get printed on Fuji Crystal Archival Pearl paper and face mounted behind acrylic at a professional photo lab.  Your contributions to this installation will insure that a timely deadline is met and that large gallery quality prints are ready to display in galleries across the country.In return, you with receive beautiful incentive items that are artistically designed and personally signed.Imagine Create Inspire!Œæ

A Playa staple for 9 years, the Balloon Chain has illuminated the skies of Black Rock City with its kinetic helium sculpture made of colorful balloons.  At night, the balloons are lit up with L.E.D. lights.The installation was founded by Robert Bose. I am the co-artist and the one representing the installation this year. We are returning to the playa armed with hundreds of balloons, lights and helium. We are paying for everything out of pocket and driving 3,000 miles cross-country with supplies, so we need your help to bring back the balloons to the playa. -ChaChawww.balloonchain.com

"Serpentine Link" est une ñuvre issue däó»une alliance, däó»un postulat commun sur le monde extí©rieur actuel et däó»une rí©flexion partagí©e sur notre universalití©. Plus on se rapproche du cube plus on rentre dans le centre de la spirale et plus läó»inox recouvre le passant jusquäó»íæ rentrer íæ läó»intí©rieur du cube. A nos pieds donc läó»origine, on dí©couvre le magma et läó»embryon. Autour de nous läó»absurdití©, läó»aveuglement et le mutisme ou le bruit, les tí©níÂbres et les baillons, mais en nous, läó»espoir. Sur les faces intí©rieures du ví©hicule imaginaire, läó»humain multiple í©coute son double, respecte et säó»emplit de cette voix däó»altí©rití© et de multiculturalisme.Il regarde läó»avenir et partage la míÈme voie, il peut säó»adresser íæ tous et säó»exprimer hors censures.Alors, vient la dí©couverte ultime d'une í©lí©vation intí©rieure íæ 3m60 de hauteur , l'instant geníÂse telle quäó»elle nous appartient íæ tous, spirituellement, infiniment, universellement íæ travers des Assemblages  visibles depuis la passerelle chrome, un fluide de curiosití©  et d'í©tincelles de technologie nous transporte en imaginaire accessible íæ la boí¬te de Pandore.Sur la passerelle, les voyageurs säó»entendent, säó»aperí_oivent et se croisent, se retrouvent et säó»approchent. Eleví©e íæ seulement 60 cm du sol elle nous donne íæ observer par sí©quence de larges champs de pixels.Notre intention est de provoquer, par ce trajet offert íæ läó»intí©rieur de läó»ñuvre, un dí©calage de nos points de vue vis íæ vis du monde, un voyage initiatique, une expí©rience íæ renouveler pour rendre les libertí©s "Entendre Voir et Parler", pour q'elles tendent vers les valeurs et les vertus universelles.

As seen on:ŒæŒæŒæŒæWho are we?We are designers, artists technology wizards and makers of an international team. We bring diverse backgrounds to collaboratively design and build a stage andinteractive art piece to enable the local arts communities in Vancouver.ŒæŒæŒæWhat are we making?We're making a hanginginstallation that will have projection mapping upon it at IDS Vancouver, anannual interior design symposium.Œæ Everyyear the goal is to create a fully recyclable installation to reduce waste oncethe symposium is complete.Œæ In past years the design team for the center stage has choose materials which can individually be recycled and disposedof. This year, we are proud to partner with a local arts collaborative to entirelyrelocate and reuse the piece for years to come.The installation is anabstract representation of downtown Vancouver, made of recycled polystyrene andwood. A variety of graphic content will be produced and projected onto the manyfaces of the piece.Œæ The piece will besuspended above the seating area of the main IDS stage to create a uniquevisitor experience.Œæ But that's the beginning of this project. After the show in September, the installationwill be carefully taken down, and shipped to The Beaumont Studios where thisproject will live and thrive in the artist collective there.ŒæŒæŒæHow did this project come to be?Originally, IDSVancouver asked Stantec to design a main stage. It could be anything decorativeor the stage itself but they asked Stantec to ensure the design was recyclable.The designers decided to make something they would recycle in full to a secondentity. Who would that entity be? The hunt began for a location who could benefit from such a project. A stage perhaps? There wasn't going to be a design until the secondhome was found. A connection between Aubrey and Mimi lead to the conversationof designing a stage for The Beaumont Studios. Jude (founder of the BeaumontStudios) wanted to create a new venue space between the two buildings of theirblock suitable to have outdoor events. Stantec then knew they needed shade, a stage andsomething incredible to attract new guests from the street. Local Projection was born and we've been working diligently as a collaborative project team to bring this to fruition!What's the plan andschedule?We're going to buildthis as a team at MakerLabs in the beginning of September, then relocate andinstall at the Vancouver Convention Center September 17th, enjoy the IDS VancouverShow, disassemble and relocate to The Beaumont Studios to be built a secondtime for the local artists of Vancouver. The first party in the new venue willbe in October and announced at a later date. ŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæWhat's our budget?We're building the mainpiece for about six thousand dollars. We have hard costs in rigging at theconvention center around eight thousand dollars and for renting projectionmapping equipment around four thousand dollars (we're unsure at this point intime).We've raised about ninethousand dollars so far - we know we can make it to the convention. Getting it to TheBeaumont Studios, we have lot more costs coming. We think about twenty thousandmore at this point. What's our budget?We're building the main piece for about six thousand dollars. We have hard costs in rigging at the convention center around eight thousand dollars and for renting projection mapping equipment around four thousand dollars (we're unsure at this point in time).We've raised about nine thousand dollars so far - we know we can make it to the convention. Getting it to The Beaumont Studios, we have lot more costs coming. We think about twenty thousand more at this point. Why do we care?We want to make a spacefor artists in Vancouver to continue the discussion about the city and howartists can continue to positively impact it. Rewards :ŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæKickstarter Video Credits:Filming/Editing : Stig DanielsŒæhttp://www.javatime.us/ŒæMusic : Ingred Hakanson Œæhttps://soundcloud.com/ingridhakansonGraphics / Animations :Kim GlauberAubrey Tucker

By moving from our old to the new Emergency Room I have received six stainless steel folding screens that were no longer used. At a later time, I thought I could replace the fabric by leaded-glass. While working on this project, I have chosen to fill a strip in the middle with glass which is soldered together according to the Tiffany process. I have reproduced a bamboo motif in the glass, because these plants are growing in the courtyard where the project is to be placed.  I have used furthermore all kinds of colors and profiles glass giving it a cheerful appearance. The "Tiffany" strip has a narrative character. It is a 'lifeline' with certain symbols such as 'love', violence, old age etc..   The entire workpiece is illuminated from the inside by a plurality of LED strips that are connected with multiple switching clocks. Day and night the artwork shows a wonderful, colorful spectacle.ŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæŒæ Bij de verhuizing van onze oude Spoedeisende hulp naar de nieuwe heb ik zes RVS kamerschermen gekregen die niet meer gebruikt werden. Op een later moment heb ik bedacht dat ik het textiel zou kunnen vervangen door glas-in-lood. Al werkende aan dit project heb ik er voor gekozen een strook in het midden te vullen met glas wat volgens het Tiffany procí©dí© aan elkaar gesoldeerd is. Omdat er in de binnentuin (waar het glas-in-lood scherm echt prachtig tot haar recht zou komen) ook bamboeplanten staan heb ik dit motief terug laten keren in de glas. Verder heb ik allerlei kleuren en profielen glas gebruikt wat het geheel een vrolijke uitstraling geeft. De "Tiffany" strook heeft meer een verhalend karakter met symbolen uit het leven zoals liefde, je huis en ouderdom. Het hele werkstuk wordt van binnenuit aangelicht door meerdere LED-strips die aan diverse schakelklokken gekoppeld zijn. Dag en nacht wordt het kunstwerk zo een prachtig, kleurrijk schouwspel.ŒæAlleen heb ik hiervoor meer dan ä‰å 2000,- materialen moeten kopen en er eveneens meer dan twee maanden vrijwel continue aan gewerkt. Tel er de BTW en de omzetbelasting bij op en je hebt een idee wat de uiteindelijke kosten zijn. Vandaar dat ik hoop dat Kickstarter mij een beetje opweg helpt om dit project voor mij ook een bevredigende uitkomst te geven.Œæ

A good artist has the need and the duty, to show his vision of the world and challenge people. I do not know if I'm right or not, but I want to try to show that the human being is not necessarily bad.ŒæWhat is the role of parents, family, neighbors and wider school, social security, nation, democracy? What do we do with our DNA, the DNA of our ancestors? These are the questions I ask myself.My installation project I is not designed for just intellectual elites. I want to show it to the whole world with free access to the children, who go to school and often do not understand why. To the workers of a factory, to offenders and convicts, to the middle-class who run into the void.ŒæThat's why I ask your help to achieve hardware support, but the most important is to find locations and support, to show and give the message to as many locations as possible, with the goal of free entry, regardless of age, race or religion. The project in theory is done, I already have some places to show my work. It's up to you now to make it live and travel.Œæe-mail : dimitrixato@gmail.comThanks a lot for your time, your support means a lot.( I put 2000$ of my proper money into the project)The pictures are just a sketch, the plan is to make an installation with many of them. The oyster with a brain is big part of the project, as I want to make it very big, in transparent resine, light material, which can be left outside in front of the exhibition.

Little ŒæStone MenThey have done their duty quietly for more than 10.000 years ; possibly even longer. A few are still being recruited to act as sentinels of direction. They have many names but they have more or less the Œæsame look: a small pyramid made generally with rough stones. Their English name is "Cairn" a Œæceltic word. "Cuirid mi clach air do chairn" is a Scottish Œæsaying Œæmeaning: "I will put a stone on your Œæcairn".Usually Cairns stand alone or Œæin a cluster of no more than three or four where footpaths cross. There are Œæhowever places crowded with several hundreds Cairns like in Moeltin ( Sud Tirol ) in Corsica or in Perí_ where they are called Apachetas. ŒæThey are generally rather small and are made with just a couple dozen stones. Perhaps Œæthese small heaps should not be grouped as proper ŒæCairns but should be considered Œæas ceremonial markings for a burial,or for an ex voto site. Maybe these smaller Cairns could be Cenotaphs: empy graves for those who never Œæreturned to their land having perished in battle or in exploration of Œædistant lands.Cairns usually are positioned Œæto mark a footpath or a mountain pass in areas above the tree line. ŒæCairns are useless in woods and forest where they can easily be engulfed by vegetation.. They are to be seen all over the world colonized by man. In Inuit territory which usually is rather flat Cairns are also used as Œæfood cache.I wish to organize an exhibition centered on Cairns and their offspring: the dry stone wall. The eventshould take place in Gressoney Saint Jean in Northern Italy right in front of Monte Rosa at 1600 metres altitude smack in the middle of Italian Alps near the Swiss border.The exhibition will be based on Œæoutstanding photos of Cairns. ŒæAn attraction will certainly be Œæthe stones scattered on the Œæpavement of the show room, which visitors will be allowed Œæto pick and try to Œæmake a mini Cairn. ŒæIn a short walk from the show room Œæit will be possible to examine Cairns built by myself with the contribution of Œæpassers byes and aficionados.It will be possible to attend a two days seminar on the subject in beautiful log cabins with fantastic food and panorama. It will be possible to book an overnight stay.Attendants will learn about the system used to interlock stones which are positioned without recurring to cement or mortar. Structures built with this technique generally are more durable because in an earthquake they are more elastic and watrer will not have a chance to freeze because it will run away immediately.We are planning to produce for the event a poster a book size catalogue and Œæa build your own Cairn explanation sheet .The main strenght of this project lies in the fact that I have personally built in the Gressoney area a celtic vortex, three Cairns and one chapel dedicated Œæto Saint Michael Arcangel. All built in the traditional dry stone technique. I am planning to have the exhibition in an open Œæspace in a charming chalet style building belonging to the municipality. ŒæThis exhibition will go on green light Œæafter I receive the ok from Kickstarter. By mid March i will know if I will be funded or not. If I don't get funded I will try to get some sponsorship and lower costs. As a painter I have had five personal exhibitions in Milano and I am quite in good terms with several art galleries. So I think that I will push on even in case of a Kickstarter "default". I think that beginning of May would be the best date..Risks and challenges.Every venture implies a risk. ŒæThe 100% safe adventure does not exist. Last fall I decided to take a walk to have a closer look of some little stone men. Then Œæknew very little about Cairns. When I passed Œænear one of them in one of my mountain excursions ŒæI realized that many had a sad Œædepressed look. If however I walked up to the sad Cairn to examine interesting stones inadvertedly patting it on the back (?) I felt a rocky smile surfacing like steam from a funnell. To cut a long story short Cairns need to be embraced just like trees..Maybe this theory goes a bit too far and runs the risk of Œænot being taken seriously. I don't think that it will stand a scientific test. However when I handle stones ŒæI feel lots of positive energy surging inside myself. In 20 years of lifting sizeable rocks I never developed back aches.ŒæThere is also the risk of being alone in mounting this exhibition. I was however able to recruit my cousin Francesca Notarbartolo di Villarosa who was responsible for the video and Antonella Macchioni responsible for editing the video. In case of unforeseen hitches they are qualified to lend a hand. There is a saying stating "If something can go wrong, it will go wrong" Œæ Bad weather, low attendance, a fir falling on the Œæroof, Œæare all possibilities however remote which could jeopardize the event.. The challege is Œæto Œæwork hard to minimiize glitches. publish all the documents which will be produced for the event. I have been chief editor of severall magazines so I am on familiar ground. ŒæWith your help I hope to be able to get across the message that Cairns are a strong link to our past when man probably was still Œæa hunter gatherer.

(EN version)FR : dí©filer vers le bas Jean-Pol d. Franqueuil's  äóVantage Points äó is a dialogue between two sculptures in the shape of faces located in two grand European cities, Strasbourg and Berlin. With their similar design, signifying the human truths common everywhere in the European Union, they are differentiated by materials and specific colors to each city : pink sandstone from the Vosges for Strasbourg and granite for Berlin. Through their eyes fabricated in glass, modern technology links the two faces, thus allowing visitors to communicate through a variety of means, such as a live audio-visual system or messages sent directly from their cellphones (two of many anticipated possibilities). The expression of their own reality at each site is transmitted to the other end of the connection.  This sculpture project invites observers to see the world from another's vantage point, revealing their differences as well as what substantiates their commonality. As viewers are transported, an immediate dialogue is established between inhabitants of these important cities of the European Community. Each sculpture is composed of two main pieces integrated into one face, symbolizing the spirit of community and unity of these great cities, leaving behind the divisions that troubled their histories and looking toward a future of openness throughout Europe.  Nestled in the structure of each sculpture, a series of projectors emit images that simultaneously overlay the inner side of the glass eyes. Connected to the Internet, this system proposed by Realisations.net in Montreal as the provider of the technological aspect of the piece provides audio-video-communication and messaging similar to that used by today's smartphones. Sensors capture movements in 3D following people's positions and motion in front of the sculptures. Cameras and microphones capture the surrounding scenery as well as audio, including speaking of passers-by. Each sculpture then broadcasts the visual and audio ambiance coming from the other city across the miles between them.  A 52 minutes documentary film is in preparation for an important French television channel. Bonobo Productions will follow in parallel every step of the sculptures creation till the äóì opening äó of their eyes towards each other. During several months, the production company will record the way each city is working its side of äóì Vantage Point äó before achieving the visual connection between the two art pieces. When the connection occurs through the 3D Internet system, Bonobo Productions will capture live each cityäó»s unveiling of its own sculpture as well as the visitorsäó» reaction to the discovery of the other sculptureäó»s surrounding. äó€ Œ‚ Le Regard de läó»Autre Œé est un dialogue entre deux sculptures connectí©es en forme de visages qui seront situí©es dans deux grandes villes europí©ennes : Strasbourg et Berlin. Elles adoptent un design semblable, pour signifier la ressemblance des ví©rití©s humaines oí_ que läó»on soit dans l'Union Europí©enne. Elles sont toutefois rí©alisí©es dans des matí©riaux et des couleurs spí©cifiques íæ chaque ville : le gríÂs rose des Vosges pour les mains de la sculpture strasbourgeoise, le granit pour celle de sa partenaire berlinoise. íó travers leurs yeux en verre, un dispositif technologique de pointe permettra une connexion et l'í©tablissement d'une relation entre les deux cití©s, aux visiteurs des deux lieux. Ils í©changeront des aperí_us de leur quotidien de maniíÂres varií©es et ludiques, soit par un systíÂme vidí©o en direct, soit par des messages composí©s depuis leurs tí©lí©phones portables pour ne citer que deux exemples.  Ce projet a pour objectif de prí©senter un regard sur les particularití©s qui entourent l'une et l'autre sculpture, en prí©cisant ce qui fait la singularití© de chacune, tout en valorisant ce qui les rapproche. En se projetant vers ce qui reprí©sente l'intí©ríÈt de l'autre, ou ses prí©occupations, une conversation immí©diate peut ainsi s'í©tablir entre les visiteurs de deux oeuvres. Chaque structure í©tant composí©e de deux piíÂces principales rí©unies en un seul visage, elle exprime le dí©passement des divisions qui ont troublí© läó»histoire de ces deux places europí©ennes importantes.  Nichí© dans la structure de chaque sculpture, une sí©rie de projecteurs í©mettent des images qui se superposent. Connectí© íæ Internet, ce systíÂme proposí© par Realisations.net íæ Montrí©al- en tant que fournisseur de l'aspect technologique de läó»ñuvre - offre audio-vidí©o-communication et la messagerie similaire íæ celui utilisí© par les smartphones d'aujourd'hui. Des capteurs relíÂvent les mouvements en 3D suivants les positions des personnes en mouvement devant les sculptures. Camí©ras et microphones captent le paysage et le son environnants afin que sculpture diffuse ensuite l'ambiance provenant de l'autre ville situí©e íæ des centaines de kilomíÂtres. Un film documentaire de 52 minutes est envisagí© pour une chaí¬ne de tí©lí©vision. La socií©tí© Bonobo Productions suivra, en parallíÂle, toutes les í©tapes de crí©ation des deux monuments, et ce, jusquäó»íæ läó» Œ‚ ouverture Œé de leurs yeux läó»un vers läó»autre. Ce travail de plusieurs mois tí©moignera des moyens mis en ñuvre de chaque cíÇtí© de la connexion visuelle entre les deux sculptures pour optimiser les compí©tences et les moyens, et parvenir íæ leur läó»achíÂvement. Une fois connectí©es läó»une íæ läó»autre par Internet, cäó»est íæ la fois läó»í©volution du regard que chaque lieu portera sur sa sculpture qui sera mis en exergue et la rí©action des visiteurs de part et däó»autre quand ils dí©couvriront, en direct, läó»environnement de läó»autre structure. En plus du film, un web documentaire sera í©galement montí©. Grí¢ce aux outils multimí©dias offerts sur le site de la chaí¬ne, les internautes pourront prolonger läó»expí©rience grí¢ce íæ des mini-reportages, des photos et des liens sur les activití©s et les projets naissant de läó»interactivití© des usagers du Œ‚ Regard de läó»Autre Œé.
