The photo above is from Camp Suburbia last year on playa. This is a special camp to those both on and off the playa, and we are planning on returning for the 2015 burn. We have dreams of expanding across the board, and have some extra costs that go with that expansion. Every member of our camp contributes a great deal of their time and money, but our camp still needs some additional assistance. We hope that the community will step up and help us make our dream a reality!ŒæBelow I have posted the majority of our camp application for anyone to read, and I hope it paints a decent image of our goals. We were able to recycle almost everything we used from last year, and will obtain items as cost efficient as possible for this year. The money we raise here will go directly into the cost of building the homes (roughly $400 a house depending on current wood cost), and getting us started on building our participant playground. Please ask away with any questions you have!Physically describe Camp Suburbia?Our camp will resemble a typical cul-de-sac you might find in any suburban town. This is where our non-camp participants will spend their time enjoying our camp and our gifts.We hope to get placed on esplanade, and are planning on building a 'playgound & park' on the inner playa across the street from our entrance. This playground will include features such as; a swing set, a slide, monkey bars, a fort (or something else to climb on), a slackline (hopefully), and an arial setup. We also plan to lay some fake grass around with what looks like a sidewalk running through it (as in a pathway you'd find in any park in the suburbs) and benches placed around the sidewalk. We've also begun looking into setting up a few disc golf baskets. Lights will be placed in order to illuminate all of the equipment to allow for use at any time.Once you enter our actual 'camp space' you will find 8 houses with attached garages (houses will measure 8x8x10 and garages will measure 8x4x6). As you walk further into our camp space, you'll find yourself walking down the center of a cul-de-sac and quickly surrounded by houses. The homes have working front doors, windows, outside lights, mailboxes, also fake grass lawns, white picket fences, and sidewalks. The homes & garages will be painted in typical suburban fashion, as well as welcome mats, house numbers, fake flowers, doorbells, and anything else we get our hands on! The garages are open on the front (to appear like the garage door is open), and will have typical garage items (such as; camping equipment, tools, a ladder, old paint supplies, skis, random boxes that say 'christmas decorations' and stuff on them, bicycles, lawn chairs, and once again anything else we get our hands on). The street will have lamps and spot lights (to light the neighborhood up at night). All of the lights we currently have for the homes & street lamps run off of solar power (we don't have or want cables to bury). At the back end of the cul-de-sac we will have our country club. This building will measure approx. 26x30x10, with working french doors in the middle and working windows on both sides. Just like the houses, the country club will be painted and made to replicate an actual country club as best we can. We plan to line the inside with rugs and have a few chairs/couches to hang out on. In front of the country club we will have a few bike parking spots with lines and signs that say 'visitor parking only'.What is Camp Suburbia bringing in terms of interactivity to the playa this year?24 hours a day participants will be able to enjoy our cul-de-sac of homes. It will have 8 homes with attached garages (the homes are 8x8x10 and the garages are 8x4x6), each with green grass lawns, white picket fences, sidewalks, and street lamps. In several of the lawns we will have different types of games available for participants (games such as croquette, badminton, frisbee, kite flying, bocce ball, cornhole, and anything else we get our hands on!). Several of the homes will have a streetlamp in front along with spotlights so the lawn will remain lit at night, allowing participants to enjoy the games at any time.Across the street (on the inner playa) we plan to construct a fully functional playground along with fake grass, park benches, and street lamps. This playground will include features such as; a swing set, a slide, monkey bars, basketball hoops, a fort (or something else to climb on), a slackline (hopefully), and an arial setup. We've also begun looking into setting up a few disc golf baskets. Lights will be placed in order to illuminate all of the equipment to allow for use at any time.We will also have a Country Club (approx. 26x30x10) with which we will host our events and parties. We plan to stock the club with ample 'white collar' dress wear to pass out to participants and annoyingly enforce a strict dress code policy. Having this club house will allow us to open the doors at any time (which we plan to do frequently) invite in participants, and have a good time. This could range from a wine tasting to a round of imagi-golf (this is where you dress like a golfer, carry around clubs, and pretend to hit golf balls... however we use no balls, we just walk around bragging about how good our shots are and mostly drinking).What events does Camp Suburbia plan to host this year on playa?During the week we will host four main events each lasting multiple hours at a minimum. All ages are welcome and encouraged to attend. The first event will begin Sunday night when we host a 'welcome home wine down' where we will open up the country club for the first time, have the bar fully stocked with wine (both red & white), and showcase some local dj's. The neighborhood will be lit up to enjoy the games, and this will give us the first chance to welcome everyone back home with class. Don't forget this is a Country Club, formal wear required (and provided for some).Our second event will be held on Tuesday morning when we host our second annual yard sale. We will litter the lawns with all sorts of treasures & crap for people to pick through. Last year, and again this year we hope to have items such as; tents, water bottles, flashlights, bike locks, functioning bikes, costumes, platewear, wet wipes, batteries, tampons, dry goods, knick-knacks, toys, art, shoes, and more. We don't want to bring any of these items home with us, so expect the very best in yard sale finds in Suburbia! Everyone will be allowed to take whatever they wish, and our camp will be in our suburban costumes meeting & greeting. We plan to open up the wine bar for this event too!The third event we will host is going to be a block party on Wednesday afternoon. We'll block off the end of our cul-de-sac, get all the lawn games ready for action, and roll out the grills. We plan to cook up a bunch of burgers & brats and serve fresh lemonade (vodka optional & encouraged). What better way to spend the middle of your day than relaxing on the lawn eating a fresh brat and enjoying a cold lemonade. We'll have some music bumping in the country club, and hopefully get everyone back into their afternoon formal wear again!The fourth and final of our scheduled events will take place on Thursday late afternoon. Here we will gather up and head off for a round of imagi-golf to the Man and back. Golfing attire, clubs, and drinks are provided. After a lovely stroll around the city, we'll meet back up at the country club for celebratory drinks and stories of our adventures!On our non-event scheduled days (Monday, Friday & Saturday) we will open up the wine bar and challenge passing by participants to friendly competitions of bocce ball, disc golf, and croquette. No matter day or night, there will always be something fun for everyone to entertain themselves with at Camp Suburbia!Here's our camp photo from last year!Thanks for taking the time to read through this. You can find our camp facebook page at www.facebook.com/CampSuburbia to check out more photos!

I'm fascinated by the world and everything that it has to offer. From beautiful fields to barren deserts, tropical forests to arctic tundra, huge cities to small villages in areas of the world most never go. You always see camera crews following around one person as they travel to some secluded locations but what about the places nobody dares to tread and the harsh and treacherous roads and landscapes they have to cross over to get there that you don't see? I want to record the world, all of it. From the the most breathtaking of sights to some of the smaller not as captivating areas and the roads in between. Talk to local people and see what they have to say about their own little slice of life. Take in everything that this planet has to offer and record everything in first person so everyone can get a feel for what it's like to be there staring at vast canyons, traversing the rough terrain of the forests and even talking to the people in these areas. My goal is to make you feel like you've been there. Not to have just seen the area but to have traveled there, trekked over the terrain surrounding the area, talked to the locals, scaled rock faces, swam across bodies of water and everything in between to get to secluded locations the world wants to see. It's a beautiful world out there, don't be afraid of what it's hiding because it might be something magnificent and you'll never know unless you're willing to jump.

For eight years, The House of Art has moved from space to space, filling each one with fantastical art, including dramatic and photo realistic pencil drawings, and paper mache creatures in the form of dragons, beasts, and even a full-size African elephant.ŒæPaintings and sculptures breathe life into empty spaces; so much so, that the many mannequins seem to move on their own. Nowhere else in the world can you see its equal. It has attracted attention from all over the nation, and has been featured in documentaries in at least two other countries. Once it nearly spawned a television program when it became one of the top attractions in the State of West Virginia. Just when it seemed that things could only get better, in 2013 the House of Art had to suddenly shut its doors and journey forward once again to find a home for its Appalachian artists and their creations. A year passed, and it seemed like nothing was going to happen.Then a generous donation was made. A private investor has given us the opportunity to fix this building up and three years to return the investment. The property at 900 Mercer St. is nearly 100 years old and was, for many years, the old Virginia Bank of Commerce. Other than a drably painted vault door, there was little to be seen in this now deadened place, but quickly The House of Art began restoring the building back to its former glory. In no time Œæcarpets were pulled up, revealing the original tile floors. Walls were torn down, along with drop ceilings and useless mechanical equipment, revealing a three bay coffered ceiling that was nearly two feet thick and filled with dental molding. After only a month, the original historic qualities of the building began to shine through.ŒæProgressŒæThis place will be the first structure that the gallery can solely call its own, and with your help we can bring it up to the standards of wonder and spectacle that the House of Art is known for. We just need help taking care of the basics, like electrical, heating, cooling, and additional bathrooms, as well as meeting building codes and regulations that will come up during the restoration process.We will also replace the existing windows and storefront with Œæhistorically accurate units, at their original heights, so that the gallery can become even more present in the community. At this point, there are four phases we would like to complete, to help establish the new Gary Bowling's House of Art. ŒæŒæäó¢	Meeting bathroom requirementsäó¢	Accessibility and egress issues äó¢	Mechanical upgrades  / Electrical / Heating and Coolingäó¢ Re-roof main structure and workshop additionäó¢	Getting the main show room open äó¢	Installing access to the workshop äó¢	Refurbishing the vault room äó¢	Installing all new windows on the first level äó¢	Refurbishing the original storefront äó¢	Finishing out the upper floor to create additional gallery / studio space äó¢	Installing new windows on the upper level / additional signage äó¢	Refinish workshop äó¢	Create a secondary exit from the workshop äó¢	Install an additional restroomäó¢	Install new historical window fixtures in existing openings äó¢	Repair and secure coiling door äó¢	This art center in southern West Virginia will brighten the existence of all that come near. äó¢ Exposing children to art and art classes, which some Appalachian communities are totally without in their daily curriculum.  äó¢	Bring art to Veterans as a way of expressing emotion when there are not words. äó¢ Add to a already growing art community in Southern West Virginia. Artistic Legacy By helping re-establishing this art center in Southern West Virginia, you will be facilitating art in the surrounding Appalachian communities, and giving a home for the Appalachian artist and their creations. You will be helping expose young up-and-coming artist to the potential of practicing art as a profession, and showing how a passion to create can become the driving force behind a career.  In doing so, you will help to change the face and mindset of the community for generations. Many thriving artists have had interaction with the House of Art or its artists. Without that experience, their art may have never had a place to grow and be nurtured into what it now is.We have a building. Now we just need your help to make it usable. We would like to raise $40,000.00 as a stepping-stone in our efforts to raise $300,000.00, So that that we can not only fix the building, but create a facility that will inspire generations of Appalachian artists.Gary Bowlingäó»s House of Art is a 501(C)-3 non-profit and all donations are tax-deductible.We're offering a host of rewards and gifts for your pledges. Whether digital, 2D, sculptural, or fantastical, here's your chance to own a small part of Gary Bowlingäó»s House of Art. Gary Bowling Gary Bowling is the president and co-founder of the gallery. His art is his autobiography. It reflects moments of his daily life, fingerprints of his emotions, thoughts, and attitudes at the time of execution. Using a wide range of mediums (watercolors, oils, acrylics, etc.), he transforms wood, paper, and canvas into transitional reflections.His art is inherently versatile, and depicts progressive-microcosms with universal appeal. With varying degrees of subtlety, Bowling incorporates pundits, philosophy, satire, and humor. Beauty embraces wit and wisdom. With adaptations of materials, techniques and forms, Bowling integrates traditional basics with unique treatments. The unexpected embraces tradition.Bowling has participated in art shows from New York to Miami. His paintings, however, have spanned the globe with their popularity. Private collectors are responsible for his global recognition. His national recognition comes from state and federal governments, as well as private collectors. Examples of his works can be seen in state and federal exhibits, including, but not limited to, the Smithsonian.Jody QueenQueen is a self-taught artist who is ever-focused on the minute detail that makes every subject unique and ultimately brings it to life. his work is startlingly realistic and invites us to examine more closely the meticulous regard for the textures that give everyday objects their singularity. Queen works primarily in layered graphite, enjoying the range of expression the medium allows. he also works in wood, acrylics, and mixed media. Following the dream of sharing his love of art, Queen is the co-founder and vice-president of Gary Bowling's House of Art, ŒæHis work has also been juried into Tamarack, the Best of West Virginia.Jamie PowersPowers is an acrylic painter and a mixed media artist.  The paintings are usually horror-themed, of which some are fiction, while others are based on reality. He was born in the dark hollows of southwest Virginia, the son of a coal miner, and grew up in McDowell County, West Virginia.He graduated Big Creek High School in 1996, then went on to study at the Columbus College of Art and Design, majoring in Illustration. He graduated in the spring of 2001.He has worked as a freelance illustrator, but now focuses more on the fine arts.  He has shown work at The House of Art in Bluefield, WV from 2010-2014, in a group exhibition called äóìThinking Like a Mountainäó at the Southwest Virginia Community College in 2010, and later at Bluefield College in 2012. He Œæalso displayed work at Kulture Klash 7 in Charleston, South Carolina in 2011, and at The East End Artmares exhibitions in Charleston, WV from 2010-2012.  He was just juried into The Allied Artists of West Virginia show at the Huntington museum.Jamie is still creeping around the coalfields of southern WV, being inspired by all the real monsters in the region.Isaac Preston Preston has been with the House of Art crew for roughly six years, and many of his works have been created and displayed at the gallery. He presented an art show with 'The Artful Lawyer' gallery in Blacksburg, VA in 2013, and hisŒæwork is also featured in the Appalachian Arts Center in Wardell, VA and the Riff Raff Arts Collective in Princeton, WV. Preston uses recyclables as his primary medium, and he is also known for his works in wire sculpture. He is also active with the Hinton, WV theater group Ars Creo, and Œæacted with the Planet Extreme Teen Center in Princeton, WV in their production of 'Charlie and the Chocolate Factory,' in which he played Willie Wonka. When time allows, he poses as a live model for artists, and performs hand percussion and spoken word at open stage events. He has also conducted workshops for his wire work. Originally centered in Bluefield, WV, PrestonŒæhopes that reestablishing in the Princeton area will give him, and other artists, a great opportunity to share their passion with others. He seeks to inspire Œænew generations to follow their passion and spread happiness whenever possible.Rita MontrosseIs a native to West Virginia and has taught art for 34 years at Princeton Senior High School in Mercer County. Presently, she is an adjunct instructor of Watercolor and Metals Smithing at Concord University.Her paintings reflect a personal relationship with her environment, either at home in the mountains of West Virginia or in her travels. Her many sketches and photographs provide material for her watercolors/mixed media paintings, and have even influenced her jewelry designs. Whichever media she uses, she works in a series starting with a representational theme and pushing it as far as she can in developing the concepts. She doesn't set a limit to the number in a series, instead working it until it seems complete. Often, a series will be revisited because she canäó»t release it, or has had an insight into a new compositional arrangement. She feels fortunate that she lives in the beautiful state of West Virginia and has been able to work at what she loves, both as an art teacher and an artist/artisan. Christopher Lee Clark Clark works in a wide array of mediums, including ink, paint, plaster, and sculpture. He is one of the key artists behind the library mural in Princeton, and has created set pieces for the Hinton, WV theater group Ars Creo, in which he also performs as an actor. Clark is a member of the Appalachian Artists Collective, for which he designed and built the Paper Theater in the Clay Center in Charleston, WV, and his work has been used and published by the internet artist community founded by actor Joseph Gordon-Levitt, HitRecord. Clark's work captures scenes of intricate fantasy, often encompassing sinister, unusual, or otherworldly tones. The creatures he has created at the House of Art and elsewhere are the fully realized visions of a mind that sees no impossibility in the realms of creation, and works to bring elements of spectacle, wonder, and imagination to life. Many of his pieces are visual staples of Princeton life, appearing in shop windows, parades, and productions. Clark has been part of the House of Art for six years.Gary Bowling, Austin Persinger, Jody Queen, Steve Jessee, Christopher Clark, Ash Gill, Patch Whiskey, Carl Ferguson, Isaac Preston, Maggie Meehan, Rita Montrosse, Jeff Travers, Jamie Powers, Robbie Moore, Debbie Bowling, Michael Abraham, Brian Aliff, Kyle Davis, Richard Shrewsbury, Œæ Brandon Daniels, Tiffany Freed, Jamie Belcher, Jerry Frech, Anthony Harvey, Dana Frech, Erica Hobbs, John Trail, Chris DeHart, Christine Keller, Jill Pritchett, Raymond Neeley, Gaynell Dawson, Don Thomposon, Janis Dean, Courtney Waller, Janice Belcher, C R Ward, Amy McPherson,Trey Snyder, Charkera Erwin, Sam Underwood, Elizabeth Hern, Jeff Smiley, Bonita Sink, Rebecca Neal, Wanda Sperling,Kathy Kennedy, Elizabeth Perdue, ŒæBeth Blankenship, Martha Sabol, LaQuay Swade,

I am a Palestinian-Black Muslim American, living as a transplant in the city of Chicago. This identity has always empowered me. I have always felt as if activism and resistance has run through my veins, and I have always created works of arts on the basis of social justice and my personal identity. I was told, albeit jokingly and with a laugh, by one of my professors this year, that the two most hated people in the world got together and created me. Given the current events of this year, he might not have been too far off the mark with his presumption. This year, it was hard to be Black, it was hard to be Palestinian, it was hard to be a Muslim, it was hard to be a woman, and it was even harder to accept being an American.ŒæI have always been proud of who I am; heritage, faith, culture, nationality, but it seemed everywhere I looked there was an overwhelming persecution of every aspect of my life that I identified with. This resulted in my inability to focus, even at times feeling so mentally blocked I believed I would never be able to create art again. From national current events like the murders of Eric Garner, Michael Brown, Tamir Rice, Tanesha Anderson, Yvette Smith, and more, the indictments, the resulting äóìriotsäó and protests, the serge and flux of gun violence in the city of Chicago, to the United States role in international affairs such as Israeläó»s siege on Gaza, drone strikes in Pakistan, the crises in Syria and the Congo, the recent release of the CIA torture report, my brain was close to malfunction. I had nightmares about the link between the prison and the military industrial complex, what it all really means, and the implications of my role in the problems of the world as a tax paying American.ŒæI quickly found that my emotions towards the state of the world around me were not mimicked within the walls of SAIC as an institution. It was hard for me to find a space where I felt safe and understood when I tried to bring up these issues, issues very relevant to the political and personal narrative driven works I create. It didnäó»t seem as if any of the things that so deeply affected me, were on the radar of the majority of the professors and students that I encountered, I felt there wasnäó»t a space in which I could speak on these tragedies, that I witnessed daily on the news and through social media. Suddenly it became increasingly apparent to me that the reason that these world issues mattered and affected me more than the people around me was due to my identity. I can see myself in the tragedies that are happening, almost as if it could be myself, or any of the people I love, lying victim to these violences, but many cannot. It is a privilege to look at these human and civil rights violations, which happen daily, and think, äóìThis could never, and will never happen to me.äóŒæSo, this is why I plan on using one of the installation rooms at the 2015 BFA show to create an infinity mirror, which I plan to project an edited video montage of world events that have been haunting me into. The idea being that when the viewer stands inside the room, not only will they see themselves reflected into the space infinitely, but also they will be infinitely surrounded and unable to turn away from these pressing world and human rights issues.The proposal is due next Monday January 26th. The show is a temporary installation which would be up for public viewing for 26 days. This years show is scheduled to be installed between the dates of February 28th-March 4. The show would be up in the gallery for public viewing between March 13th-April 1. With Deinstall happening between the days of April 2-4th.Œæ

Please join us in bringing the world somethingŒæ unique.We anticipate upon hopeful funding (fingers crossed) to be able to ship to backers there respective rewards by end of May 2015 !

Kinetic Universe, the folks who bring you the Kinetic Grand Championship, the Rutabaga Ball, and the Kinetic Classic Kid Powered Art Race, would like to present: Kinetic Museum Eureka! It's a treasure trove of nearly 5 decades of Kinetic history right in Old Town! Open for Eureka's monthly art crawl: Arts Alive!What we already have: Space! Volunteers, antique kinetic sculptures, historic race film footage, pictures, stories, and memorabilia.Œæ Now we just need the structure:Since we were forced to close the Kinetic Museum Ferndale, Kinetic Universe has been working to find a new home for our collection of historic kinetic sculptures and memorabilia. We found this very reasonably priced space in Old Town Eureka and jumped at the chance.Œæ Now we're reaching out to you, Kinetic Fan to help us get set up.Œæ Once the gears are turning we will be able to support the Museum in the long term with monthly Arts Alive! events, merchandise sales, and sponsorships from local businesses. Glory!

Thisexhibition, which is curated by Erin Joyce Projects, will present the work of leading Contemporary American Indian andFirst Nations artists from across the North American continent. These artistsall actively engage the notion of pop-culture, misappropriation, andrepresentation in their work. Utilizing pastiche, they create imbricatedworks that will stand alone but enter into dialogue with one another in thegallery space. This exhibition will be in three states äóñ as a portion of theexhibition will be presented at Radiator Gallery in New York, and the Institute of American Indian Arts: Museum ofContemporary Native Arts in Santa Fe, New Mexico, and the Museum of Northern Arizona, in Flagstaff, Ariona.The exhibition features work from Postcommodity, Edgar Heap of Birds, Nicholas Galanin, Dana Claxton, Marcus Amerman, and Cheyenne Randall. The exhibition serendipitously coincides with the United Nations Permanent Forum on Indigenous Peoples, which will bring indigenous leaders and thinkers from all over the world to New York to discuss pressing issues affecting their tribes.ŒæThe reason fundraising needs to occur for the exhibition is to cover the costs of shipping and insurance of artworks to and from New York City from the artist(s) studio, cover the cost of travel and lodging for the artist and curator, as well as to cover the curatorial fees and catalogue printing fees.Œæ

The No More Hiroshimas ProjectThis project started in a graphic design class I was taking last fall and rapidly grew into the dream of an installation and teaching event related to the 70th anniversary of the bombings of Hiroshima and Nagasaki.As Burlington College has a professional gallery and an Institute for Civic Engagement, I approached the gallery director with the idea of the installation, and she green lighted it! The installation and event will be in August 2015.Commemorations of the first atomic bombings are held annually across the United States and around the world, and provide a means to remind ourselves, our communities and elected officials that we continue to face the danger of nuclear annihilation, and that action for nuclear disarmament is an urgent necessity. Commemorations open spaces to educate the publicäóîespecially younger generationsäóîabout the human consequences of nuclear war. They provide forums and encouragement to plan education and organizing in the year to come. In the United States, they also provide an opportunity to face and learn from one of the most devastating acts of war in U.S. history.We must act to ensure atomic bombings never again occur.The CostsThe costs associated with this exhibit are related to both the cost of printing and mounting large scale imagery with information about the bombings, the fallout, and the long term effects of nuclear war and the nuclear era. Many of the pieces require use of historical photos, and have costs related with the use of those pieces.I have priced out their use from Corbis images and Getty Images, as well as the price for printing and mounting. The rights to use these historic images will total approximately $3500.Aside from the images and historical information on the wall, there will be a river of origami cranes hung from the ceiling, moving through the 2 rooms of the gallery. I've already folded about 1300 of them as of 2/09/2015, and envision at least twice as many! The papers I'm using vary from those readily available at places like Creative Habitat and Michael's to hand-printed, hand-made papers at $28.00 for a single sheet.The Exhibit SpaceThe exhibit will be multimedia, with historic video and various film footage airing on a loop. The open space in the center of the main room of The Gallery will be filled with meditation cushions and a live Japanese maple. There will be a table filled with directions on how to fold origami peace cranes like the ones hanging above people, origami paper for viewers to create their own crane, and black tags with ribbons on them. People will be challenged to fold a crane for peace and place if at the foot of the tree. The tags will be for commitments about what each person will commit to for peace - whether that is personal meditation, taking action, supporting the Institute for Civic Engagement, joining VPIRG, or other personal commitment.The August 6th EventOn the day of August 6th, the public will be invited to events and presentations throughout the day at Burlington College about the history of Hiroshima and Nagasaki, the fight for peace in the modern world, and nuclear issues. The day will culminate in an public evening memorial ceremony by Lake Champlain.I am asking for this funding as an artist and creator of this event, not as an official representative of Burlington College.

In Greek mythology the Hyperboreans were a mythical people who lived "beyond the North Wind". Hyperbí_rea was a land that was supposed to be perfect, with the sun shining twenty-four hours a day, which to modern ears suggests a possible location within the Arctic Circle.What is Hyperbí_rea Program?I live in the region of Italy which in the past was called Magna Graecia and I found this myth very interesting for the name of my artistic project: Hyperbí_rea.My Hyperbí_rea is an incredible artistic journey of over 10,000 kilometers which will start from the village of Parabita, South Italy; it will cross the entire Europe untill the North Cape (Norway), the northernmost point of the continent; then from there it continue for another 1500 kilometers and ends in RÛ‚ga, the Baltic capital of Latvia. I will address the entire performance in solitary aboard my Vespa PX125E of 1982 and will cross 10 countries:  Why a journey by aŒæ Vespa?In addition to the remarkable performance on asphalt, the program finds its basis in the actions that I intend to achieve along the way: the art installations that will take shape in extraordinary places that I will explore. The job requires great incentives and persistent commitment and will be constantly documented through notes, drawings, photos and video. A Vespa makes the trip without a doubt full of romanticism, but, more important for me, it would guarantee independence and freedom for my movements in urban and in natural contexts.Travels by Vespa before Hyperbí_reaTo make long journeys in solitary aboarding two-wheeld vehicles is not a novelty. Finding daredevils who venture by Vespa is always more sporadic.The propensity began in the Fifties by some adventures to test themselves on board of this scooter. Giorgio Bettinelli with his 254,000 kilometers around the world is remembered as a hero of 90's and 00's.The difference with "normal Vespa travels" The innovation of Hyperbí_rea then other journeys by Vespa in history is summarized in the following points:Besides the arrivalHyperbí_rea will not end in RÛ‚ga. Please help me to make this great program a reality for the next April.Updates that share the creative journey as the project comes to life: Hyperbí_rea's Blog on davideleopizzi.comSome reward that I will make for youŒæSomething about the previous works

Guatemala Despuí©s is an emerging artistic and curatorial collaboration betweenŒæThe New SchoolŒæandŒæCiudad de la Imaginacií_n.The project will culminate into artistic works showcasedŒæin a digital collection, joint exhibitions and public programming hosted at theŒæSheila Johnson Design Center (SJDC)Œæin New York City from April 9-29, 2015Œæand inŒæQuetzaltenango, Guatemala in June 2015.ŒæWebsite:Œæhttp://www.GuatemalaDespues.orgJoin the Facebook group for updates:Œæhttp://www.facebook.com/guatemaladespuesCollaborative Process:ŒæThe project involves a process of co-investigation and workshops with artists, curators, filmmakers, social scientists, students and community-based creative practitioners in Guatemala and New York City. The key themes and directions are developed through ongoing interviews and workshops with participants, multi-disciplinary collaborations in selected sites of interest.Creative Outcomes:ŒæGuatemala Despuí©sŒæsupports site-specific artistic investigations that may reveal, activate, provoke or transform the ways in which we understand historic memory, repression, healing and forms of utopia or dystopia emerging in Guatemala. It also critically examines the political, economic and cultural influences (including foreign policy, migration and creative exchange) between the United States and Guatemala.The projectŒæuses an experimental, inclusive and participatory approach towards engaging creative practitioners and the general public using multi-disciplinary forms of investigation and expression including performance, film, sound visual, narrative and poetry. The curatorial team selected aŒædozen multi-disciplinary artistic projectsŒæbeing developed collaboratively by overŒæ40 emerging and established Guatemalan and US-based artists.The grouping of selected proposals is notable for its wide range in themes and practices. Collaborative work was encouraged to promote interdisciplinary partnerships and diversify the impact of the projects.The submissions include Hipnosis, by Regina Jose Galindo and Alejandro Ceibal, which explores the potential of public messaging -- a practice reminiscent of conventional marketing strategies, and inspired by hypnotic therapy, but for public good. The project manifests utopic wishes through site-specific interventions across Guatemala City.For The Metamorphosis of Devaluation - artists Fernando and Angel Poyon, collaborate with theatre producer Angelica Ventura and historian Maria Jacinta Xon Riquac äóñ for a tongue-in-cheek project that tracks the devaluation of the artist fee that the group will receive for the project.ŒæThe group is one of many proposals by indigenous artists. All four members are Maya Käó»icheäó», from the Quiche and Chimaltenango provinces of Guatemala.The joint exhibitions and public programming in April-June 2015 will expose these compelling works to audiences in New York City and Guatemala, while making the works accessible worldwide through theŒæDigital Collection PlatformŒæand Curatorial Catalogue.Support Us:ŒæWe need your contributions to support stipends for the Guatemalan artists whose work will be showcased, production and promotion of the two exhibitions, public programming, design of the digital platform and curatorial research being conducted by students at the New School.ŒæLearn more: http://www.GuatemalaDespues.orgRewards: Contributors have a chance to receive special rewards including a calender and notebook designed byŒæCiudad de la Imaginacií_nŒæand visually stunning books including "Imagining Guatemala" andŒæ"Bananí_polis", signed by its author. Aquaponics systems are designed to circulate water from a fish tank through the vegetable garden and back to the fish tank.Œæ As the water passes through the garden, the roots of the plants extract the nutrients they need and at the same time clean the water that is returning to the fish. ŒæŒæŒæŒæThis method of growingŒæuses 80% less water thanŒæa traditional garden!ŒæŒæThis makes aquaponics ideal for growing anywhere:Œæ Desert or droughtŒæclimates, offices, homes, schools, hospitals, rooftops, or just your own backyard!Œæ The plants have a faster growth rate and can be grown closer together because they are not competing for nutrients in soil.Œæ There are a number of support mediums which can be used, both natural, such as granite, or man-made, such as expanded clay.Œæ Because the system is raised, it is isolated from the soil, andŒæthere are no weeds.Only we make art around this system and make it beautifulŒæcustomŒæfit to your imagination.We build with nature's pride!!TO SUM IT UP:There is no watering, there is no weeding, your plants grow faster and produce more vegetablesŒæin smaller areas.Œæ The plants are grown at "counter height" so there is no bending over to tend to them! You are also raising an edible protein source, the fish!Once your system is set up and running, a normal day consists of throwing a handful of food to your fish.Œæ Planting and harvesting can literally be done in minutes. Requiring only about 15 minutes a day of your time on the average, you will find yourself spending time in your garden because you want to, not because you have to!WHAT YOU CAN EXPECT:I started with two 100 plant systems (these systems we nowŒæcall "Old Faithful"); each 100 plantŒæsystem takes up a 5äó» X 20äó» space or 100 sq. ft.Œæ This includes a 16 square foot divided äóìnurseryäó and six 10 foot flow pipes, each containing 14 plant stations for a total of 84 individual plant stations and 16 + in the äóìnurseryäó.ŒæŒæ We now have created the 200 plant system ("The Food Factory) which takes up a 5' x 30' space or 150 sq. ft.ŒæŒæThis system has 168 plant stations plus room for 32+ plants in the "nursery".Œæ (Each nursery has the capacity for hundreds of small plants.)The fish tanks have a capacity of 200 gallons. ŒæThe pump will be sized based on water volume and grow area demand.Œæ I am currently using a 1250 gallon per hour pump.ŒæI am currently raising Tilapia, so I have included a heater on my home systems,Œæ just for the coldest months.Œæ If you enclose your system, this heaterŒæmay notŒæbe needed.PLANTS WE'VE GROWN IN OUR SYSTEM:Œæ 5 types of cherry tomatoes, + 200 lbs of beefsteak tomatoes (Fall of 2012)ŒæŒæGreen bell peppers, red bell peppers,Œæ 2 types of cucumbersŒæ 4 types of squash,ŒæŒæ8 - 10 Œætypes of lettuce; basil, broccoliŒæ Green beans, yellow beans, peas, eggplant, spinachŒæ Strawberries, basil,wheat grass.Œæ Flowers and rare edible flowers!!!!!The systems I design can be customized to fit your needs and your yard while at the same time complimenting the natural surroundings.Œæ

Our vision is to create and deliver an audio-visual experience.  Crave is not only our project title it is the sensation we want our audience to leave with.With that in mind we have collaborated with several artist to come up with a style direction that has the potential to leave an everlasting impression.  Using live DJäó»s, live visuals, projection installations, and luminescent ambiance, the treatment feels unrestricted with the lack of boundaries between what is real, and what is surreal äóñ it is limitless, infinite, and therefore boundless.Project Crave is an alliance between artists meant to remind people that we must live every moment.  The world is changing so rapidly if we donäó»t stop to live every once and awhile things will pass us by.  This project is a fusion of talent, heart, and hope brought together to inspire people to strive to find the fun in all aspects of their existence.Whenever they think back, their Craveings will remind them of the one spring night they entered another world full of neon paintings, beams of light, and the crowd they danced the night away with.

Currently, what we call "The Tea House" will be the focal point of the farm where educational workshops and cultural events will take place. ŒæWe prefer to use natural building materials such as Bay Leaf for the thatch roofs and local hard wood. ŒæThe Tea House has a roof completed but is in need of financial assistance to finish the flooring. ŒæOnce built, the Tea House will host speakers and artists (eg. local healers speaking about holistic healing, local maya potters teaching traditional pottery, etc), environmental awareness and conservation discussions through talks and documentary showings. ŒæWe also would like to develop the Tea House as a resting place for locals and travelers where they can enjoy eating and drinking organically grown super fruits (cacao, noni, sour sop etc), fresh juices, and herbal tonics made from local medicinal herbs growing wild on the farm. ŒæA cabin industry bottling these tonic drinks and natural cosmetics will provide work for local women and men living in the area of San Antonio village.Once we receive our financial goal through Kickstarter, the funding will be put to:Œæ*Building materials for the Tea House and renewing existing accommodations*Purchasing solar batteries and solar panels to power the Tea House and upgrading the existing solar powered electrical system*Sound equipment (speakers, mic etc.)We currently host travelers and volunteers that have come to explore the maya ruins and organic farm life. ŒæOur location and environment is near perfection (see the view on the main image?) and we have 3 beautiful cabanas (bay leaf thatch and wood) that house my family, guests and volunteers. ŒæWe want to make this a special place for the people, the community and the world as a whole. ŒæWe welcome travelers, students, teachers, researchers, artists, craft-makers, adventure seekers, archaeologists, gardeners, farmers, families and friends to come and visit or stay for a while to explore the maya world and immerse in cultural exchanges amongst the people that become a part of Pacbitun Farm.Œæ

In 2014, a grassroots cry for non-violence, among soldiers, police and civilians, would resonate worldwide.ŒæFrom Russiaäó»s emerging imperialism, to a third US military confrontation on Iraqi soil, to the citizens of Hong Kong pleading for democracy, to the militarized police in Ferguson, the time is particularly ripe for an anti-militarist message.Guo JianŒæ+ŒæMarcus EriksenŒæwill create a multi-dimensional piece which includes a war memorial statue and documentary film footage about the memorialäó»s creation. 35-40 actors of various cultural backgrounds will be recruited to shoot a movie, documenting the creation of a war memorial. The actors will wear military uniforms representing several military cultures, anachronistic and often on historically opposing sides. Akin to traditional war memorials such asŒæIwo Jima, this group of military men and women would be planting a flag together äóñ but here it is aŒæwhite flag of surrender.ŒæA participatory photo series calledŒæ#SURRENDER SelfiesŒæwill also be part of the exhibition. The artists are encouraging supporters worldwide, from opposing factions, to submit photos with their hands up. Whether or not you can donate, please post a #SURRENDER Selfie.ŒæLearn More.Help support this project and receive unique and meaningful rewards ranging from meeting the artists to owning a piece of their artwork! Check out some examples of the rewards below.Exhibition T-Shirt ($50 Level)ARTWORK: Chi-I-Joe (+$500)ARTWORK: #SURRENDER Exhibition Print Series (+$1000)ARTWORK: "MEAT" Photo Series (+$5000)Guo JianŒæis a Chinese artist who has exhibited worldwide, and has been featured in theŒæNY TimesŒæandŒæWall Street Journal. He is a third generation military veteran, having served in Chinaäó»s Peopleäó»s Liberation Army during the Sino-Vietnamese war.Guoäó»s work is heavily influenced by the Chinese Cultural Revolution of 1966äóñ76, the late 1970s, early 1980s war with Vietnam, and the Tiananmen Square massacre of 1989 äóñ in which he participated as a protestor. After the events of 1989, Guo Jian became a pioneer of the Chinese avant-garde art scene, and a founding member of the famousŒæYuanmingyuan Artist Village.Guo Jian was recently exiled from China, after he completed a morbid diorama of Tiananmen Square, which he covered in ground meat and left to rot. (Financial TimesŒæ1Œæ2Œæ3,ŒæCNN). After worldwide coverage of his arrest and detainment, Guo was deported and separated from his family, ending up in Sydney. The collaboration with Emerging Collective will be his first project since being exiled.Marcus EriksenŒæis a US Marine Corp veteran whose work centers on the realities of war, disillusionment with militarism, and environmental activism. He has won awards for his service in Kuwait City during the Gulf War, and afterwards became interested in showing the harsh realities of wartime, and how it changed him and his peers. He is an environmental activist with notable projects that have garnered media attention. Now based in LA, Marcus earned his PhD in Science Education and has the skills to work withŒæmetal, wood, paint, and even animal flesh. Through art-as-activism, he has brought attention to the plight of Hurricane Katrina victims, plastic in the worldäó»s oceans, the material refuse and rubble that results from armed conflict, the shame of surviving conflict, and the sadness of fallen soldiers.Œæ ŒæEmerging CollectiveŒæis a non-profit art initiative, creating dialogue between the First World and the Emerging Markets through the prism of art. The program involves immersive art exhibitions, mentorship of emerging artists by globally recognized artists, and a digital content platform cataloguing these new endeavors. With an emphasis on activist and avant-garde art, Emerging Collective aims to catapult the most promising creatives to the forefront of the global art scene, and serve as a cultural change-agent for the next generation.HOW IT WORKSThe program consists of a dual artist-in-residency program and a collaborative exhibition äóñ one globally recognized artist and one top emerging talent. One of these artists will come from the first world, and the other will come from the emerging markets. The mentorship relationship will be solidified in their collaboration.First, they will create a piece in the disused space chosen. The creative process will be live streamed, and the work will be on auction from the moment the work begins, ending when the work is complete. They will also collaborate on an immersive concept and build it together. ŒæThe exhibition will be centered around these two artworks.During the exhibition, Emerging Collective will curate intimate discussions with the artists, as well as other culturally relevant programming in the exhibition space.Œæ The mentorship relationship, and the immersive work that is produced from it, will be the result ofŒænorth-south dialogue. This will be a transcendent artwork that neither artist could have imagined alone, and will be Emerging Collectiveäó»s biggest contribution to humanity äóñ to literally push culture forward.Œæ

Created from up-cycled plastic debris, The Plastic Sea will take guests on a unique journey, educating them on how plastic pollution is affecting life in and out of the worlds oceans and encouraging people to take a stand to prevent further destruction.Incorporating  projectors and LED light sculptures, this interactive art installation creates a dream like underwater experience. Half of the profit from each piece sold from this installation will be donated to the Surfrider Foundation to keep protecting our ocean, waves and beaches."Art is a global language & Plastic is a global problem"Œæ-Aurora RobsonI want to keep the size and location of the installation open and base it on the amount of funds I receive at the end of this campaign!ŒæThe more support you can give the more spectacular it will be!Œæ| RootamentalŒæ| | Hayley Marie PhotoŒæ| | Linda Leavitt Music | | The Beach Hair Studio | Œæ| Acropolis | Œæ| ŒæLiam Photography | Œæ| Terry Lilley's Underwater 2 web | Œæ| Project Vortex | Œæ

Holmes County äóî the heart of Ohio's Amish Country äóî is rich in many ways, but lacks a stage for artistic and cultural exchange and especially, has no outlet for local artists and no place for residents and visitors to explore and experience artwork.ŒæWith the Holmes County Open Air Art Museum, we want to establish an entirely new museum to create an illuminating way to experience the work of local artists.The Holmes County Open Air Art Museum will beŒæa collection of artwork, sculptures, earthworks, and any other creations permanently installed outside and unprotected from the natural elements. It will be art that you can walk through, gaze up at, and witness in each changing season, art that constantly evolves against the backdrop of rural farmland and forested trails.With this Museum, we have the unique opportunity to create a new creative space, built by our community and influenced by the artists whose work will fill it. Help us make this vision a reality!My name is Jason Nies and I am the person behind the Holmes County Open Air Art Museum and the owner of The Inn at Honey Run, a boutique hotel in Millersburg, Ohio. The Inn has great potential as a new venue for creative output in this community, a dream I've harbored since helping create a community for artists called Junctionview Studios in Grandview, Ohio.ŒæNow, for the first time, comes the opportunity to build something permanently inspiring that can spread the impact of art to Central Ohio. With your help, the Holmes County Open Air Art Museum will ignite conversation, drive thought, provoke emotion, and leave a lasting impression on each visitor. There is a great need for more creativity and cultural exchange outside of the urban environment, and especially here in Holmes County.Around the world, rural locales are enriched and enhanced with public art äóî many countries in Europe and several in Asia and South America have an open air art museum. Even the United States has several variations of an open air art museum or sculpture garden.ŒæThis is not so in Holmes County, Ohio. There is a vast, empty canyon of culture and open air art in this part of Ohio that will be filled by the Holmes County Open Air Art Museum,Œæwith the help of all of our backers.Aside from becoming a vital part of the culture here, the Holmes County Open Air Art Museumäó»s location will set it apart from existing spaces. At the center of the largest Amish settlement in the world, the beautiful rolling hills and natural tranquility of our area allow visitors to shed the outside world and freely engage in the artistsäó» imagination and vision.The museumäó»s location äóî adjacent to The Inn at Honey Run and set on our 50-acre property äóî is an added advantage. The Inn is already a tranquil place for contemplation and retreat, surrounded by lush forest and hillside meadows.ŒæHere, the land and art are secure and will be protected and nourished for generations, for visitors and locals alike to appreciate.ŒæSo far, 25 local Ohio artists have shown interest in becoming the first to create and display their work at the Holmes County Open Air Art Museum. Immediately after reaching our initial funding goal, we will establish formal agreements with the artists to plan their installations and schedule their opening days. Each artist will participate in the opening of his or her piece and will interact with the supporters and co-creators of the museum. In the long term, we will not limit eligibility to Ohio artists, but we feel this is fitting for the initial 15 installations, a chance to grow the Museum with pride in local talent.ŒæThere are no requirements for materials or media to be used in the artwork. We will encourage and seek out a variety of styles and media to provide a range of materials from natural to recycled. The vision and creativity of each artist will dominate the works of art.ŒæWe are a typical small business äóî we make enough money to maintain the Inn, but we canäó»t take in enough revenue to fund a project of this scope and pay professional artists a fair commission for their work. This is the same reason most art museums are funded by wealthy patrons.ŒæOur goal is to fund the Holmes County Open Air Art Museum with thousands of small donations and create a museum that truly values the public and the artists. This model ensures that artists are free to create their masterpieces without the influence or expectations of a powerful board of directors äóî the artists will have full control over the Museum collection as it takes shape.ŒæWe've calculated a need for $50,000 to commission and install the first five works of art. Every dollar contributed beyond this amount will go toward more artwork. My dream is to raise $150,000 or more so we can open the Museum with 15 permanent pieces. Your support will make this a reality and help create an emotionally moving art experience for thousands of people.ŒæŒæWe are deeply and truly appreciative of all who will be a part of bringing unique, large-scale artwork to Ohioäó»s Amish Country. It is not often that we can be a part of the creation of an entirely new artistic space and museum, and we are extremely excited to build a community of passionate art lovers.ŒæThe rewards we are offering are designed to provide a truly unique and immersive experience for our art-loving backers, from an invitation to be a patron of art in Holmes County to a nightäó»s stay with us at The Inn at Honey Run and a private reception with the artist.ŒæWant to give a reward as a gift? Youäó»ll have a chance to let us know that youäó»re making a pledge on someone elseäó»s behalf once the project is over. Just let us know who should receive the reward on the follow-up survey. You'll be invited to walk the grounds of the museum after some of the first artworks are installed. Be among the first to experience the Holmes County Open Air Art Museum!We'll host an opening reception for each installation, inviting the artist and our backers to celebrate together. Like a gallery opening, our receptions will be held at the Inn, surrounded by nature and artwork, with hors d'oeuvres, refreshments and a presentation from the artist.ŒæA special rewards tier for our earliest backers. A pledge at this level is not only a strong vote of support, but also an opportunity to witness the creation of the Museum. Early Backers are invited to stay at The Inn at Honey Run during the installation of a piece of art, experiencing both the Inn's tranquility and its new identity as an artistic haven.ŒæGolden Guests are invited for the whole package äóî a big thank you for being a part of the museum every step of the way. Join one of our artists and fellow backers at one of the private opening receptions with a presentation by the artist, hors d'oeuvres andŒærefreshments, followed by an overnight stay at the Inn.ŒæAfter an opening reception with the artists, spend a night in one of our private and secluded earth-sheltered Club LevelŒæHoneycombŒærooms. Each room features a gas fireplace and private patio overlooking our sheep meadow (and the sunrise each morning), and this reward includes complimentary full breakfast.ŒæThe Inner Circle offers an incomparably intimate evening with one of the artists of the Museum. First, join fellow backers and art lovers at an opening reception with a presentation by the artist, hors d'oeuvres andŒærefreshments. Inner Circle members will alsoŒæbe invited to a gourmet, five-course dinner with the artist at the Inn's restaurant, Tarragon. A night's stay in the inn's luxuriousŒæaccommodations on the night of the reception is also included.We will begin installing the first work of art in April 2015 and we will open a new piece every three weeks after that for a total of 10 installations in 2015. This is dependent on your support and whether we can stretch our initial goal of five works of art to the dream of 15. If we do, beginning in April 2016 we will add the next five pieces in three-week intervals and conclude this initial period of growth with a grand unveiling and the first Art Festival at the Holmes County Open Air Art Museum.Your support is just the beginning of the museum. My vision calls for a continually growing collection, an annual art festival, and an artist residency program.We will add two to three new permanent art pieces to the collection each year going forward after the initial 15 works are installed. These will be funded by the The Inn at Honey Run, made possible by the increased visitors to the museum.During the summer of 2016, we will host the first Art Festival Week on the grounds allowing artists working in all media to display, perform, and ignite art for the public and create a living art experience.The third part of the plan calls for a permanent cottage with a work studio to be built along the museum trail, which will allow one artist to live here for a period of time to work on his or her next creative endeavor.In 2002, my family decided to take a trip to Latvia, where my motheräó»s side originated. My grandmotheräó»s health was deteriorating and we wanted to have the opportunity to share this trip back to her native land with her. During the trip, I had the opportunity to visit the Open Air Art Museum at Pedvale. My imagination awakened as I walked around the landscape, taking in the works of art. Iäó»d always appreciated art and enjoyed the museum experience, but this cool June day in Latvia uncovered a passion for interacting with art in an open air format. Iäó»ve been looking for an opportunity to start something like this in the United States ever since.ŒæOther inspirational open air art museums include Inhotim inŒæBrumadinho, Brazil; Middleheim Museum in Antwerp, Belgium; and Storm King Art Center in New Windsor, NY.Museums are created and maintained by the wealthy individuals of this world because money is needed and they control the finances. My dream is to expand the honor and duty of bringing art to the world to everyday people, people who love art and want to share this love with their fellow inhabitants of this earth.ŒæIn this way, the barrier of wealth is destroyed and the joy of curating art is now attainable by every person who so chooses. I encourage you to join in this dream and permanently etch your name in the history of HC-OAAM while giving the world a new way to create museums. Come, help us define this new museum experience.   I have been the owner of The Inn at Honey Run for five years, and I have spent the last five years improving and fixing up the property. I have been developing new businesses and creating new concepts throughout my career. Before owning the Inn, I owned an art studio building in Grandview, Ohio and an Antique Mall (Heritage Square Antique Mall) in Columbus, Ohio.ŒæOne of my first opportunities to bring art into my professional life came in 2003, with the creation of Junctionview Studios in Grandview, Ohio, just outside of downtown Columbus. A close friend of mine was attending the nearby Columbus College of Art and Design, and we saw the need for a creative space open to all media, one that would unite the urban community and celebrate the beauty of the neighborhood. I collaborated with the owners of a former plastics warehouse and we set about remodeling the facility to fit our needs. Within this relatively-small warehouse of about 25,000 square feet, we created 20 studios and three larger spaces: a dance studio, a childrenäó»s art center, and a 3,000-square-foot gallery.ŒæThe energy was alive at our first show in October of 2003 äóî we knew Junctionview was a success. It was a place where the art community and the general public could cross paths. After two years, I moved on to my next project, leaving a collaborative group of artists to lead Junctionview. The space thrived until 2013, when it succumbed to economic pressure for a new apartment community.Œæ

To make our dream of a happier morning commute possible we need your help to realize my performance-art project "Move(d) By Nature".By supporting Move(d) By Nature you support the dream of a greener, stressfree everyday life.

The beginning of my move into art happened during a time when life had defeated me. After under-bidding the largest print contract of my career, things went south. I nearly lost everything making delivery on my print contract.Financially wiped out and depressed, I had lost the will to continue my business with the same determination and drive. Rather than work, I began to sift through my college photography. I started printing random photos that I liked. My roommate at the time was encouraging me along the way. One of these images was a stained glass Jesus that I took at night time in Phoenix.I had the idea to print using colored material rather than white. I had a huge mix of results The stained glass Jesus image was an interesting image to work with. I began printing it on different colors of material. This was my way of not working. I was now playing with my printer rather than printing the usual boring marketing material.Since I usually work with adhesive materials, I started mounting the prints onto spray painted backgrounds. Between printing and spray painting, I had found a happy distraction from work and my professional career.ŒæOne evening a guest who was over saw some of the work. She asked how much I would sell one for. Ding! In a moment, I understood that I could become an artist. I was taken back and had no answer for a price.To make a long story short, all of the sudden I had almost 75 of these 8x10 Jesus plaques. I didn't know what to do with them, so I decided to start framing them. I made it a dogmatic practice to finish one or two each Sunday. Some of the frames are made by me and some of them are second-hand. There are only a few which I did not work on the frame.Once again - to make a long story short, all of the sudden I have an office full of Jesus's, and its time for them to find new homes. I am raising funds to re-locate from the snow and into warmer climates (AZ). In the spirit of dogmatic practice, I am running this kickstarter until my birthday, and am seeking to raise $333 dollars towards my move.ŒæŒæThese are the remaining un-framed plaques.ŒæHere is the collection of Jesus with frames!

The Tappäó»s Initiative is a juried Artist-in-Residency Program (AiRP), developed by Friends of the Tapp's Arts CenterŒæ(a 501(c)3 not-for-profit entity), that aims to bring contemporary art production, practice and community engagement to the Columbia/Midlands area. ŒæEach resident will have full access to their own studio space for four months. Throughout this time, the resident artist will realize a site-specific project, and invite the public to discuss and interact with the contemporary artwork during several open-gallery events. We believe the interactive aspect of our project is unique, and will benefit the community by furthering an understanding of contemporary art issues, modes of practice and how visual language functions in 'building' culture, both locally and abroad. Moreover, the emerging artist selected for the Artist-in-Residency Program will benefit from both professional and personal growth. For emerging artists, the completion of an art residency program is paramount for launching any artist career. At the end of the four month studio time, the resident artist will close with an exhibition of work produced during the time in the space. Tapp's Arts Center (TAC) will host an opening reception, as well as an artist discussion during the run of the show.Those who give to The Tappäó»s Initiative will help foster an important, but still missing, piece of Columbia's art landscape. You will be participating in the cultural and artistic growth of our city, and the money earned through this campaign will help cover facilities cost, marketing, educational and support materials, and most importantly, it will allow us to provide financial support to the artist in the program by way of a stipend. We believe artists should be able to participate in the local economy while at the same time producing cultural and artistic contributions.Studio Rental (4 months): 1200Materials (Exhibition/Studio): 1000Stipend: 1500Administration/Marketing: 300Total Cost: $4000Our space is a 23,000 square foot contemporary art gallery located in the downtown Columbia, South Carolina. It features an open floor plan, main circular desk, free wi-fi, communal microwave and coffee maker, several benches, and an outdoor workspace. In addition, our location includes 32 artist studios, a classroom, and two event spaces (the Skyline Room and Fountain Room).Because Friends of the Tappäó»s Arts Center is a 501(c)3 non-profit, a portion of your donation is tax deductible in the U.S. Please consider this in your end-of-year giving for 2014. Family & Self...Family seems to be my reasoning for doing anything with regards to Financial rewards! ŒæMore specifically, my Kids future is Paramount... and their College Fund is barely walking at this point. ŒæSo, consequently I have decided, after 7 years of being the Stay-at-Home Dad with a Flawed steel Back, to get back into the game of working thru my passion of Art. ŒæBut, at the same time, my-"Self" wants and desires to be successful at some form of Art, my passion... to make my mark. ŒæI'm 54 years old and moving thru the Half-time of my life. ŒæAnd frankly, at this stage of my life I have become wiser and believe there is no reason why I can't be successful fulfilling the specific needs of both the Family and my-Self.MyŒæSTARSCAPESŒ¬Œæbusiness project reflects a large portion of me, my lifestyle and current situation. ŒæArt is something I've done as a hobby for years, and many think my published "sculpted cork art" should be here instead. ŒæBut, I firmly believeŒæSTARSCAPESŒ¬ will prove to Extremely successful for me in the St Louis area.Profit Margins areŒæSuperior...ŒæŒæthe cost tocomplete one room is under $10 inŒæmaterials, and the retail price to theconsumer is from $150 for a small Stargazing Skylite and up to $500, $1,000 ormore for larger rooms and home theaters; you can see that the profit is verygood!Œæ The program cost along with initialoperating costs, is $5,000 for initial business and educational materials,equipment, tools & supplies, vehicle window lettering, local advertising,and incidentals.Scope of Business.... ŒæPeople today,young and old alike, are stressed to some degree. I'd like to help out withsomethingŒæthat isstress-relieving, relaxing, inspiring, and even a bit romantic.Œæ It makes life just a little bit moreenjoyable.Œæ Here's the product:STARSCAPESŒ¬ is custom-painted 3D murals of the starry night sky on the ceilings of rooms by using a special invisible paint, and I can complete it in just a few short hours (without moving any furniture).What youäó»llexperienceäó_ Imagine stargazing from the comfort of your hotel bed, gazing atancient constellations like Orion, Pegasus, Ursa Major (the Big Dipper),Gemini, Scorpio, Sagittarius and Crux (the Southern Cross) all in theirastronomically correct locations. The crescent moon and famous stars likePolaris (the North Star) can be found along with a beautifully visible section of our ownMilky Way galaxy.The benefits of enjoying this unique, celestial starry sky are great. It is relaxing, stress-relieving, educational,awe-inspiring, and romantic. Imagine a business-person lying on the hotel roombed, stargazing and relaxing, as all of the worries of the day fade away.Imagine children and even some adults, whom are afraidof the dark and now äóìasking to go to bedäó! ŒæIt happens with STARSCAPESŒ¬. ŒæEveryone loves tostargaze; we've just forgotten about them.

The Nicholas Lawson General Studies Building Project isintended to be constructed in such a way so that for the period of time that itis so that it takes itäó»s place as the tallest building on a University Campusin the University System. The purpose of this is the generate public interestand inspire competition among high school students forthe purpose of competing to enroll at aUniversity of Cincinnati program that would be known as the University ofCincinnati General Studies Program.This 11 Story building would ask for Freshmen to give theirfinal presentations starting at the top floor of the Nicholas Lawson GeneralStudies Building. The presentations these students would give wouldcomprehensively detail their experiences in studying abroad on their classäó»schoice of continent. Thesubsequentyears would entail the students spending nine months as a class experiencingthat which every continent has to offer.The basement of the Nicholas Lawson General Studies Buildingwould house a data center where students as they are traveling around the worldand experiencing life abroad while gaining perspective on the GlobalCommunications Network would be where the students store their diverse andvaried Multi Media Creations in the forms of Text Documents, Video Documents,Audio Documents, and Photography Documents.The students would in fact spend nine months out of eachyear for their first seven years of study experiencing in full detail eachcontinent. They would then spend the final three months of each of their firstseven years of study and travel in the Nicholas Lawson General Studies Buildingworking collaboratively on their final presentations. Each years the studentsare to give their presentations on their respective floor representative oftheir year in the program with their first year being the year that they givetheir class presentations in the first floor and their subsequent years givingtheir presentations on each level lower.The final four years of the program would ask students toexperience and recover from the culture shock that would be experienced and tocollectively work together to detail their inspiration that they wouldexperience. They would be expected to organically over the first seven years oftheir studies and travel to collect a professional contacts lists that theywould be expected to naturally keep in touch with.These students would spend their final year on the groundfloor of the Nicholas Lawson General Studies Building working to create a finalpresentation that explains and details their by this point global inspiredmindset and would be asked to explore and understand how best to navigateglobal issues up to and including drafting writing as to how best to go aboutnavigating the Global Warming issue that is presently being discussed andunderstood in society at large.This is a program that is intended to produce global mindedcitizens equipped with competitive stories in society at large that stem fromhaving an understanding in some form of what life is like on each of the sevencontinents.It is understood that in a globally networked societyinterlinked with a global communications network that training students and youthto think globablly through the process of experiencing globe that they wouldthen be able to in enhanced fashion function more professionally on a locallevel pulling on their diverse international contacts to aid them inaccomplishing their future goals and furthering their respective communities withthe aid of their cumulative experiences amassed in their 11 year universitystudies.The funding that this Kickstarter Program is asking for willbe used to offset the costs of creating the first draft of a set of plans forthe building and will be issued to a local Architecture Firm to begin the firstphase of a presentation to initiate this program.I hope you find this idea inspiring and that you feel thatthis undertaking would be beneficial to the Global Community in such a way thatyou open your pocket book and help promote the futuresäó» ability to better andmore thoroughly understand the needs of the leadership in the future and theunderstanding that it would be a program like this that would enable futureclasses of Students to promote understanding and communication in a GlobalSociety. Thank you for your time. I hope this provides you with astyle of inspiration that opens your eyes up to what is possible.

Interactive elements engage the public towardsaction and immerse the audience within the experience.The goal of AFFECT is to go a step beyond andshow that we are always involved even if we believe we are separate from the act ofcreation.AFFECT is an interactive installationthat beckons people to engage with the space and each other.Œæ Audience movement, actions, and gestures are combined with environmental information to create dazzling effects.Œæ We use the latest in IoT sensors and motion graphics to engage the audience and show their place within the creative process.Here, the audience is dared to trulycreate the artistic expression with their active participation.Œæ Both the form of the installation and thevisual content show how active participation in creation is more powerful thanattempting to be an impossible passive spectator. --------------------------The form of AFFECT is reminiscent of a gear, or perhaps a single-celled organism splitting into two.Œæ The sizes of the screens and the proportions follow the golden ratio, and the geometric design in the center is called a sri yanta, or sacred instrument.Œæ We invite the audience to play with this digital arcade game!ŒæAbove is a concept image of the installation, where the three screens produce visual content based on motion, rfid and other sensors.Œæ Stretch Goals:$12K: Bigger badder faster!Œæ We can get better hardware to run badder software for faster and higher definition effects!Œæ If we can get this stretch goal we'll include the wall plaque for all levels above the pendant level.$18K: More functionality!Œæ We can add additional layers of functionality, including SMS control of the RFID functions.Œæ If we can get this stretch goal we'll add layers of functionality to the rewards, such as LED effects or proximity sensors.Below is one of the rewards of a wall panel with similar technology allowing interaction with light effects.ŒæWe thank our supporters with gifts like the above wall panel and smaller desk versions that aren't quite as interactive but are quite stylish and add a nice light feature to any room.Each supporter over the smallest contribution will receive a pendant version of the AFFECT shape with either necklace or earring clasp:Œæ While the exact visualizations are still under development, below are some examples of the types of visualizations being utilized:

The interactive installation is based on a black, dark room, constructed in the interior of a art gallery. A "rain" of golden faoils susspendet on threads randomly disposed from the hight of a persson how is walking in the room, to the ceiling. The threds are going up and down by using an servomotor. the motor is commended by a net of infrared sensors dissposed at a working height from the ceiling, and connected to EV3 bricks from Lego Mindstorm. Using a software, the motors comanded by the sensors and bricks the "golden rain" is mowing up when a persson, or perssons are walking in tho the room. An ambient light is changing with the walk, an so the rain is making place to the perssons an is falling back when the persson is leaving the path and the room. A persson can chose any path in the room, he can turn back an so on...Œæ

Many haunted attractions are geared toward quick jump-scares and blood-and-gore type props, and tend to rush people through small violent scenes to achieve the scare effect. What if instead of relying on that quick fear response or the shock factor of bloody visuals, there was a haunt that really makes people feel as though they are in a whole new world first? If it feels that real, then surely the fear and terror will be that much more real too, once the creatures show up...This year I have a smaller goal - I want to put some of my skills into practice, so I can be more prepared for a better, bigger, and much scarier haunt next year.ŒæThis campaign is to help me fund materials to provide a neat little haunted walk that even my 3-year-old Niece would be able to go on without feeling scared. Picture an environment that isn't scary but still makes kids feel like they've been transported to a new Halloween-themed world. If this first year is successful, I plan to spend more time on the haunt next year, and as my Niece grows, hopefully so too will my haunt, until I am able to start running true terror-inducing haunts that people love!

The labyrinth is one of the oldest contemplative and transformational tools known to humankind. This walking meditation has been used for centuries for prayer, ritual, healing, and personal/spiritual growth.Œæ A labyrinth is not a maze with tricks and roadblocks.Œæ Labyrinths are unicursal, offering only one way in to the center and one way back out to the opening. With the destination assured, the labyrinth walker can honor the journey itself and what it has to teach. The mind can be quieted, turning attention to the wisdom of the heart and the graces of being, rather than doing.Œæ The fluid movement of the labyrinths winding turns connects the walker with the earth and nature.Œæ Labyrinths provide a sacred space to bring thoughts, challenges, ideas, or simply your spiritual essence to light. Labyrinths are typically found at church sites, college campuses, parks, and hospitals/specialty medical centers.There are also many privately owned labyrinths which can be accessed with permission from the owner.Œæ However, in the North Mississippi area, there is a need for access to this wonderful transformative tool, which is not locally available.Œæ It is my wish to build a classical labyrinth, 50 ft. in diameter.Œæ The space I have designated for this labyrinth is nestled beside the woods and surrounded by nature's beauty.Œæ There is a big red swing at the point of the space where labyrinth walkers may relax after their walk.Œæ The plans for this project also include benches for meditation or journaling before or after the labyrinth walk.Œæ Bringing the labyrinth to the local rural community will afford an opportunity for personal inner growth to those who may have never had access to the labyrinth.Œæ It will also be an added destination for travelers who visit the North Mississippi area.Thank you for your support of the Labyrinth @ Funky Junction Farm project.Œæ Your donations will create love and light for the North Mississippi area for years to come.Peace,Madison
