I'll post initial sketches soon.

What are we doing you cry?We're sending letters to everyone in the world, one town at a time.We're trying to prompt chats around neighborhoods. (Not boring! Exciting!)We're trying to spread a bit of butter! (Joy.)We're lighting the long weird wick of community curiosity and waiting for it to do whatever that particular mix of people does. (Who knows?!)What sort of thing should strangers say to strangers?Who absolutely hates letters?What will come for you in the mail tomorrow?Thanks to the brilliant people who pledged on here last time we wrote over 600 letters to every home in Polish Hill in Pittsburgh in America...Now we want to go further, quicker, bigger, thinner, taller, shorter, etc.(6,825,898,913 x better)Will you help?Yes?No?Join us! It's free! (not free)(This time we're looking to raise $8000 for travel to a very remote (secret at the moment, sorry) location. Until now we've had to limit our letter writing to 620, the most we can do in two weeks without dying, but with $8,000 we can write to hundreds and hundreds more people, longer letters, further travels, whole cities, etc.)

The Brooklyn Hi Art Machine began as two artist that have been living in the same Brooklyn building for the past 12 years, last summer we began having drawing and sewing nights. This summer we would like to extend our art making to our community by creating a free arts program that would take place on our block 3 days a week, 4 hours a day for a period of 3 weeks.During these art workshops there will be individual projects that participants can take home as well as a collaborative project that everyone can contribute to that will focus on issues that are important to our neighborhood, that will later be displayed publicly and celebrated at the end of the free art workshop series.As artist, we began these evenings of art making with the intention of building a closer relationship as neighbors. We believe that bringing this practice to the rest of our community will allow us to act as a bridge between our neighbors and the various cultural institutions that exist in our community but have fallen short when it comes to engaging local residents.Our goals are to create a greater connection between neighbors in our communityand make art friendly and accessible to all.We believe that by becoming active ,collective participants in art making, members of the community can find new ways to relate to each other and to the art institutions in the neighborhood.We will use the money raised on Kickstarter for art supplies, equipment such as tables, chairs, a sun canopy; healthy snacks and way way cool t-shirts featuring original artwork for our participants.

4000 Years for Choice (http://www.4000yearsforchoice.com) develops visual narratives about the practices of contraception and abortion from around the world over the past 4000 years. The project aims to celebrate, inspire, and empower women and men in their reproductive lives!This project responds directly to 40 Days for Life campaign (http://www.40daysforlife.com), an anti-choice movement targeting women's health clinics through 40-days of prayer and fasting in front of clinics across the counry. Therefore, I decided to create a project that focuses on these same clinics through a national postcard mailing campaign.So far, I have personally "kickstarted" the project with my own funding by sending seven postcards to approximately 180 clinics (those targeted by the 40 Days campaign.)The feedback has been phenomenal! Abortion providers, nurses, college professors, and pro-choice supporters have emailed saying thank you for this amazing project!Check out the comments and press...http://4000yearsforchoice.com/4000/category/comments/http://4000yearsforchoice.com/4000/category/press/Specifically, funding will be used to continue this project. I will print and mail one postcard per week to approximately 200 clinics for 52 weeks. All of the designs are finished, it's just a matter of printing and mailing!Here's the budget...200 printed postcards ($34.42 per week) x 52 weeks = $1789.84200 stamps ($56 per week) x 52 weeks = $2912.00Total project cost = $4701.84The history of contraception and abortion is transformative, healing, and brings a much needed historical context to the pro-choice landscape. These postcards are just one way to let clinics know they are following a tradition that dates back thousands of years.I hope you will support my project!

As a professional artist/oil painter and an amateur vegan cook I have been looking for a way to use my art to promote a healthy, sustainable and compassionate lifestyle. My solution is to create a series of postcard sized, illustrated vegan recipe cards.How the project will work:I will begin the series using recipes that I have gathered through the years. I will prepare the food, set up a still-life using the meal, execute a painting of the still-life and photograph the painting for the front of the recipe card. On the back will be simple instructions on how to prepare the dish. Once project is up and running I will use recipes provided by backers. I am asking all backers who are inclined to submit 1 recipe that they want to share with the world and I will include it in my series. All backers who submit a recipe will be credited with a byline on their card. I am aiming toward a minimum of 25 cards. The maximum is dependent upon funding.Once the project is complete the cards will be printed and distributed to backers based on the rewards system described. The idea is that everyone involved will share and distribute these cards to friends, family, strangers, businesses, etc. in an effort to spark dialogue about the importance of steering toward more humane and environmentally sustainable eating habits. I feel the best way to accomplish this is to demonstrate that vegan food can be absolutely delicious and satisfying as opposed to an act of culinary deprivation and I want these recipes to prove it.What to consider when donating a recipe:1) It tastes fantastic; something with which non-vegans would have a hard time finding fault.2) something that is not too complex; remember it has to fit on the back of a postcard and the print must be legible.3) keep these categories in mind: easing into vegan, international dishes, traditional breakfast turned vegan, soups, desserts. these are just a few to get you thinking.What the funding is for:Funding for this project goes toward the following:- art materials; the paint, canvas, etc.- printing costs, full color illustration on the front, recipe on the back- artist feeFor examples of my artwork and credentials check out: http://www.edmondpraybe.comand feel free to email me with any questions.

I am an artist with a disability, and im currently trying to raise enough funds to cover the costs of framing work for a showing of mouth drawings i will be doing this september. I was born with a condition called arthrogryposis , this disability prevents me from holding a pencil or pen with my hands and because of this i have developed the ability to draw with my mouth.I was recently offered a show in louisville ky, the show will take place in september of this year and will consist of 10 twenty by thirty inch drawings done on water colour and print making paper. each of these drawings take roughly 3 days to construct, and i currently have 7 of the 10 ready to frame. I plan to mount the drawings and then frame them in a simple light wood frame. each one of these works will cost roughly 150 dollars each to frame, and the gallery i will be showing the work at cannot afford to give me financial assistance.The reason im trying to raise the funds on kickstarter is that i am currently on a fixed income, and because of the short notice [ i only have 2 months ] i do not have enough time to slowly raise the funds myself.If you can't give alot....then give a little, because every bit helps.you can see past works of mine here - http://thanielionlee.com/sd09.html and here - http://www.flickr.com/photos/thaniellee/sets/72157622805167449/more information about my disability can be see here - http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthrogryposis

Since the first ever "Drawing Day" -- the one day in the year when everyone around the world tries taking some time off to draw something, to try to achieve 1 million drawings drawn that day, globally -- I've held these 24-hour nonstop drawing marathons, where I drew nonstop for the whole 24 hours, other than a few biobreaks (2008, 2009). I drew what came to mind in this weird stream of consciousness that gets at you when you haven't slept for 36+ hours (hyping and PR-ing the event, the day before, then the entire day drawing)... and, I also took requests -- I drew whatever *anyone* requested. It's the one day in a year that I truly feel like I'm myself, and yet...I wasn't able to participate this year largely due to my Wacom Intuos 2 failing just days before the vigil. Reality; I took that as a divine sign (yet another one) that drawing and art isn't for me.I can't say I'm a successful artist, per se -- at least, not in the standards capitalism would hold me to. Despite being a full time artist for the past one sixth of my life, I've managed to fail at every single grant opportunity I've tried at (rejection, rejection, rejection! :-()... Economically, I'm a starving artist -- but energetically and spiritually, I'm a devoted zealot of art.Earlier this week, after some tinkering, I fixed my tablet and... I want to draw, draw, draw, nonstop... It's like my old long-lost best friend has risen from the dead -- in the style that I can do numbers in, yet still express ideas, convey the human story in -- sketches via the Wacom pad, my art in black and white.So, here we go... please help support me in my way-too-idealistic-and-a-tad-bit-crazy project. I'd need the entire month off to be able to draw non-stop, to live an entire 30 days, to be able to just exist, and do what I do as an artist. The minimal cost of that is 3k - I live in California, so that'd barely cover rent, plus a small stipend for groceries. For me, being able to raise that just for my art would mean so much -- it'd even *feel* like a miracle! Not to mention, this is also your chance to get *cheap* but chic custom art!We have the entire month of August to raise the funds for my crazy dream -- Kickstarter is an all-or-nothing deal. If we reach our goal, I'm drawing non-stop from September 1 to September 30! Send in your requests digitally - and I'll email you your drawing - you can be anywhere in the world! You'd get your drawing's worth!Please let me draw!!!

The Last Supper is a two-week long affair, with a celebration, charity benefit, and arts exhibition that showcases local emerging art, film, music, new media, and culinary talents. Now in our sixth year, weäó»ve grown from a backyard party celebrating the end of Summer to an indoor-outdoor feast, concert, and exhibition at Brooklynäó»s Third Ward with 800+ attendees. We are a community-based event, supporting local artists and local food producers.Each year we choose a theme dealing with consumption for our artists, musicians, and chefs to pursue. This yearäó»s theme is self-made, referencing how communities and individuals define, create, and provide identity for themselvesäóîwhether it be through DIY movements, online personas and avatars, community collaborations, or individuals relocating and starting new lives.This year, we plan on expanding the scope of The Last Supper further, to include community events such as lectures and interactive workshops. Your donation will support these events, as well as our annual opening-night party, showcasing food, art, and music from emerging talents, which benefits the Food Bank of New York City.Your donation helps us cover necessary set up fees for the festival and opening night event, including food, event space, and production costs (equipment rentals, hanging art).

My name is Paul Gaj. I am a graphic designer, illustrator and artist who lives and works in Groton, Massachusetts. Many people throughout the country have been appalled by the economic and ecological devastation in the Gulf brought on by the tragic oil spill. We all want to help in some way, but as the leak is capped, the focus and interest from the rest of the country will also begin to dissipate, but for an incidental update on the evening news.I have spent a good portion of my career painting the seascapes and waterways of New England. I can only imagine how awful it would feel to walk along tar-bathed sands on Cape Cod and not be able to enjoy the seafood that provides both livelihood and nourishment or the pristine coves and marshes that have inspired decades of artists and visitors here.I would like to document the immediate transformation of the Gulf in the wake of the spill through my watercolors (what more appropriate medium), photographs, sketches and brief conversations with residents over a three week period and compile my observations into a book and exhibition titled äóìEye on the Gulf Coast. The View From a New England Artistäó.I intend to use my own vehicle with all the necessities and travel from Boston to Pensacola, Florida. From there I will make my way west to Venice, Louisiana and back to Pensacola. I plan to split the trip along the coast so that I can hit a few areas I may have missed on my return. Mind you, this is also hurricane season and I will be taking every precaution. I will be traveling alone and away from my family (Whose full support I have). I donäó»t consider this a paid vacation.I am not trying to profit from the tragedy of others. The purpose of this project is twofold. One is that as much as I and others in the Northeast and other parts of this country would like to, we cannot go down there and scrub the oil off the rocks and birds nor donate large sums of money to assist the effort. Two, is that as an artist, I not only want my work to say something about what I see, I want it to do something. Have an effect. Make an impression beyond a mere image and to generate additional publicity and support for the Gulf coast.I will not be making an evil corporation or political issue out of this. There are plenty of people and organizations out there doing that already. If anything, I am looking to become more informed about the situation from my first hand experience, and I hope I can inform others and perhaps let the folks along the Gulf know that their tragedy is our tragedy and even though we are in New York or Minnesota they are our citizen brothers and we truly care and want to help.For more information please visit http://www.eyeonthegulfcoast.comor http://www.pgajdesign.com

We are a burning man theme camp made up of Santa Cruz artists, surfers, and hippies. Our dream is to offer free tie dye to the Burning Man community, white t-shirts and all. In the desert habitat of Burning Man we believe that our super bright, DIY tie dye will bring giggles and colorful creative zing to many dusty burners. Tie dye is raw artistic self-expression and for most of us it brings to mind peace signs and free-spirited adventures in rusty VW buses, two things our planet could use more of. Support our tie dye revolution!

I want to help a friend of mine who will be going to an event and wants to give out stickers in the form of a white/blank cartoon speak-bubble while he blows bubbles. By passing out the bubble sticker at the event (and to the public in general), the idea is to encourage people to place the sticker somewhere in a public space (or anywhere, how are we to stop such a thing?). Doing this may provoke someone else (or the same person who placed the sticker) to write something interesting into the bubble-space.We think more people should be part of creative urban expression to level the playing field currently imbalanced by excessive corporate advertisements. We want more citizens to claim their stake in public spaces.In order to give away stickers to donors, more funds are needed due to the minimum order size and shipping costs. This means that the project costs will cover printing (vinyl stickers) and shipping costs (to ship stickers to donors).Thank you for your time.

At REPUBLIC it has always been our belief that whatever path suits you, whatever your religion, politics or philosophy it is in our common human interest to transcend our differences so that we might come together to create opportunities for self discovery, friendship and public service. Through collaboration we hope to develop a voice that speaks to quality, innovation, originality and taste. Trough team work, dedication and experience we produce exhibitions and events that meet the measure of your imagination. Through our diverse network and service menu we help people and businesses to realize the maximum potential of their vision while strengthening the character of our individual members in the process. We do this by providing out members with meaningful opportunities for fellowship, charity, creativity and leadership.We now need your help and your pledges to move forward.In the coming months republic will go through another transformative phase of it's evolution. Beginning at as team of three in the summer of 2006 under the name ArtSpace NYC the organization developed a catalog of twenty two events and a substantial following within a year and a half at their permanent gallery space in FT. Greene Brooklyn including multi-media exhibitions, film festivals, a young curators program and collaborations with many local and national charities and cultural institutions. In the winter of 2008 ArtSpace NYC dissolved and REPUBLIC Brooklyn was conceived to build on the principles and momentum of that early experience.Over the last year REPUBLIC Brooklyn has expanded to a board of 9 directors and an extended pool of human resources that reaches out vast and broad through out New York. With an increased dedication and insight from a larger team of multi-talented and multi-faceted individuals, the organization has gone on to produce events and exhibitions as eclectic as a large group exhibition of digital video projection, live performance and interactive digital new media in 6000 sq, Ft. Warehouse to a six month five tier fund raising project for the Cooke Center for Learning and Development. We also expanded and developed our charitable branch called the *Reaching Out* program in order to utilizes the capacity of our resources and serve various public and private charitable interests for periods ranging from several weeks to up to six months.Functioning loosely as a fraternal organization over the last year REPUBLIC Brooklyn is now expanding into REPUBLIC Worldwide Inc. Complete with a new more complex branding structure and new website conceived and developed to emphasize the services we provide through our consultation, production and marketing menus.As a worldwide operation we are currently in development with branches as far apart as Philadelphia, PA and Sydney, Australia. Your pledge of only ten dollars or more will also go towards the creative and charitable projects that our team is currently producing while we transverse the rocky terrain of incorporation and redevelopment. We cant do this without youand we can track and report to you exactly where your donation is going to be invested in the project. At Republic we are trying to do something different, something that changes the way people see the world around them. With your help there's no goal we cant accomplish.For more information about REPUBLIC, our events and the artists who participate in our exhibitions or to learn more about the Reaching Out program please visit us onlie.www.republicbrooklyn.blogspot.comwww.republicbrooklyn.com*video footage from Digital Rituals courtesy of Kevin Yourdonfor more information about the video of Digital Rituals (above) including the artists involved in the project please visit :http://www.republicworldwide.com/events_digital_rituals.htmlor contact :kREPUBLIC Worldwide Inc.jason@republicbrooklyn.com917. 478. 7513Republic Worldwide is:Jason Patrick Voegele - CEO / FounderSamantha Katz - Marketing Director / Branding ManagerDrew Kassl - Design Director / IT ManagerJason Isch -Director of Charitable / Social OutreachLauren Culbreth - Public Relations DirectorMarissa J. Forbes - Copy Editor / Blog ManagerSean McGurn - Media DirectorCharles Merritt - Chief Operations Officer

Through art education, art therapy, and creative experimentation, we the Artcult cultivate diverse human expression by the donating of time and supplies to the elderly, young and underprivileged in our communities. Our services make art-making accessible for people of all ages and abilities through the recycling of wood, paper and plastics into high-quality art materials. We aim to encourage the exploration of personal aesthetic potential in all and desegregate the art world.Lowe's Hardware Co. is our major sponsor and charitable donations of materials by many organizations throughout the United States work in conjunction with our efforts to prepare and distribute art supplies at no cost to our beneficiaries. The donated time of our volunteers raises the quality of life for many people by providing stress relief, mental and physical exercise, social interaction and support.Money donated from Kickstarter.com will go towards the printing of Artcult merchandise which will display the artwork of our beneficiaries for purchase by their families and our supporters. Woodworking and canvas stretching equipment, paintbrushes and paint supplies will also be purchased with the collected funds. If you would like to have us support your organization or seek information about donating supplies for our project, please feel free to contact us and we will promptly return your request.www.artcultonline.com / www.artcultonline.blogspot.com, Cheers and Thank You!

Hello, and welcome to project Casa Artelexia. Who and what is Casa Artelexia??? I am Elexia and my father/business partner is Andres. One year ago, we started a family business importing artistic Mexican products. My father makes several trips a year to Mexico where he works with a group of artists and craftsmen from all parts of Mexico to create high-quality unique gifts, decor and furniture. We work very closely with the artists and strive to create working relationships that are beneficial to both. We pay the artists and craftsmen fair wages and try to keep our retail prices reasonable, passing the savings directly to you, our customer. Since March 2009, we have sold our products at various outdoor markets and have received tons of positive feedback on the quality and uniqueness of our products.Until now, our main retail venue has been the La Jolla Farmers' Market, where we have had great success. Most recently, we have started to sell our products at the wholesale level and we are currently in stores in New York, Colorado, Georgia, Texas, Arizona, New Mexico, Ohio, Washington and Oklahoma. We also have an online store at www.artelexia.com.Our next phase of the business is to open a retail store in downtown San Diego in order to help us bring Mexico's art and culture to you. We also aim to use the store's location as a "cultural center" for events and a meeting place for Mexican/Latino artists looking to promote their work. We believe in a close-knit community and hope to become a local leader in the Mexican and artist communities. We are working closely with local Hispanic cultural organizations in an effort to increase the public's knowledge of Mexico's rich history, culture and arts.As you know, the start-up costs for a small business can get quite expensive. In this economy, small business loans are next to impossible to secure. While we are investing our time, money and hearts into the next phase of Artelexia, we need your help to make this dream a reality. We have joined this fund-raising website in order for us to be able to reach out to you to ask for your much needed support. For every level of donation, there will be a äóìgiftäó from Artelexia as a thank you. You will also be able to follow our progress on this website, which will allow you to see your donation at work.Here is just one example of a series of events to be held at Casa Artelexia: Every 3rd Thursday of the month, Casa Artelexia will host a Loteria Fundraiser Fiesta. Guests will be charged a small fee to play and will win prizes. All monies raised will go towards various charities and organizations which share a common goal and vision with Casa Artelexia.If we can raise $10, 000 through your generous pledges, the funds will go towards a portion of our start-up costs, which will include:äó¢ painting the interior and exterior of the buildingäó¢ installing proper lightingäó¢ repaving the front stepsäó¢ supplies, such as cash register, counter, furniture, phones, bags, wrapping supplies,äó¢ insuranceäó¢ decoräó¢ landscaping the backyard, which will be made available to local artist events and hosting cultural meetingsäó¢ signageWe hope that you appreciate where we are going with Artelexia, follow along with our progress, tell a friend and contribute toward our goal of raising $10,000. All donations, regardless of amount, are greatly appreciated. This project truly means so much to us and we firmly believe that with your help we can make a difference. We thank you for your support.

The ToonSeum is proud to present an exhibition featuring original art from the groundbreaking anime classic Akira.Katsuhiro Otomoäó»s anime masterpiece Akira is widely regarded as one of the most groundbreaking and influential films of all time. Based on the artistäó»s own landmark manga series of the same name, the film not only shattered box office records around the world but has retained a fiercely dedicated audience of animators and aficionados for more than twenty years äóñ and for good reason. Akira revolutionized animation and arguably saved the Japanese film industry, paving the way for a new generation of artists and spawning a worldwide acceptance of animation as high art.Akira was an epic collaboration and full of animation firsts. Adapted from thousands of pages of manga and pooling resources from several of Japanäó»s largest entertainment companies, the production cost over $10 million, which in 1988 made it the most expensive animated feature ever made. Akira was the first animated film in Japan to record its voice actoräó»s performances before principle animation began so that characteräó»s facial expressions and lip movements could be synchronized. An elaborate symphonic score was written and conducted by composer Shoji Yamashiro, a then unheard of indulgence that has become one of the most definable and enduring features of the film.No other film had ever looked like Akira, itäó»s stunningly fluid and detailed animation often requiring as many as nine separate cel layers. The 125 minute feature was comprised of over 160,000 cels and almost as many backgrounds, each one completely handäóñdrawn and hand-painted. Purists recognize Akira as the last completely hand-created animated feature, as cel animation quickly gave way to cheaper digital production and CGI technology.In 2010, the historical and artistic significance of Akira cannot be understated. As the popularity and influence of animation continues to expand, the Akira Exhibit gives audiences the unique opportunity to take a deeper look into this unparalleled achievement in filmmaking. Each item in the exhibit has been hand selected by Akira expert Joe Peacock from his unrivaled collection of more than 10, 000 authenticated pieces.Visitors will be given access to never-before-seen aspects of the film, from fully-displayed backgrounds, sketches and production development layouts, to the layers of cels that made up some of the most astounding scenes in the film.The Akira Exhibit promises to be an enthralling experience, sure to captivate any fan of animation and graphic storytelling, from anime enthusiast to those witnessing Otomoäó»s grand vision for the fist time.We are seeking public support to help present this remarkable exhibition. Your pledge helps pay for the cost of framing, marketing, and educational programing.Thank you.

I am a Mexican-born graphic designer and visual artist who moved to New York after living for 12 years in San Diego. After leaving my art studio in sunny San Diego in time to experience the most frigid New York winter in a decade, I found myself feeling disoriented, overwhelmed, alienated, aloneäóîand unemployed. And, without the ability to relieve stress through riding my bike through the city, I had to look for another artistic and emotional outlet!I found this on the train one day, when absent-mindedly sketching figures in the subway with a chisel-tipped sharpie. Because of the fast pace of the city, I was forced to work quickly to capture the behaviors of unsuspecting passengers: sleeping, frantically playing video games or simply reading newspapers. When it got too cold, I would duck into a Starbucks to observe life both inside the cafí© and out the window onto the street.Basically, the product that I hope to create would be 100 bound monograph art books. The books would contain both word and image, and would document, through quick, gestural sketches and accompanying text, my exploration of New York City from an outsider's standpoint. As the cityäó»s inhabitants begin unpeeling layers of insulated clothing, they will also begin to metaphorically reveal themselves as the weather gets warmer. I will also capture the changes in nature as winter evolves into spring, then summer.To me the idea of sketching comes from the need to understand human complexity and its ever- changing environment. I want to capture the essence of New Yorkäó»s daily life. New York is a beautiful and inspiring city; I donäó»t wish to be confined to working in my apartment. I want to venture out and be embraced by the fast pace of the city so that I can translate it to my sketches.In order to complete this project, I'll need to purchase daily triple-espressos, monthly Metrocards, a bunch of Sharpies and sketchbooks, a digital camera, a MacBook laptop, as well as funding to produce self-promotional materials (postcards, business cards and stickers).Thanks in advance!-gErardo yEpiz

Project Mission Statement:"While working as a field organizer for Barack Obama's 2008 Presidential Campaign it struck me that there was a side of campaigning that is never known until you live it. Our staff was often lauded for our close-knitted-ness, our tenacity, and our dedication. The behind-the-scenes story only reinforces this perception.Days seemed like weeks and if someone had a desk next to yours then there was a 90% chance that they would become your best friend before the first coffee break was over. And there were moments that illustrated all of this. I began capturing these - just for posterity's sake in my sketchbook. As the moments added up and interest in how this collection of young kids with (largely) no prior experience pulled off an amazing electoral victory began building, I began to see these moments coalescing to tell a greater story.A collection of 300 drawings that illustrate what it was really like.The heartache, the unbelievable stress, and the moments when despite everything you laugh for half an hour because someone screwed up and a sex hotline number was printed on a state-wide absentee mailer. This is what campaign life is about: the moments.The specifics are my own, yet my story is everyone's story on this campaign. The incredibly inspiring call to service that prompted me to hop a bus to New Hampshire, driving from Ohio to Mississippi with just a backpack to my name, and working with the smartest people I'll ever know.Many books will be written that tell the story of the candidate, or the candidate's top advisors. But we were the foot soldiers right on the frontline. And in many states, we were the margin of victory."THE PLAN:The book consists of 300 pen and ink drawings, as well as a running commentary throughout. 150 from the primaries (8 states) and 150 from the general. I am about 160 drawings into it.Each individual drawing takes about 6 hours to do, from conception to completion. You can imagine, with a day job as a campaign organizer, this time is hard to come by. And of course, in order for this book to be relevant, it needs to be completed as soon as possible. On a day off I can crank out 3 in a day. On a work day, I'm lucky to get a single one done.Without a job, I could finish this in 2 months.The goal of using Kickstarter as a funding platform is simple: Raise enough money to support myself for 2 months, sans day-job, get this thing done during those 2 months, and self-publish the first print.It seems very fitting to use a grassroots fundraising model for a project of this nature. In 2008 we used grassroots to get a man elected president. Surely in 2010, we can get a book published. :)I hope you'll consider donating to this project! There are some great items for each donation level to the side here, and I really can't do it without you!! Thanks!Also- please visit http://www.jennwhitcomb.com for a fun flash-filled glimpse into the making of this project, as well as more samples.

Viral Linguistics is a collaboration between musician Honeybear and visual artist Heather Kai Smith. Heather makes drawings calling back to the innocent illustrations of the 1950's and 60's while inserting emotion, creating a contemporary context for the familiar style. Honeybear weaves honest and lonesome narratives while keeping sight of the light even when exploring ghostly soundscapes of experimental-folk music.The fruit of the project will be a 40 page notebook/sketchbook with 10 drawings of Heather's scattered amongst the pages. The cover will be drawn by Heather, then silkscreened and assembled by Honeybear. Included will be two download codes (one for the notebook's owner and one to give to a friend) for a 6-track collection of music by Honeybear.The funding will be put towards printing, paper, bindery supplies, silk-screening supplies, and mastering for the recorded tracks.

An original collection that will include sketches, designs and writings (that are drawn) all in pen and ink. The book's format will be 8.5"x11", hard back and of course printed in black and white. The collection will consist of at least one hundred fifty pages and I have half the content already. The work continues daily, so the number of pages may naturally grow. The content will be extremely varied. From abstract line work, detailed figures & form, process sketches, graphic art, drawn poems, text design, favorite quotes by friends, family and other notables all in a drawn format as well as anything else that flows from the well. Your generous backing will aid in necessary supplies such as archival ink, pens, bristol paper, fees for digitizing images, the purchase of ISBN number and of course the printing production of the book itself. I'd love to go larger in format, so if enough backing arrives that can happen too. Let's make this happen!

"Return to Use"I am looking to build a tree structure completely out of recycled scrap metal. I am looking to keep a large majority of the pieces in their original form because I really want to show that, even in its original form, we can still use "old junk" for something and that is why it is called "Return to Use". The tree itself will be more of a fantasy design rather than reality and I plan to let my creativity go wild. Depending on donations, I want the tree to sand 12'-15' tall and 8'-10' wide. Along with the fantasy idea I am also going to use 200 LED lights, through out the project, to enhance the night features.I will be taking this piece to the 2010 Esthetic Evolution and my hopes are to also take it to the 2010 Burning Man event. The Esthetic Evolution (EE) is going to be held on June 17th-20th near Boise, ID and Burning Man is held in the Black Rock desert in Nevada at the end of August. I am looking for donations to complete the project before EE and additional funds to transport it to Burning Man. 100% of the donations will either go into the project or to the transportation of the art piece. Once everything is over, if their are any remaining donations I will invest those into another project on Kickstarter.

Eric Rosner has been illustrating in NYC for over 20 years, he has a unique style that recaptures a classic period of Manhattan and presents it for a new participating audience. Ink marker is used to create stunning iconic structures from a golden age. This process is combined with digital enhancements that complete a singular vision to showcase New York City's most eloquent inhabitants."I get lost in the moment when a piece comes to life. You find yourself thinking of all the people who have graced this grand Metropolis and these buildings have housed them all. Whether it was epic business transactions, stunning scientific discoveries or grand entertainment showcasing, the city of New York has a unique tale of histories. With my artwork I hope you can imagine a beautiful time period over a century ago when the imagination ran wild and magnificent structures soared to the sky. "The money raised will pay for arranging art shows, studio space and materials.For other examples of my works please check www.erosner.com

Contribute now and receive a limited edition print, a copy of the 7" vinyl project after its pressed and a digital copy of the music. Legend has it that Indian Nick was created by the early settlers of America, a hybrid Indian (Half Indian, Half European decent). Their intent was to utilize his skills and local knowledge to show them where all the good soil was for farming. Colonization began, and Indian Nick was the middle man, genocide or assimilation... the end goal. They gave him a bible and a horse when he left camp in the Spring of 1774, unfortunately the settlers plan backfired, Indian Nick sided with his indigenous brothers and sisters & has since been spotted in numerous locations and political events such as The Revolutionary War, Removal Era Wars, Battle of Antelope Hills, The Dakota War, The Black Hills War, The Battle of Powder River, Yakima War, Battle of Little Bighorn, Wounded Knee, The occupation of Alcatraz Island, Trail of Broken Treaties march, Takeover of DAM etc. If you happen to see Indian Nick, please notify authorities as he has several warrants for his arrest spanning across many old and new territories & borders.Disclaimer*(the limited edition print is not the image shown)The work you will receive is Indigenous in contentPreview the some of this music herehttp://indiannick.bandcamp.com/releaseshttp://lineout.thestranger.com/lineout/archives/2010/05/31/the-digital-indigenous

I am a former New York police forensic artist drawing 64 facial images of composite friends. I'll then draw a series of composites from the composites; 32 drawings combining four faces each, 16 drawings combining eight faces each, and so on until finally there is one drawing derived from all 128 faces.I'm posting the drawings to my website as each one is completed. I'm using charcoal on Stonehenge paper, 8.5 x 11". The first 64 people who sent in usable photos are included, and drawings are made in the order that the photos were received. From the initial set of 64, the original drawings will go to the friends of the people who sent in the photos - an experiment in gift economy. I began accepting submissions in November 2007 and filled up all the spots in May 2008. Participants include people from across the USA, Canada, United Kingdom, Australia, Brazil, China, and beyond.I've filled all the photo entries for this project, but now I'm looking for some financial support to help bring it to completion. As of June 2009, 36 drawings are done and I've got 91 left to make.Kickstarter funds will help pay for materials (paper, charcoal pencils, fixative, frames), as well as BFF posters and books that I'd like to make. I plan to have a show of the drawings in the physical world when they are all completed, and then distribute the originals. Putting on the show will involve a variety of costs as well (shipping, signage, invitations, etc). Supporting the BFF project will help this all come to fruition.BFF has been featured on Boing Boing and in FHM Germany. I posted a walk-through tutorial video, "How To Draw A BFF", to YouTube, and it's included on this page as well.To be updated when new drawings are posted, subscribe to my RSS News feed, or follow me on twitter @shawnfeeney. Pledging even just $1 will get you a shout-out on my website. If you've got deeper pockets, I'll draw you a custom BFF-style composite of your very own. You can pledge even if the goal has been met. Many thanks!

Public schools are struggling to provide students with a well-rounded education. Due to lack of adequate funding, art and music programs are at the bottom of the list. I started the Bone for a Brush project to support The Center for Arts Education by raising funds for their mission to ensure arts education for every public student in NYC.It began with a sculpture created in November 2008. I worked for several months with the assistance of artist Ted Lawson of Prototype Inc. constructing a 7-foot tall pillar of 156 cast wishbones. During the exhibition, the sculpture was knocked over and lay in a pile of ruin. Distraught over the whole ordeal, I did nothing. After a few weeks of mourning I had an epiphany and transformed the event into an impetus to do something positive and contribute to something I believe in: I would sell pieces of my sculpture and direct the proceeds to CAE, which would help keep the arts alive in NYC by providing arts education access for public school kids.About The Center for Arts EducationThe Center for Arts Education (CAE) is leading the change to restore quality arts education for every one of New York Cityäó»s more than one million public school students. They champion arts powered learning through three channels:Developing model teaching and learning programs for schools, parents, cultural organizations, and teaching artistsHelping parents become advocates as a part of their childrenäó»s art's educationWorking with elected officials and decision-makers to influence policies that will support public school arts educationLearn more about CAE at Visit CAE! or join their community on Facebook

I am having my first one person exhibition November 19 - 25, 2009. I am raising money to include people who may not be able to purchase an original piece of artwork as well as make all of you a part of this experience. The money that will be donated will go towards the production of the FACES Exhibition Book, a limited addition of prints and postcards. As we move closer to the deadline and the exhibit, I will be posting samples of the book on the site and on facebook, Those who a kind enough to be large supports will have the opportunity to be interviewed for the production of the DVD and the website. This will truly be a community based exhibition and we will have a ton of fun watching it unfold.

Being an artist living with three Labador Retrievers it's just normal to be painting them. I also wanted to make a difference somehow, so contacted Lab rescues, painting their Labs, then selling the artwork giving a percentage to the rescue. http://savingalabaday.blogspot.comMy Kickstarter Project is to raise funds for the Heart of Texas Labrador Rescue. www.hotlabrescue.org The Kestral Fund for Labradors helps those in extra need before they can go onto their forever home. So many come in hurt needing operations, heartworm medications or worse. During the past year HOTLAB rescue has taken in several dogs who would have otherwise been put down. There was Lance, who was use as a bait dog for fighting dogs, Besty required skin grafts on her elbows, Phoenix, who had a shattered rear leg and Malibu, who was shot in the shoulder. If HOTLab had not stepped in each of these dogs would have ben put down and now they have a new lease on life.Why is it called the San Antonio Project? Because it is timed out such that we can present the proceeds at a Fund Raiser they are having in San Antonio on November 7, 2009 at the Fairmount Hotel. So please join me in helping this most worthy organizations.

Hello Everyone,Short and simple, hereäó»s our project. Weäó»d like to do a small First Edition production run of this brand new - hot off the workbench - fun pop-up-drawing.This design solves a 4-year challenge of ours: finding an artful way to reproduce our innovative concave drawings.You can understand our predicament. Afterall, reproducing 'concave' drawings on any 'flat' surface isäó_well, impossible. That rules out almost all modes of mass-display: books, photos, computer screens, etc. Everything is flat, and for good reason, flat = space efficient. However, one happy medium bridges both worldsäó_the pop-up! :)Our design is complete, engineered to a T, and weäó»re sourcing a manufacturer. Talking shop with several assembly houses, weäó»re just about ready to move. This is where you come in.Hereäó»s part of an email from one of the companies weäó»ve been communicating with:äóìI am in absolute awe of your pop up engineering ability. This is unbelievable. Your design is one of the most intricate Iäó»ve seen. Now for the bad news äóñ itäó»s going to be expensive to produce.äóThis manufacturer is the leading contender for the bid. And weäó»re glad sheäó»s on board. Itäó»s been tough to convince anyone to take this on; people are just spooked by the complexity. But you are not!With your help, her teams can hit the ground running with our design, buckle down with glue and paper, and the First Edition Oakes-pop-up will be born!Check out our prizes to the right for varying levels of support. Any amount you donate will be greatly appreciated.Thank you,Ryan & Trevor Oakes- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -The image on this concave pop-up is of The Field Museum in Chicago. We drew it as part of our exhibit there last spring. The original drawing is in the collection of The Field Museum. It is the most intricate rendering weäó»ve made so far.- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -For more information about our concave drawings please visit: www.OakesOakes.comLawrence Weschler, "Double Vision: The Art of Trevor and Ryan Oakes" Spring 2009. Learning "to see" is the most fundamental task for an artist. Drawing directly from life in ink has taught me to trust my hand and eye connection as I must live with the lines I put on the paper. And it also has taught me to let go, and risk, being in the moment, to put the lines down with spirit and conviction, win or lose. My lines do have this spirit of life. The ultimate use of the creative process is about transforming our consciousness and living sustainably in harmony with all life.In 2000 I published a book of ink drawings produced over 16 years on the NYC Subway. This book has been well received and sold in the MTA Transit Museums. For this new project I will pull together a much broader spectrum of drawings from the last 40 years. Living and working in New York City has provided me with fertile ground to cultivate ideas and observe the greatest human diversity on the planet. This exciting book will include drawings of subway riders; buildings and locals (e.g., bars, cafes, restaurants, waiting rooms, music events, poetry readings); portraits of the wonderful people I have been blessed to meet; and studies from the great master works in museums; The LIVING LINE will also document the development of themes and ideas I have explored through line drawing..The "LIVING LINE: A 40 Year Odyssey Through Drawings" will be at least 100 pages and have between 75 - 150 ink drawings interspersed with NY stories, insights about life in the city, and thoughts about culture and the creative process. There will be a limited 75 hardcover Collector Edition books available plus a soft-cover edition for wider distribution. This book will provide an intimate look at life through the sensitive eyes of an artist.It is very important to me to get my work out there for people to see and enjoy. Having spent my entire adult life translating the world around me into ink lines, has offered me the opportunity to be an observer, to collect impressions and see much of what others pass by unnoticed. Being an artist and learning "to see", and drawing continuously over many years, has kept me connected to life in an honest and passionate way. I hope this book becomes a reality and you too have the opportunity to take this odyssey through the living line. One of my main goals as an artist and a man, is to bring my expertise of the Creative Process to personally transform myself to a higher level of consciousness, but also to disseminate what I know and have learned to others. Without widespread use and understanding of the creative process, we lessen our ability to envision, actualize and sustain life on this planet.If you know me and my work or not, this is your opportunity to jump in and be part of of the creative process with me. I want your support so I can bring these drawings together in a meaningful way and share them with others. This is your opportunity to support my life's work.The money collected will pay for compilation, layout / design, printing, launch and distribution plus payment processing fees, and I hope new drawings.The holidays are coming and this will make a perfect gift. I do appreciate very much your interest and I know you will return again and again to look at the "living lines" in this book.I will list all my backers in the book to so their vital support will be acknowledged and always be with the book.Here is a link to view a selection of drawings by Richard Gins:http://www.facebook.com/album.php...Here's a link to my Subway Rider book:http://www.youtube.com/watch...Thanks again,Richard Gins

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------What is The Endangered Species Print Project (ESPP)? :The Endangered Species Print Project offers limited-edition prints of critically endangered species. The number of prints available corresponds with the remaining animal or plant populations.For example, only 35 Amur Leopards remain in the wild, so for this edition, only 35 prints will ever be made.All net proceeds from ESPP are donated to conservation organizations. A different organization, whose mission is to the ensure the survival of the specie depicted, is chosen for each print.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Can you Tell Me More?ESPP is the brainchild of Chicago-based artists Molly Schafer and Jenny Kendler. The project was born from the desire to operate outside the white-wall gallery system and use their artistic talents to support conservation efforts and biodiversity on Planet Earth. ESPP is a labor of love for Schafer and Kendler, who manage all aspects of the project and the creation of the original artwork, along with their day-jobs and individual artistic practices. As the project progresses, ESPP will be releasing additional prints on a monthly basis, including works by guest artists.Since information on these rare species can be hard to come by, the ESPP site also features short articles on each species. Schafer and Kendler are in close touch with researchers working in the field to confirm the accuracy of their information and to stay up to date on news and population counts. The net proceeds from the sale of all prints goes directly to these researchers & organizations assisting in the conservation of these highly endangered creatures.The first five prints offered by ESPP are: The Panamanian Golden Frog, The Vancouver Island Marmot, The Seychelles Sheath-tailed Bat, The Indri Lemur and The Amur Leopard (being posted soon!). ESPP's first guest artist will also soon be posting the amazing Giant Gomeran Lizard as ESPP's 6th print.These species are all critically endangered --- and it just so happens, rather charming. The vibrant prints, mash-ups of science and whimsy, are highly limited editions. So get yours before they disappear --- and help prevent these species from disappearing too!-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------How are Things Going With ESPP?ESPP has received very positive responses and has recently been featured on the home pages of Juxtapoz Magazine, Cool Hunting, Design Milk, Pikaland, OMG Posters!, and was written up in the Sierra Club's blog: The Green Life. ESPP continues to work with other conservation organizations and has upcoming plans to collaborate on prints and promotions with the Center for Biological Diversity. As the project moves into late 2009 and 2010, ESPP will be actively seeking funding to increase it's scope and effectiveness.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Please check out our website at: http://endangeredspeciesprintproject.com-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Why is ESPP asking for your donation?:ESPP is a not for profit venture. We do not make an income managing or illustrating for the project. Artists donate both their time and work. The cost of the prints cover the production costs and fund the associated conservation organization.Right now anyone who buys a print from ESPP, since ESPP is not a 501(c)(3), must pay us in two separate transactions for tax reasons --- one check or online payment to reimburse our expenses and one payment that will be donated directly to the conservation organization. We would like to streamline this process into a one transaction method. The intent is to both streamline the sales process and be able to give a larger amount of the sale of prints to the conservation organizations.Because of the two payment transaction being complicated, confusing and inconvenient for people, we believe that we are getting fewer sales, and these critically endangered species are left with less money to ensure their survival. The high number of hits we receive on our website vs. the lower number of sales seems to point to the difficult transaction process.Because of this, we'd like to be funded through Kickstarter to cover our own personal expenditures, which include the following production costs of:- Printing- Recycled Mailers- Glassine Sleeves- Postage- ShippingWe consider the time that we spend creating the artwork and the artwork itself to be donated, but because we both work full-time jobs in addition to working on the very time-consuming ESPP, we are hoping for support on our personal efforts.If we are funded to cover our expenses, then people can make just one payment when they purchase and ESPP print.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The Best Part!:The best part is that once funded we can then give 100% of our next 100 sales to the associated conservation organizations --- doubling the amount of funds that go to these amazing groups working in the field to preserve biodiversity! Some of these organizations are very small and focused, so have few other sources of funding. We can make a big difference if we all work together to help them out.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Our Goal:Our goal is $2500, enough to fund 100 prints or more and with their sale on our site, to raise $5000 or more for conservation --- but we would love to double or even triple that amount!-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
